page.title: Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles

revision.text:
[[File:Recharging unit.jpg|thumb|[[Plug-in electric vehicle]]s subject to incentives in some countries include [[battery electric vehicle]]s, [[plug-in hybrid]]s and [[electric vehicle conversion]]s. Shown here is a [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]] recharging]]
'''Government incentives for plug-in hybrid electric vehicles''' have been established by several national governments and local authorities around the world as a financial incentives to [[plug-in electric vehicle]] vehicles to consumers. These mainly include tax exemptions and [[tax credit]]s, and additional perks that range from access to bus lanes to waivers on fees (charging, parking, tolls, etc.).<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/GlobalEVOutlook2017.pdf|title=Global EV Outlook 2007: Two million and counting.|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=International Energy Agency|access-date=}}</ref> The amount of these incentives usually depend on [[Electric-vehicle battery|battery]] size and the vehicle all-electric range, and some countries extend the benefits to [[fuel cell vehicle]]s, and [[electric vehicle conversion]]s of [[hybrid electric vehicle]]s and conventional [[internal combustion engine]] vehicles. The [[Institute of Economic Affairs|IEA]] determined that, as of 2016, 0.2% of all passenger vehicles (approximately 2 million) currently on the road worldwide are electric.<ref name=":0">{{citation|title=Which Countries Have the Best Incentives for EV Purchases?|url=https://www.fleetcarma.com/countries-best-incentives-ev.purchases/|publisher=Fleetcarma|accessdate=2017-10-04}}</ref>
The world's total final consumption of energy by sector represented 9,426 Million [[Tonne of oil equivalent|Tonnes of Oil Equivalent]] (Mtoe) in 2014, 28% of which is attributed to transport alone, accounting for an increase of 5% from 1971 statistics.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/KeyWorldEnergyTrends.pdf|title=Excerpt from: World energy balances|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=International Energy Agency|access-date=}}</ref> Moreover, 23% of energy-related [[Greenhouse gas|Greenhouse Gas (GHG)]] emissions worldwide are also attributable to transport.<ref name=":12"/> Thus, the electrification of the transport sector represents an area of opportunity for governments to cut their GHG emissions,<ref name=":12"/> which is why they are starting to champion policies that increase plug-in hybrid electric vehicles adoption rates. [[File:Total_final_consumption_of_energy_by_sector.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Total_final_consumption_of_energy_by_sector.png|thumb|'''Total final consumption of energy by sector.''' The world's energy consumption more than doubled between 1971 (4,244 Mtoe) and 2014 (9,426 Mtoe). Even though the proportion of energy consumption per sector did not dramatically change, the percentage of energy consumption from transport increased by 5%.]]
==Asia==
===China=== {{Main|New energy vehicles in China}} {{See also|Renewable energy in China|Automobile industry in China}} {{update|section|date=September 2014}} [[File:BYD Electric Taxi.jpg|thumb|[[BYD e6]] all-electric taxi in [[Shenzhen, China]].]]
The Chinese government adopted a plan in 2009 with the goal of turning the country into one of the leaders of all-electric and [[hybrid vehicle]]s by 2012. The government's intention was to create a world-leading industry that would produce jobs and exports, and to reduce urban pollution and its oil dependence. However, a study found that even though local air pollution would be reduced by replacing a gasoline car with a similar-size electric car, it would reduce [[greenhouse gas]] emissions by only 19%, as China uses coal for 75% of its electricity production.<ref name=NYTChina>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/02/business/global/02electric.html|title=China Vies to Be World's Leader in Electric Cars|publisher=The New York Times|first=Keith|last=Bradsher|date=2009-04-01|accessdate=2009-04-05}}</ref>
The Chinese government uses the term [[new energy vehicle]]s (NEVs) to designate plug-in electric vehicles, and only pure electric vehicles and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles are subject to purchase incentives.<ref name=NEVs>{{cite web|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EXTNEWSCHINESE/Resources/3196537-1202098669693/EV_Report_en.pdf|title=The China New Energy Vehicles Program - Challenges and Opportunities |author=PRTM Management Consultants, Inc.|publisher=[[World Bank]]|date=April 2011|accessdate=2013-04-22}} ''See Acronyms and Key Terms, pp. v''</ref> On June 1, 2010, the [[People's Republic of China|Chinese]] government announced a trial program to provide incentives up to 60,000 [[Chinese yuan|yuan]] (~{{USD|9,281}} in June 2011) for private purchase of new [[battery electric vehicle]]s and 50,000 yuan (~{{USD|7,634}} in June 2011) for [[plug-in hybrid]]s in five cities.<ref name=EdmondsCh>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2010/06/china-announces-plan-to-subsidize-evs-and-plug-in-hybrids-in-five-major-cities.html |title=China Announces Plan to Subsidize EVs and Plug-in Hybrids in Five Major Cities |publisher=[[Edmunds.com]] |date=2010-06-01 |accessdate=2010-06-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605040731/http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2010/06/china-announces-plan-to-subsidize-evs-and-plug-in-hybrids-in-five-major-cities.html |archivedate=2010-06-05 |df= }}</ref><ref name=NYT0610>{{cite news|url=http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/02/china-to-start-pilot-program-providing-subsidies-for-electric-cars-and-hybrids/|title=China to Start Pilot Program, Providing Subsidies for Electric Cars and Hybrids|publisher=New York Times|date=2010-06-02|accessdate=2010-06-02 | first=Jim | last=Motavalli}}</ref> The cities participating in the pilot program are [[Shanghai]], [[Shenzhen]], [[Hangzhou]], [[Hefei]] and [[Changchun]]. The subsidies are paid directly to automakers rather than consumers, but the government expects that vehicle prices will be reduced accordingly. The amount of the subsidy will be reduced once 50,000 units are sold.<ref name=EdmondsCh/><ref name=NYT0610/> In addition to the subsidy, the Chinese government is planning to introduce, beginning on January 1, 2012, an exemption from annual taxes for pure electric, fuel-cell, and plug-in hybrid vehicles. Hybrid vehicles will be eligible for a 50% reduction only.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2011-06/20/content_12731970.htm|title=Taxes slashed to cut emissions|last=Han |first=Tianyang|work=[[China Daily]]|date=2011-06-20|accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref>
In 2011, only 8,159 electric cars were sold in China despite a 120,000 yuan subsidy. Unsubsidized lead-acid EVs are produced without government approval at a rate of more than 30,000 per year in [[Shandong]] and requires no driving license because the top speed is less than 50 km/h. They cost 31,600 yuan and have been the target of criticism from major car manufacturers.<ref name=reuShi>{{cite news |first1=Fang |last1=Yan |first2=Ken |last2=Wills |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/19/us-china-mini-ev-idUSBRE83I0CZ20120419 |title=Mini electric cars fill gap in China as official EVs sputter |publisher=[[Reuters]] |location=US |date=2012-04-19 |access-date=2012-04-24}}</ref>
A mid-September joint announcement in 2013 by the National Development and Reform Commission and finance, science, and industry ministries confirmed that the central government will provide a maximum of {{USD|9,800}} toward the purchase of an all-electric passenger vehicle and up to {{USD|81,600}} for an electric bus. The subsidies are part of the government's efforts to address China's problematic air pollution.<ref>{{cite news|title=China announces new electric car subsidy program|url=http://www.chinaeconomicreview.com/node/64577|accessdate=2013-09-18|newspaper=China Economic Review|date=2013-09-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217055135/http://www.chinaeconomicreview.com/node/64577#|archive-date=2013-12-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
As a result of the government support and new incentives issued in 2014, production of new energy vehicles between January and August reached 31,137 units, up 328% from the same period of 2013. Domestic production during the first eight months of 2014 includes 6,621 plug-in hybrid sedans and 16,276 all-electric cars.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ecns.cn/business/2014/09-07/133426.shtml|title=China's Jan.-Aug. NEV production up 328 percent |last=Gu |first=Liping|work=Xinhua|publisher=ECNS|date=2014-09-07|accessdate=2014-09-07}}</ref>
Additionally, to further electric vehicle production, China passed measures to greatly increase the number of electric vehicles on the road. Original policy declared that companies with vehicles sales of over 30,000 vehicles must comply with new rules around NEVs. Each company was required to fulfill a number of NEV credits, as much as 8% by the year 2018. This target was later pushed to 2019, with a requirement of 12% by 2020. These credits are granted by the fuel efficiency and weight of the vehicles, so more fuel efficient vehicles count for more credits. Originally, these credits were granted according to the vehicles' range, however the final policy provided a more continuous way of determine credits. The breakdown of credits in the original proposal are given below: {| class="wikitable" |+Proposed Credit Policy !Electric Range (km) !Per-vehicle credit |- |'''80-150''' |2 |- |'''150-250''' |3 |- |'''250-350''' |4 |- |'''≥ 350''' |5 |} In the final policy, credits were instead given by the formula: (0.012 × electric range + 0.8) × adjustment factor. These credits were capped at 6. Additionally, these credits can be bought and sold.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/China-NEV-mandate_ICCT-policy-update_20032018_vF-updated.pdf |title=China’s New Energy Vehicle Mandate Policy (Final Rule) |publisher=International Council on Clean Transportation |date=January 2018 |access-date=2018-07-01}}</ref>
In February 2018, to further promote energy-efficient electric vehicles, China raised subsidies for electric vehicles meeting additional range requirements. Electric vehicle incentives for cars with at least 400 km of range increased from 44,000 yuan to 50,000 yuan, while vehicles with less than 150 km of range have been removed from the list of vehicles qualifying for an incentive.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-13/china-raises-subsidies-to-reward-longer-traveling-electric-cars|title=China Raises Subsidies to Reward Longer Range Electric Cars|last=|first=|date=2018-02-13 |work=Bloomberg}}</ref> Changes were also made to the incentive structure for electric buses and trucks. Buses are now required to have a range of at least 150 km and have energy consumption of less than 0.7 Wh/km·kg.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/China-NEV_ICCT_policy-update_17052017_vF.pdf |title=Adjustment to subsidies for New Energy Vehicles in China |publisher=International Council on Clean Transportation |date=May 2017 |access-date=2018-07-01}}</ref>
===India=== [[File:REVA NXR.jpg|thumb|[[Mahindra e2o]] which is manufactured in India]]
In November 2010, the Government of India (GoI), through the [[Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]] (MNRE), announced a subsidy of {{currency|950|INR}} million for electric vehicles. The subsidy provided benefits up to 20% on the ex-factory price, with a maximum benefit of {{currency|100,000|INR}} on electric cars, {{currency|4,000|INR}} on two-wheelers, {{currency|5,000|INR}} on high speed two-wheelers, {{currency|400,000|INR}} for electric minibuses, and {{currency|60,000|INR}} for three-wheelers. To claim the subsidy, manufacturers needed to certify that 30% of the components were made in India. The scheme ended on 31 March 2012.<ref name=IndiaSalesDrop>{{cite news |title=Electric vehicles sales drop after subsidy scheme ends |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-06-18/news/32299423_1_subsidy-scheme-cash-subsidy-sohinder-gill |accessdate=2015-01-14 |work=[[The Economic Times]] |date=2012-06-18}}</ref><ref name=IndiaApproves>{{cite news |title=India Approves Incentives for Electric Vehicles |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-22/india-approves-incentives-for-electric-vehicles-update1-.html |accessdate=2015-01-14 |work=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]] |date=2014-11-22}}</ref><ref name=IndiaSubsidyWall>{{cite news |title=How India's e-vehicle dream crashed into the subsidy wall |url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/how-india-s-e-vehicle-dream-crashed-into-the-subsidy-wall-114082600021_1.html |accessdate=2015-01-14 |work=[[Business Standard]] |date=2014-08-26}}</ref>
In April 2014, the Indian government announced a new plan to provide subsidies for hybrid and electric vehicles. The plan will have subsidies up to {{currency|150,000|INR}} for cars and {{currency|30,000|INR}} on two-wheelers. India aims to have seven million electric vehicles on the road by 2020.<ref name=IndiaNewPlan>{{cite news |title=Boost for electric and hybrid cars with Rs 1.5 Lakh subsidy |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/business/companies/boost-for-electric-and-hybrid-cars-with-rs-1-5-lakh-subsidy/99/ |accessdate=2015-01-14 |work=[[The Indian Express]] |date=2014-04-18}}</ref>
There is no subsidy or incentive for hybrids and imported vehicles, which acts as a deterrent to new entrants. To meet the stated GoI objectives under the Paris Accord, the GoI has set deadline for 'Only Electric Vehicle (Manufacturing)' by 2030. Although highly ambitious as it may seem, there is growing recognition among policy makers to incentivise electric vehicle manufacturing under the 'Make In India ' policy, and a new framework policy for this was to be released by year end, 2017. Moreover, infrastructure for electric vehicle charging is also being considered; provided either through existing energy retailers like fuel pumps or by subsidising manufacturers' investments in the field.
Tesla Motors has been offered tax incentives and potential financial backing via Special Purpose Vehicles ('SPV's) to establish a domestic manufacturing unit in India. Although, there are local sourcing norms of 30%, electric vehicle entrants have been exempted. Yet much will depends on governments plan to subsidise the vehicle, due their high upfront cost, that will determine any potential shift in the market.
According to an [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] report, India is regarded as a country providing the least subsidies, compared to other major markets, to renewable energy in electric vehicle and that may hamper the governments target of achieving the all electric target by 2030.
Various state governments and cities provide their own subsidies:<ref>{{cite web|title=Electric Vehicle India |url=https://www.tekes.fi/globalassets/global/ohjelmat-ja-palvelut/ohjelmat/eve/selvitykset/finpro_electric_mobility_in_india_2013.pdf |first1=Rekha |last1=Salvi |first2=Sreehari B. |last2=Nambiar |publisher=[[Tekes (agency)|Tekes: Finnish Funding Agency for Innovation]] |accessdate=2015-01-14 |date=2013}}</ref> * Delhi, Rajasthan, Uttarakhand and Lakshadweep don't levy [[Value added tax|VAT]] * Chandigarh, Madhya Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat & West Bengal offer partial rebate on VAT * Delhi also provides a 15% subsidy of the base price of select electric cars, like [[REVAi|REVA]]. It also exempts such cars from road tax and registration fees.
===Japan=== {{See also|Plug-in electric vehicles in Japan}}
The Japanese government introduced the first electric vehicle incentive program in 1996, and it was integrated in 1998 with the Clean Energy Vehicles Introduction Project, which provided subsidies and tax discounts for the purchase of [[electric vehicle|electric]], [[natural gas vehicle|natural gas]], [[methanol fuel|methanol]] and [[hybrid electric vehicle]]s. The project provided a purchase subsidy of up to 50% the incremental costs of a clean energy vehicle as compared with the price of a conventional engine vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evaap.org/pdf/incentive.pdf|title=Incentives for EV & HEV|date=October 2003|publisher=Electric Vehicle Association of Asia Pacific|accessdate=2010-06-06}}</ref> This program was extended until 2003.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Max |last=Ahman|title=Government policy and the development of electric vehicles in Japan|journal=Energy Policy|date=March 2006|pages=433–443|issue=34|doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2004.06.011}}</ref>
In May 2009 the [[National Diet]] passed the "Green Vehicle Purchasing Promotion Measure" that went into effect on June 19, 2009, but retroactive to April 10, 2009.<ref name=JAMAFact/> The program established tax deductions and exemptions for [[Green vehicle|environmentally friendly]] and fuel efficient vehicles, according to a set of stipulated environmental performance criteria, and the requirements are applied equally to both foreign and domestic produced vehicles. The program provides purchasing subsidies for two type of cases, consumers purchasing a new passenger car without trade-in (non-replacement program), and for those consumers buying a new car trading an used car registered 13 years ago or earlier ([[scrappage program]]).<ref name=JAMAFact>{{cite web|url=http://jama.org/pdf/FactSheet10-2009-09-24.pdf |title=Fact Sheet - Japanese Government Incentives for the Purchase of Environmentally Friendly Vehicles |publisher=[[Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association]] |accessdate=2010-12-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226222150/http://www.jama.org/pdf/FactSheet10-2009-09-24.pdf |archivedate=2010-12-26 |df= }}</ref><ref name=JAMA2010>{{cite web|url=http://www.jama-english.jp/publications/MIJ2010.pdf|title=The Motor Industry of Japan 2010|publisher=[[Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association]]|accessdate=2010-12-24}} ''See pages 45–46''.</ref>
====Tonnage and acquisition tax reductions==== [[File:Lawson-car.jpg|thumb|The cost of the [[Mitsubishi i MiEV]] in [[Japan]] falls from [[Japanese yen|¥]]4 million to ¥2.8 million after all government incentives are discounted from the sales price.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nb20100403a1.html|title=Showrooms get i-MiEV, first cheap electric car|first=Yuri |last=Kageyama ([[Associated Press]])|publisher=[[The Japan Times]]|date=2010-04-03|accessdate=2010-06-06}}</ref>]]
New next generation vehicles, including electric and [[fuel cell vehicle]]s, [[plug-in hybrid]]s, [[hybrid electric vehicle]]s, [[clean diesel]] and [[natural gas vehicle]]s are exempted from both the acquisition tax and the [[tonnage tax]].<ref name=JAMA2010/><ref name=JAMANews>{{cite journal|url=http://www.jama-english.jp/asia/news/2009/vol36/index.html|publisher=[[Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association]]|accessdate=2010-06-06|journal=News from JAMA Asia|issue=36|date=September 2009|title=Japan's measures to withstand impact of global crisis on its automotive industry - JAMA shares at the 4th Indonesia International Automotive Conference}}</ref> Acquisition taxes on used vehicles will be reduced by 1.6% to 2.7%, or between 150,000 yen (~US$1,600) and 300,000 yen (~US$3,200). Electric and fuel cell vehicles have a 2.7% reduction while plug-in hybrids have a 2.4% reduction.<ref name=JAMA2010/><ref name=Outlook/>
These incentives are effected from April 1, 2009 until March 31, 2012 for the acquisition tax which is paid once at the time of purchase. The tonnage tax reductions are in effect from April 1, 2009 until April 30, 2012 and the incentive is applicable once, at the time of the first mandatory inspection, three years after the vehicle purchase.<ref name=JAMA2010/><ref name=JAMANews/> As an example, the amount exempted for the purchase of a new next generation vehicle is 81,000 yen (~US$975) corresponding to the acquisition tax, and 22,500 yen (~US$271) for the tonnage tax, for a total of 103,500 yen (~US$1,246).<ref name=JAMA2010/>
====Automobile tax reductions==== Consumers purchasing new next generation electric vehicles, including fuel cell vehicles, benefited from a 50% reduction of the annual automobile tax. These incentives were in effect from April 1, 2009 until March 31, 2010, applicable only once.<ref name=JAMA2010/>
====Incentives for purchasing new green vehicles==== Subsidies for purchases of new environmentally friendly vehicles without scrapping a used car are 100,000 yen (~US$1,100) for the purchase of a standard or small car, and 50,000 yen (~US$550) for the purchase of a [[kei car|mini or kei vehicle]]. Subsidies for purchasing trucks and buses meeting the stipulated fuel efficiency and emission criteria vary between 200,000 yen (~US$2,100) to 900,000 yen (~US$9,600).<ref name=JAMAFact/><ref name=JAMANews/><ref name=Outlook/>
Subsidies for purchases of new environmentally friendly vehicles in the case of owners scrapping a 13-year or older vehicle are 250,000 yen (~US$2,700) for the purchase of a standard or small car, and 125,000 yen (~US$1,300) for the purchase of a mini or kei vehicle. Subsidies for purchasing trucks and buses meeting the stipulated fuel efficiency and emission criteria vary between 400,000 yen (~US$4,300) to 1,800,000 yen (~US$19,000).<ref name=JAMAFact/><ref name=JAMANews/><ref name=Outlook/>
All incentives for new purchases with or without trading were applicable in Japan's fiscal year 2009, from April 1, 2009 through March 31, 2010.<ref name=JAMANews/><ref name=Outlook>{{cite web|url=http://www.marklines.com/en/rinji/outlookfor2009_sales_en.jsp#japan|title=Sales Promotion Scheme and 2009 Vehicle Sales Forecasts - Japan: Rebate for purchase or replacement with eco-friendly vehicles|publisher=Marklines.com|accessdate=2010-06-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426043330/http://www.marklines.com/en/rinji/outlookfor2009_sales_en.jsp#japan|archivedate=2009-04-26|df=}}</ref>
===Philippines=== Under President Duterte's administration, the [[Tax Reform for Acceleration and Inclusion Act]] was signed into law, which has exemptions made for anyone buying an electric vehicle alongside hybrids.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.autoindustriya.com/features/excise-tax-simulation-how-expensive-will-the-cars-of-2018-be.html |title=Excise Tax Simulation: How expensive will the cars of 2018 be? |first=Vince |last=Pornelos |work=AutoIndustriya |location=Philippines |date=2017-12-19 |access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref>
=== South Korea ===
In July 2016, the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy announced a plan to make electric car batteries run longer, build a network of charging stations and make electric car purchases and ownership more affordable. The government expects that the current and future policy programs will help increase the electric car market share in South Korea to 0.5% in 2017, up from 0.2% in 2015, and to achieve 5.3% in 2020.<ref name=Korea2020>{{cite news | url=http://www.bna.com/south-korea-formulates-n73014444008/ | title=South Korea Formulates Ambitious Plan to Promote E-Cars | first=James | last=Lim | work=Blomberg BNA | date=2016-07-10 | accessdate=2016-09-24}}</ref>
The government subsidy has in place a one-time purchase subsidy for electric cars. Effective July 8, 2016, the subsidy was increased to 14 million won ({{USD|12,100}}) from 12 million won ({{USD|10,400}}). Also starting in 2016, the purchase tax surcharges of electric cars will be reduced, and all-electric car drivers will benefit from reductions in insurance premiums, expressway tolls and parking fees. The government plan calls for the deployment of fast charging stations in 2020 to be available at an average of one within a two-kilometer radius in the capital city of Seoul. In addition, 30,000 slow charging stations will be strategically located at about 4,000 apartment complexes nationwide by 2020.<ref name=Korea2020/>
The government's plan also includes the development of an electric car battery, beginning in 2016, with energy density high enough to more than double the travel distance on a charge to {{Convert|400|km|abbr=on}}. The government expects to increase the global market share of South Korean electric cars to match that of South Korean gasoline and diesel cars, which reached 8.5% based on sales by South Korea's two main car exporters, [[Hyundai Motor Company]] and [[Kia Motors]].<ref name=Korea2020/>
==Europe==
[[Electrification of transport]] ([[electromobility]]) figures prominently in the Green Car Initiative (GCI),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.green-cars-initiative.eu |title=PPP European Green Cars Initiative |publisher=Green-cars-initiative.eu |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref> included in the European Economic Recovery Plan. [[Directorate-General for Mobility and Transport (European Commission)|DG TREN]] is supporting a large European "electromobility" project on EVs and related infrastructure with a total budget of around {{euro|50 million}} as part of the Green Car Initiative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/transport/urban/vehicles/road/electric_en.htm |title=Transport: Electric vehicles - European commission |publisher=Ec.europa.eu |accessdate=2009-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319033116/http://ec.europa.eu/transport/urban/vehicles/road/electric_en.htm |archivedate=2011-03-19 |df= }}</ref>
There are measures to promote efficient vehicles in the [[Directive 2009/33/EC]] of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 April 2009 on the promotion of clean and energy-efficient road transport vehicles<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:120:0005:0012:EN:PDF |title=DIRECTIVE 2009/33/EC OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 April 2009 on the promotion of clean and energy-efficient road transport vehicles |accessdate=2010-12-26}}</ref> and in the Directive 2006/32/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 April 2006 on [[efficient energy use|energy end-use efficiency]] and energy services.
As of April 2011, 15 of the 27 [[European Union member states]] provide tax incentives for [[plug-in electric vehicle|electrically chargeable vehicles]], which includes all [[Western Europe]]an countries plus the [[Czech Republic]] and [[Romania]]. Also 17 countries levy [[greenhouse gas emissions|carbon dioxide]] related taxes on passenger cars as a disincentive. The incentives consist of tax reductions and exemptions, as well as of bonus payments for buyers of PEVs, [[hybrid electric vehicle|hybrid vehicles]], and some [[alternative fuel vehicle]]s.<ref name=NYT072911>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/31/automobiles/europes-incentive-plans-for-spurring-ev-sales.html?_r=1&emc=eta1|title=Europe's Incentive Plans for Spurring E.V. Sales|first=Paul |last=Hockenos|publisher=The New York Times|date=2011-07-29|accessdate=2011-07-31}}</ref><ref name=ACEA2>{{cite web|url=http://www.acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110330_EV_tax_overview.pdf |title=Overview of Purchase and Tax Incentives for Electric Vehicles in the EU |publisher=[[European Automobile Manufacturers Association]] |date=2011-03-14 |accessdate=2011-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927060852/http://www.acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110330_EV_tax_overview.pdf |archivedate=2011-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
===Austria=== Electric vehicles are exempted from the fuel consumption tax, levied upon the first registration, and from the monthly vehicle tax. In addition to tax breaks, [[hybrid electric vehicle|hybrid vehicle]]s and other [[alternative fuel vehicle]]s benefit from a fuel consumption tax that pays bonuses to passenger cars with low carbon dioxide output. Alternative fuel vehicles, including hybrids, qualify for as much as {{euro|800}} (around {{USD|1,120}}) in annual bonuses. This bonus was valid from 1 July 2008 until 31 August 2012.<ref name=NYT072911/><ref name=ACEA2/> Additionally, cars with no carbon emissions qualify for a deduction of the VAT (Value-Added Tax), as of January 2016.<ref name="EU-overview">{{cite web |url=http://www.acea.be/uploads/publications/EV_incentives_overview_2017.pdf |title=Overview on Tax Incentives for Electric Vehicles in the EU |publisher=European Automobile Manufacturers Association |year=2017 |access-date=2018-07-01}}</ref>
===Belgium=== The Belgian government established a personal income tax deduction of 30% of the purchase price including [[VAT]] of a new electric vehicle, up to €9,190. [[Plug-in hybrid]]s are not eligible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.going-electric.org/vehicules-electriques/nouvelles/cp100203-avantages-financiers-belgique.htm |title=Incitants à l'achat de véhicules électriques en Belgique, Press Release |publisher=Going Electric |date=2010-02-04 |accessdate=2011-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005021946/http://www.going-electric.org/vehicules-electriques/nouvelles/cp100203-avantages-financiers-belgique.htm |archivedate=2011-10-05 |df= }}</ref><ref name=Belg>{{cite web|language=French|url=http://minfin.fgov.be/portail2/fr/downloads/composition/ssp-environment-taxation-09-11-20.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706134124/http://minfin.fgov.be/portail2/fr/downloads/composition/ssp-environment-taxation-09-11-20.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-07-06|title=Conseil des Ministres : nouvelles mesures éco-fiscales, Press Release|publisher=Ministre des Finances|date=2009-11-20|accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref><ref name=ACEA3/> This tax incentive ended on December 31, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://monargent.lecho.be/budget_et_temps_libre/budget/La_voiture_electrique_ne_s_impose_toujours_pas.9253324-2223.art?ckc=1|title=La voiture électrique ne s'impose toujours pas|language=French|trans-title=The electric car still is not essential|first=Carine |last=Mathieu|work=[[L'Echo]]|date=2012-10-12|accessdate=2012-11-17}}</ref> There is also available a tax deduction up to 40% for investments in external [[recharging station]]s publicly accessible, to a maximum of €250.<ref name=Belg/> The [[Wallonia]] regional government has an additional {{euro|4,500}} eco-bonus for cars registered before December 31, 2011.<ref name=NBelgium>{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/06/11/nissan-leaf-priced-as-low-as-27-800-40-254-u-s-in-belgium/|title=Nissan Leaf priced as low as €27,800* ($40,254 U.S.) in Belgium|first=Eric |last=Loveday |publisher=AutoblogGreen |date=2011-06-11|accessdate=2011-06-11}}</ref>
===Bulgaria===
Electric vehicles, including cars, motorbikes and mopeds, are exempt from the annual circulation tax.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://europa.eu/youreurope/citizens/vehicles/registration/taxes/bulgaria/index_en.htm |title=Car registration and taxes - Bulgaria |publisher=European Commission |date=2017-03-01 |access-date=2018-04-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180421162718/https://europa.eu/youreurope/citizens/vehicles/registration/taxes/bulgaria/index_en.htm# |archive-date=2018-04-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
=== Cyprus === Vehicles with emissions less than 120 grams of carbon dioxide per kilometer are exempt from paying registration taxes.<ref name="EU-overview"/> ===Czech Republic=== Electric, hybrid and other alternative fuel vehicles used for business purposes are exempt from the road tax.<ref name=ACEA2/>
===Denmark===
In 2016, battery electric vehicles lost access to their registration tax exemption. The registration tax will gradually be phased back in until 2020.<ref name="EU-overview"/> {{As of|2016}} there are only 7,000 electric cars in Denmark.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.danskelbilalliance.dk/Statistik/Bestand_modeller.aspx|title=Dansk Elbil Alliance - Bestand af elbiler i Danmark|work=danskelbilalliance.dk|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006030304/http://www.danskelbilalliance.dk/Statistik/Bestand_modeller.aspx|archivedate=2015-10-06|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Estonia=== No grants towards the purchase of Plug-In or Electric vehicles as of 2016. Electric vehicles are exempt from the city public parking fees and can use bus lanes.
From 2011 to 2014 Estonia has allocated a total of {{currency|9 million|euro}} in grants towards the purchase of battery electric vehicles (ended 7 August 2014).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kredex.ee/kredex/news/grant-for-purchase-of-electric-cars-proved-popular-admission-period-for-applications-ends-on-07-august |title=Sihtasutus KredEx - Grant for purchase of electric cars proved popular, admission period for applications ends on 07 August |work=Kredex |date=2014-08-06 |accessdate=2015-01-29}}</ref> From 2011 to 2014, KredEx has allocated grants totaling {{currency|10.5 million|euro}}; the average grant per car was {{currency|16,500|euro}}. The grant has helped the purchase of over 650 electric cars in Estonia. At that time, a country-wide quick charging network (CHAdeMO 500V/120A and Type2 400V/32A) was established.
===Finland=== The Prime Minister of Finland (2003–2010) Mr. [[Matti Vanhanen]] has mentioned that he wants to see more [[electric car]]s on Finnish roads as soon as possible<ref>{{cite web|first=Tapio |last=Mainio |url=http://www.hs.fi/autot/artikkeli/Vanhanen+haluaa+s%C3%A4hk%C3%B6autot+Suomen+teille/1135238356818 |title=Vanhanen haluaa sähköautot Suomen teille - HS.fi - Autot |publisher=HS.fi |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref> and with any cost to the governmental car related tax incomes.<ref>{{cite web|first=Tuomas |last=Linnake |url=http://m.itviikko.fi/?page=showSingleNews&newsID=200820199 |title=Matti Vanhanen puhui sähköautojen puolesta | It-viikko |publisher=M.itviikko.fi |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref> Charging at home from motor and cabin heating outlets (common in all Nordic countries) has been determined to be a possible load on the grid, although this load is expected to mainly take place at night when overall demand is lower. If all cars in Finland run totally on electricity, it will add 7-9 TWh annually to the load, which corresponds to 10% of Finland's annual consumption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fortum.fi/sahkoauto/#/fin/kysysahkoautosta/9 |title=Fortum ja sähköauto |publisher=Fortum.fi |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref> On-line route planners like http://www.uppladdning.nu/ list a daily growing number of free charging outlets set up by merchants and private individuals, making it possible to drive an EV for free from Helsinki through Sweden all the way to Copenhagen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uppladdning.nu/ |title=Map |publisher=Uppladdning.nu |accessdate=2010-02-12}}</ref>
For the period of 2018-2021, €6,000,000 annually will be allocated towards the purchase of electric cars and conversion of petrol cars to E85 and gas. An individual registering a new electric car in the period 1.1.2018-30.11.2021 is eligible for a grant of €2,000, if the purchase price of the car is €50,000 or less.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.trafi.fi/oleedellakavija/tayssahkoauto/sahkoauton_hankintatuki |title=Trafi.fi - Sähköauton hankintatuki |publisher=Trafi.fi |accessdate=2018-04-01}}</ref>
In the end of 2017, there were 1,449 electric cars registered in Finland.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.trafi.fi/tietopalvelut/tilastot/tieliikenne/ajoneuvokanta/ajoneuvokannan_kayttovoimatilastot/sahkokayttoiset_autot |title=Trafi.fi - Lk-ajoneuvojen käyttövoimatilastot |publisher=Trafi.fi |accessdate=2018-04-01}}</ref>
===France=== {{See also|Plug-in electric vehicles in France|Bonus-malus#French taxation|l1=French bonus-malus}} Since 2008 France has a [[bonus-malus]] system offering a financial incentive, or bonus, for the purchase of cars with low [[carbon emissions]], and a fee, or malus, for the purchase of high-emission vehicles. The bonus applies to private and company vehicles purchased on or after 5 December 2007 and are deduced from the purchase price of the vehicle. The malus penalty applies to all vehicles registered after 1 January 2008, and is added at the time of registration. Since 2009, every family with more than two children receives a deduction from the malus of 20 g of {{CO2}} per km per child.<ref name=EUenvironTax>{{cite web | url=http://www.ieep.eu/assets/1398/ETR_in_Europe_-_Annex_2_3_4.pdf | title=Environmental Tax Reform in Europe: Opportunities for the Future | publisher=[[Institute for European Environmental Policy]] (IEEP) | date=2014-05-30 | accessdate=2016-10-08 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009191722/http://www.ieep.eu/assets/1398/ETR_in_Europe_-_Annex_2_3_4.pdf | archivedate=2016-10-09 | df= }}'' See Chapter 3 - Car Registration Tax ('Bonus-Malus' system) in France pp. 15-21.''</ref>
;2012-2014 [[File:Saint Étienne-Autolib-20140127.jpg|thumb|[[Electric car]]s purchase under a battery leasing contract, such as the [[Renault Zoe]], are eligible for the full {{euro|6300}} bonus for zero {{CO2}} emission vehicles.]]
Until July 31, 2012, a premium up to {{euro|5,000}}, under the bonus-malus system, was granted for the purchase of new cars with {{CO2}} emissions of 60 g/km or less which benefited [[battery electric vehicle|all-electric cars]] and any [[plug-in hybrid]] with such low emissions. Vehicles emitting up to 125 g/km or less, such as [[hybrid electric vehicle|conventional hybrids]] and [[natural gas vehicle]]s, were granted up to {{euro|2,000}}.<ref name=ACEA3/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abccarbon.com/50000-electric-vehicles-france-commits-to-infrastructure-production/|title=50,000 Electric Vehicles: France Commits to Infrastructure & Production|publisher=ABC Carbon|date=2010-04-13|accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref> The incentive could not exceed 20% of the sales price including [[VAT]], increased with the cost of the battery if it is rented.<ref name=ACEA3/>
Effective on August 1, 2012, the government increased the bonus for electric cars up to {{euro|7,000}} but capped at 30% of the vehicle price including [[VAT]]. The price includes any battery leasing charges, and therefore, electric cars which need a battery leasing contract also are eligible for the bonus. For example, an electric car sold for {{euro|23,333}} including VAT was eligible for the maximum bonus of {{euro|7000}}. The emission level for the maximum bonus was raised to 20 g/km or less. Cars with emission levels between 20 and 50 g/km were eligible to a bonus of up to {{euro|5,000}}, and between 50 and 60 g/km were eligible to a bonus of up to {{euro|4,500}}. After this limit, the bonus dropped to {{euro|550}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.automobile-propre.com/france-consumer-bonuses-for-electric-and-hybrid-cars/ |title=France: Consumer bonuses for electric and hybrid cars |first=Yoann |last=Nussbaumer |publisher=Automobile Propre |date=2012-08-10 |accessdate=2013-02-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110165813/http://en.automobile-propre.com/france-consumer-bonuses-for-electric-and-hybrid-cars/ |archivedate=2012-11-10 |df= }}</ref>
The fee schedule for the bonus-malus was modified in 2013. Effective November 1, 2013, the bonus was reduced from {{euro|7,000}} to {{euro|6300}} for all-electrics and any other vehicle with {{CO2}} emissions of less than 21 g/km. Vehicles emitting between 21 and 60 g/km, such as [[plug-in hybrid]]s and [[hybrid electric vehicle|conventional hybrids]], were eligible to a bonus up to {{euro|4,000}}, and for emissions between 61 and 90 g/km up to {{euro|150}}, down from {{euro|550}}. Effective January 1, 2014, the fee schedule for the malus was increased to a maximum penalty of {{euro|8,000}} from {{euro|6,000}} for vehicles emitting over 200 g/km. [[Flex-fuel vehicle]]s remained exempt from the malus fee. A neutral class applies to vehicles emitting between 91-130 g/km.<ref name=EUenvironTax/><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.bioethanolcarburant.com/actualite/de-nouveaux-baremes-bonus-malus-en-2014/ |title=De nouveaux barèmes bonus-malus en 2014 | language=French | trans-title=New bonus-malus scales in 2014 |author=<!--Staff--> |publisher=Bioéthanol | date=2014-01-17 | accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref>
;2015-2016
From April 1, 2015, a super-bonus was introduced, increasing the financial incentive to a cumulative total of {{euro|10,000}}, consisting of the regular bonus of {{euro|6300}} for purchasing a pure electric car, plus up to {{euro|3700}} for customers [[Scrappage program#France|scrapping]] a diesel-powered car in circulation before 1 January 2001. In the case of plug-in hybrids with {{CO2}} emission levels between 21 and 60 g/km, the purchase bonus was {{euro|4000}} plus the scrapping premium of {{euro|3700}}. Also a specific {{euro|500}} grant was introduced for families which are below the income tax threshold who buy an ordinary new or second hand car below certain {{CO2}} emission thresholds or a hybrid or electric car.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.connexionfrance.com/April-petrol-mutuelles-depassements-electric-cars-16798-view-article.html| title=What is new for April 1?| publisher=The Connexion| date=2015-04-01|accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref>
[[File:BMW i3 Paris 04 2016 5605.JPG|thumb|[[Electric car]]s equipped with a [[range extender]], such as the [[BMW i3 REx]], are entitled to the {{euro|6300}} bonus if emitting between 21 and 60 g/km of {{CO2}}.]]
Effective January 4, 2016, the {{euro|6300}} bonus limited to 27% of the purchase price of vehicles emitting up to 20 g/km was kept. This bonus corresponds to pure electric vehicles and those equipped with a [[range extender (vehicle)|range extender]]. Vehicles emitting between 21 and 60 g/km are entitled to a {{euro|1000}} bonus. This bonus corresponds to the majority of plug-in hybrids. Conventional hybrid passenger cars emitting between 61 and 110 g/km with sufficient level of hybridization, with an electric motor with an output power of not be less than 10 [[kW]], are entitle to a {{euro|750}} bonus.<ref name=bonus2016/> Diesel-powered hybrids, such as the [[PSA Hybrid4]], are no longer eligible for the bonus, even if the car emits less than 110 g/km of {{CO2}}.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.autonews.fr/dossiers/industrie/204883-bonus-malus-bareme-2016-prime/ |title=Bonus-malus écologique : le barème 2016 | language=French | trans-title=EcologicalBonus-malus: the 2016 scale |author=<!--Staff--> | work=Autonews France | date=2016-01-08 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref>
The combined {{euro|10000}} super-bonus for the purchase or lease of a new all-electric car was maintained. To be eligible for the additional scrappage bonus, the old diesel-powered car have to be owned for at least a year and in circulation before 1 January 2006. The new vehicle must not be sold within 6 months of acquisition or have traveled less than {{convert|6000|km|abbr=on}}.<ref name=bonus2016>{{cite web |url=http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Bonus-Malus-definitions-et-baremes.html |title=Bonus-Malus : définitions et barèmes pour 2016| language=French | trans-title=Bonus-Malus: definitions and scales for 2016 |publisher=Ministère de l'Environnement, de l'Energie et de la Mer |location= |date=2016-05-04 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref>
The scrappage bonus for the purchase of an all-electric car was maintained at {{euro|3700}}, while the bonus for plug-in hybrid car emitting between 21 and 60 g/km was set at {{euro|2500}}. Only individuals or professionals are eligible for the scrappage bonus. Commercial vehicles are not eligible. Neither demonstration vehicles are eligible to the superbonus unless the vehicles are sold or leased within one year following the date of first registration.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.avere-france.org/Site/Article/?article_id=6110&from_espace_adherent=0 | title=Superbonus & prime à la conversion : mode d'emploi | language=French | trans-title=Superbonus & conversion premium: user manual |publisher=Association Nationale pour le Développement de la Mobilité Électrique- AVERE France |date=2016-01-04 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref> {{As of|2016|09}}, the scrappage bonus of {{euro|3700}} for trading in old diesel-powered cars has been granted to more than 10,000 purchase transactions.<ref name=AVEM10K>{{cite web | url=http://www.avem.fr/actualite-les-aides-pour-les-2-3-et-4-roues-electriques-en-2017-annoncees-par-segolene-royal-6223.html | title= Les aides pour les 2, 3 et 4 roues électriques en 2017 annoncées par Ségolène Royal |language=French | trans-title= Subsidy for the two-, three- and four-wheeled electric motorcycles by 2017 announced by Ségolène Royal |first=Philippe |last=Schwoerer |publisher= Association pour l'Avenir du Véhicule Electrique Méditerranéen (AVEM)|date=2016-10-06 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref>
;2017 {{As of|2016|09}}, the government proposal to be in force from 1 January 2017 provides that the {{euro|10,000}} super-bonus for scrapping a diesel vehicle over 10 years-old will be renewed. However, the bonus for the purchase of a pure electric car will drop to {{euro|6000}} from {{euro|6300}} in 2016, but to compensate, the additional scrappage bonus will be increased to {{euro|4000}} from {{euro|3700}} in 2016. Also, the government plans to introduce a purchase price cap to the vehicles eligible for the bonus, and to introduce a new bonus for two-wheeled motor vehicles. For the more polluting vehicles, the government intends to increase the maximum malus fee to {{euro|10000}} from {{euro|8000}} in 2016 for vehicles emitting more than 191 g/km, lowering the limit from 200 g/km in 2016.<ref name=bonus2017>{{cite web | url=http://www.avem.fr/actualite-projet-de-loi-de-finances-2017-decryptage-6212.html | title= Projet de loi de finances 2017 : décryptage |language=French | trans-title= Bill 2017 Finance: deciphering |first=Tiphaine |last=Leurent |publisher= Association pour l'Avenir du Véhicule Electrique Méditerranéen (AVEM)|date=2016-09-29 |accessdate=2016-10-08}}</ref>
The government intends to maintain the {{euro|1000}} purchase bonus for plug-in hybrids with a {{CO2}} emission level between 21 and 60 g/km. However, the proposal does not include anything about the conversion premium for scrapping a 10-year-old diesel car for the purchase of a plug-in hybrid. The purchase bonus for non-rechargeable hybrid vehicles will be eliminated.<ref name=bonus2017/>
===Germany=== {{See also|Plug-in electric vehicles in Germany}}
[[File:Elektromobilität - Angela Merkel 2010.JPG|thumb|[[Chancellor of Germany|Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] announced her goal to bring 1 million electric vehicles on German roads at the 2010 Electromobility Summit in Berlin.]]
"[[Nationale Plattform Elektromobilität]]" (NPE)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/germany-starts-national-electric-mobility-platform-19976.html |title=Germany Starts National Electric Mobility Platform |publisher=autoevolution |accessdate=2010-06-26}}</ref> is a German government initiative to develop Germany into a leading market for electric mobility.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/05/vw-20100503.html |title=VW Showcases Golf Blue-e-motion at Berlin E-Mobility Event |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2010-05-03 |accessdate=2010-06-26}}</ref> In May 2010, under its National Program for Electric Mobility, [[Chancellor of Germany|Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] set the goal to bring 1 million electric vehicles on German roads by 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://proceedings.eceee.org/papers/proceedings2011/4-174_Praetorius.pdf?returnurl=http%3A%2F%2Fproceedings.eceee.org%2Fvisabstrakt.php%3Fevent%3D1%26doc%3D4-174-11|title=E-Mobility in Germany: A research agenda for studying the diffusion of innovative mobility concepts|first=Barbara|last=Praetorius|publisher=ECEEE|year=2011|accessdate=2014-08-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826114744/http://proceedings.eceee.org/papers/proceedings2011/4-174_Praetorius.pdf?returnurl=http%3A%2F%2Fproceedings.eceee.org%2Fvisabstrakt.php%3Fevent%3D1%26doc%3D4-174-11#|archive-date=2014-08-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> However, the government also announced that it would not provide subsidies to the sales of plug-in electric cars but instead it will only fund research in the area of electric mobility.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5533192,00.html |first=John |last=Blau|title=Berlin plugs in electric mobility strategy|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=2010-05-03|accessdate=2014-08-24}}</ref> Electric vehicles and plug-ins are exempt from the annual circulation tax for a period of five years from the date of their first registration.<ref name=ACEA3/><ref name=RAI>{{cite web|url=http://www.raivereniging.nl/dossiers/elektrische-voertuigen.aspx |publisher=rai vereniging (RAI Association - Dutch Association of Bicycle and Automobile Industry) |title=Policy support for electrically chargeable vehicles |date=February 2010 |accessdate=2010-05-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112230831/http://www.raivereniging.nl/dossiers/elektrische-voertuigen.aspx |archivedate=2009-11-12 |df= }} ''Click under "Overzicht stimuleringsprogrammas elektrische voertuigen (Overview incentive programs electric vehicles) to download the report in pdf format (website in Dutch)''.</ref> In 2016, the annual circulation tax exemption was extended from five to ten years, backdated to 1 January 2016.<ref name=Bild052016/>
The private use of a company car is treated as taxable income in Germany and measured at a flat monthly rate of 1% of the vehicle's gross list price. So plug-in electric cars have been at a disadvantage since their price tag can be as much as double that of a car using a conventional internal combustion engine due to the high cost of the battery. In June 2013 German legislators approved a law that ends the tax disadvantage for corporate plug-in electric cars. The law, backdated to 1 January 2013, allows private users to offset the list price with {{euro|500}} per unit of battery size, expressed in [[kilowatt hour]]s (kWh). The maximum offset was set at {{euro|10,000}} corresponding to a 20 [[kWh]] battery. The amount one can offset will sink annually by {{euro|50}} per kilowatt hour.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/07/germany-electricvehicles-tax-idUSL5N0EJ1Y320130607|title=Germany ends tax disadvantage for corporate electric cars |work=[[Reuters]] |date=2013-06-07|accessdate=2013-06-24}}</ref> The range criteria will rise to {{Convert|40|km|abbr=on}} starting in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euractiv.com/sections/transport/berlin-approves-new-incentives-electric-car-drivers-308700|title=Berlin approves new incentives for electric car drivers|first=Daniel |last=Tost |publisher=EurActiv.com|date=2014-09-25|accessdate=2014-09-25}}</ref> As part of the package of financial incentives approved in 2016, private owners of plug-in electric vehicles that charge their cars in their employer premises are exempted from declaring this perk as a cash benefit in their income tax return. Employers who provide this perk are allowed to discount from their income tax a 25% of the lump sum value of the cash benefit. These two fiscal benefits apply only from 1 January 2017 until the end of 2020.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kfz-betrieb.vogel.de/e-auto-praemie-diese-voraussetzungen-muessen-erfuellt-sein-a-545197/index6.html |title=E-Auto-Prämie: Diese Voraussetzungen müssen erfüllt sein: Gibt es auch Formen von Steuervergünstigungen oder Steuerbefreiungen? |language=German |trans-title=E-Car Bonus: These requirements must be met: Are there any tax relief or tax exemption benefits? |author=<!--Staff--> |work=KFZ-betrieb |date=2016-08-09|accessdate=2016-09-25}}</ref>
[[File:Opel Ampera and smart-ed 2012.JPG|thumb|left|[[Smart ED]] [[all-electric car]] (right) and [[Opel Ampera]] [[plug-in hybrid]] (left) in Germany]]
In August 2014, the federal government announced its plan to introduce non-monetary incentives through new legislation to be effective by 1 February 2015. The proposed user benefits include measures to privilege battery-powered cars, fuel cell vehicles and some plug-in hybrids, just like Norway does, by granting local governments the authority to allow these vehicles into bus lanes, and to offer free parking and reserved parking spaces in locations with charging points.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kfz-betrieb.vogel.de/neuwagen/handel/articles/454644/?cmp=nl-125 |title=Förderung von Elektroautos kommt ins Rollen |language=German |trans-title=Promotion of electric cars gets rolling |author=<!--Staff--> |work=KFZ-betrieb |date=2014-08-04 |accessdate=2014-08-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826165602/http://www.kfz-betrieb.vogel.de/neuwagen/handel/articles/454644/?cmp=nl-125 |archivedate=2014-08-26 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thegreencarwebsite.co.uk/blog/index.php/2014/08/15/germany-plans-new-ev-incentives-to-spur-uptake/|title=Germany plans new EV incentives to spur uptake |first=Faye |last=Sunderland|work=The Green Car Website UK|date=2014-08-15|accessdate=2014-08-24}}</ref> Not all plug-in hybrids will qualify for the benefits, only those with {{CO2}} emissions of no more than 50 g/km or an [[all-electric range]] of over {{Convert|30|km|abbr=on}} are eligible.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2014-09-24/germany-proposes-free-parking-to-spur-electric-car-sales |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140925011901/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2014-09-24/germany-proposes-free-parking-to-spur-electric-car-sales |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-09-25 |title=Germany Proposes Free Parking to Spur Electric-Car Sales |first=Stefan |last=Nicola |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=2014-09-24 |accessdate=2014-09-24 }}</ref>
According to the fourth progress report of the German National Electric Mobility Platform, only about 24,000 plug-in electric cars are on German roads by the end of November 2014, well behind the target of 100,000 unit goal set for 2014. As a result, Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] recognized in December 2014 that the government has to provide more incentives to meet the goal of having 1 million electric cars on the country's roads by 2020. Among others, and based on the recommendations of the report, the federal government is considering to offer a tax break for zero-emission company cars, more subsidies to expand charging infrastructure, particularly to deploy more public fast chargers, and more public funding for research and development of the next generation of rechargeable batteries.<ref name=GERincentives2014>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2014-12-02/merkel-backs-incentives-in-1-million-electric-cars-push |archive-url=https://archive.is/20141207130846/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2014-12-02/merkel-backs-incentives-in-1-million-electric-cars-push |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-12-07 |title=Merkel Backs Incentives in Push for a Million Electric Cars |first1=Brian |last1=Parkin |first2=Dorothee |last2=Tschampa |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=2014-12-02 |accessdate=2014-12-07 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/the-future-is-electric-or-is-it/a-18108847|title=The future is electric - or is it?|first=Sabine |last=Kinkartz|work=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=2014-12-03|accessdate=2014-12-07}}</ref>
;Purchase incentive
At the beginning of 2016, German politicians from the three parties in Mrs. Merkel's ruling coalition and auto executives began talks to introduce a subsidy for green car buyers worth up to {{euro|5000}} ({{USD|5500}}) to boost sales of electric and plug-in hybrid cars.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://europe.autonews.com/article/20160129/ANE/160129831/germany-will-mull-5000-euro-incentive-for-ev-plug-in-hybrid-sales | title=Germany considers $5,500 incentive for electric cars | work=[[Reuters]] | publisher= [[Automotive News|Automotive News Europe]] |date=2016-01-29 |accessdate=2016-03-20}}</ref> {{As of|2016|02}}, the German government proposal is for the auto industry to cover 40% of the cost of the purchase subsidy. Private buyers would get the full {{euro|5000}} subsidy, while corporate buyers would receive {{euro|3000}} for each electric car, and the program is expected to run until 2020, the deadline set to achieve the goal of 1 million electric cars on German roads. Incentives will fall by {{euro|500}} each year.<ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-electric-germany-idUSKCN0VZ251 |title=Automakers would share German electric car incentive plan cost | first1=Tina |last1=Bellon | first2 = Markus |last2 = Wacket |work=[[Reuters]] |date=2016-02-26 |accessdate=2016-03-20}}</ref> In March 2016, Nissan Europe announced its support to the green car incentive and its commitment to double the government's E-premium incentive when buying a Nissan electric car, with a reduction of the purchase price of the same amount of the subsidy. Nissan Center Europe CEO said "''we remain convinced that the goal of one million electric cars by 2020 is still achievable''." According to Nissan if from now on electric car sales double every year until 2020, it is still possible to achieve the government goal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kfz-betrieb.vogel.de/wirtschaft/articles/526724/?cmp=nl-125&uuid=B225CA8F-E6F9-464D-9839-BAB0E10881B8 |title=Nissan will zusätzliche E-Prämie zahlen | language=German |trans-title= Nissan will pay an additional E-premium | first=Andreas |last=Grimm |work=KFZ-betrieb |date=2016-03-18 |accessdate=2016-03-20}}</ref>
[[File:2014 Tesla Model S in Germany.jpg|thumb|The [[Tesla Model S]], and other premium cars with a purchase price over {{euro|60,000}} ({{USD|67800}}) are not eligible to the purchase bonus.]]
An incentive scheme to promote plug-in electric vehicle adoption was approved in April 2016 with a budget of {{euro|1 billion}} ({{USD|1.13 billion}}). A total of {{euro|600 million}} ({{USD|678 million}}) is reserved for the purchase subsidies, which are expected to run until all the money is disbursed, estimated to last until 2019 at the latest. Another {{euro|300 million}} ({{USD|339 million}}) are budgeted to finance the deployment of charging stations in cities and on autobahn highway stops. And another {{euro|100 million}} ({{USD|113 million}}) would go toward purchasing electric cars for federal government fleets. The program is aimed to promote the sale of 400,000 electric vehicles. The cost of the purchase incentive is shared equally between the government and automakers. Electric car buyers get a {{euro|4000}} ({{USD|4520}}) discount while buyers of plug-in hybrid vehicles get a discount of {{euro|3000}} ({{USD|3390}}). Premium cars, such as the [[Tesla Model S]] and [[BMW i8]], are not eligible to the incentive because there is a cap of {{euro|60,000}} ({{USD|67800}}) for the purchase price.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://in.reuters.com/article/autos-electric-germany-discount-idINKCN0XO1Y4 | title=Germany to launch 1 billion-euro discount scheme for electric car buyers | first=Andreas | last=Cremer | work=[[Reuters]] | date=2016-04-27 | accessdate=2016-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/28/germany-subsidy-boost-electric-car-sales | title=Germany to give €1bn subsidy to boost electric car sales |author=Agence France-Presse | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=2016-04-28 | accessdate=2016-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kfz-betrieb.vogel.de/wirtschaft/articles/531213/?cmp=nl-125&uuid=B225CA8F-E6F9-464D-9839-BAB0E10881B8 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20160616183533/http://www.kfz-betrieb.vogel.de/wirtschaft/articles/531213/?cmp=nl-125&uuid=B225CA8F-E6F9-464D-9839-BAB0E10881B8 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2016-06-16 |title=Bis zu 4.000 Euro Förderung für Elektroautos |language=German |trans-title=Up to 4,000 euros in funding for electric cars |author=<!--Staff--> |work=KFZ-betrieb |date=2016-04-27 |accessdate=2016-04-14 }}</ref> Only electric vehicles purchased after 18 May 2016 are eligible for the bonus and the owner must keep the new electric car at least nine months. The same rule applies for leasing.<ref name=Bild052016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bild.de/politik/inland/elektroauto/kabinett-beschliesst-umweltbonus-45858838.bild.html |title=Prämie für E-Autos beschlossenWie komme ich jetzt an den Bonus?|language=German |trans-title=Premium For Electric Cars Decided, how do I get to the bonus? |work=[[Bild]] | date=2016-05-18 |accessdate=2016-09-25}}</ref>

===Greece=== From 2011 to June 2016, all electric vehicles were exempt from the registration tax.<ref name=ACEA2/> From 1 July 2016 onwards the registration tax for hybrid vehicles was reduced to 50%.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.economy365.gr/article/9587/oi-nees-allages-sti-forologia-trikyklon-yvridikon-kai-ilektrikon-ih |title=Οι νέες αλλαγές στη φορολογία τρικύκλων, υβριδικών και ηλεκτρικών ΙΧ |trans-title=New changes in taxation of tricycles, hybrids and electric cars |work=Economy 365 |location=Greece |language=gr |date=2016-08-06 |access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref>
===Hungary=== All hybrid and electric vehicles are exempt from registration tax. The Government announced that from October 27, 2016, electric vehicles would be eligible for a 21% rebate of the gross purchase price, capped at a {{currency|1.5 million|HUF}} ({{euro|4,800}} at the December 2016 exchange rate). Furthermore, to promote electric cars, the Government has added some other regulatory incentives, such as green license plates, and simplified tax and regulations on electric charge points. By 2020, the Government expects that there will be 30,000 environmentally friendly cars on Hungarian roads.<ref>{{cite web |title=New government incentive for purchasing environmentally friendly vehicles |url=http://www.kormany.hu/en/ministry-for-national-economy/news/new-government-incentive-for-purchasing-environmentally-friendly-vehicles |publisher=Government |location=Hungary |accessdate=2016-12-06 |date=2016-09-21}}</ref>
===Iceland=== All electric vehicles are exempt from VAT up to {{currency|6,000,000|ISK}}, and the tax is applied at the normal rate for the remainder of the price.<ref>{{cite web |title=Amendments to vehicle taxes |url=http://www.althingi.is/altext/140/s/1656.html |publisher=Government of Iceland |language=Icelandic |accessdate=2014-07-29 |date=2012-06-19}}</ref> Electric vehicles also get free parking in the city center for up to 90 minutes, which also applies to cars with {{CO2}} emissions of less than 120 g/km and weigh less than 1,200 kg, which excludes several electric cars such as the [[Tesla Model S]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Amendments to vehicle taxes |url=http://www.mbl.is/bill/frettir/2014/07/15/tesla_faer_ekki_ad_leggja_fritt/ |publisher=News Site |language=Icelandic |accessdate=2014-11-25 |date=2014-05-17}}</ref>
===Ireland=== [[File:Bilbao 05 2012 Opel Ampera 2472.JPG|thumb|The [[Opel Ampera]] [[plug-in hybrid]] is available in several European countries.]]
Series production EVs were exempted from [[Vehicle registration tax (Ireland)|VRT]] until December 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.revenue.ie/en/tax/vrt/leaflets/change-tax-base.html |title=Change to the Tax Base |publisher=Irish Tax & Customs |year=2008 |access-date=2018-07-01 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081209033520/http://www.revenue.ie/en/tax/vrt/leaflets/change-tax-base.html# |archive-date=2008-12-09 |df= }}</ref> The VRT exemption was replaced by a €5000 credit against the tax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.revenue.ie/en/tax/vrt/vrt-guide.html|title=Guide to Vehicle Registration Tax(VRT)|publisher=}}</ref> Annual motor tax for EVs is €120.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.environ.ie/en/LocalGovernment/MotorTax/MotorTaxRates/MotorTaxRatesbasedonCO2Emissions/|title=Motor Tax Rates|work=Department of the Environment, Community and Local Government}}</ref> The Government has set a target of 10% for all vehicles on Irish roads to be electric by 2020.
The [[Electricity Supply Board|ESB]] eCar electric vehicle charging network serves as the main charging network for the island of Ireland and has rapidly expanded in recent years. Currently the network is free to use with an RFID card provided by ESB to EV owners who wish to use the network. The network aims to provide rapid charging every 30 km on major routes and as of 2015 has almost 2000 standard charging points (all provide connection via [[IEC 62196]] Type 2 Mennekes, around half are 22 kW with the remainder a mix of 3.6 kW and 7.4 kW). There are around 100 [[CHAdeMO]] rapid chargers with over 70 located outside the [[Dublin]] Metro area.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.esb.ie/electric-cars/electric-car-charging/electric-car-charge-point-map.jsp|title=Charge Point Map|publisher=}}</ref> All rapid chargers installed since mid-2014 have been triple standard [[CHAdeMO]]/[[Combined Charging System]]/AC 43 kW. Four rapid chargers in Dublin and two rapid chargers in Belfast were co-funded by the EU as part of the UK/Ireland RCN program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rapidchargenetwork.com/resources.php|title=Rapid Charge Network|publisher=Rapid Charge Network}}</ref> The UK charging network operated by [[Ecotricity#Vehicle recharging|Ecotricity]] has a single [[CHAdeMO]] only rapid charger at IKEA Belfast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecotricity.co.uk/for-the-road/our-electric-highway|title=Our Electric Highway|publisher=}}</ref> This is the sole rapid charger on the island that is not part of the ESB eCars network.
[[Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland]] offers a government grant of up to €5,000 for the purchase of a new electric car.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gas2.org/2010/04/13/ireland-moves-to-ease-switch-to-electric-cars-with-grants-infrastructure/|title=Ireland Moves To Ease Switch To Electric Cars With Grants, Infrastructure|publisher=Gas2.0|date=2010-04-13|accessdate=2010-05-17}}</ref> Electric and hybrid vehicles had a reduction of up to {{euro|2,500}} off the registration tax between July 2008 and December 2010.<ref name=ACEA3/> However this grant is only available on vehicles on an approved list of models <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seai.ie/Grants/Electric_Vehicle_Grant_Scheme/I_am_a_consumer/List_of_Eligible_Vehicles/|title=SEAI - List of Eligible Vehicles|publisher=}}</ref> which must be sold by a dealer registered for the scheme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seai.ie/Grants/Electric_Vehicle_Grant_Scheme/I_am_a_dealer/Current_List_of_Registered_Dealers/List_of_Registered_Electric_Vehicle_Grant_Scheme_Dealers.html|title=SEAI - List of Registered Electric Vehicle Grant Scheme Dealers|publisher=}}</ref> No grant applies where a vehicle is imported privately. The grant is reduced to €3,800 for business purchasers or those who require finance to purchase the vehicle, however some importers will report financed private sales as cash sales to acquire the full grant.
{{As of|2014|09}}, plug-in electric car purchasers are eligible for a government credit worth up to {{euro|5,000}} (about {{USD|6,500}}). Vehicle Registration Tax (VRT), up to {{euro|5,000}} is also waived for electric cars. Also, all-electric car owners pay the lowest rate of annual road tax, which is based on emissions. In addition, the first 2,000 electric cars registered in Ireland are eligible for installation of a free home-charging points worth about {{euro|1,000}} (about {{USD|1,300}}).<ref name=GCR>{{cite news|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1094211_electric-cars-in-ireland-how-to-get-to-the-tipping-point |title=Electric Cars In Ireland: How To Get To The Tipping Point? |first=Colin |last=Cleary |work=Green Car Reports |date=2014-09-14 |accessdate=2016-01-23}}</ref>
===Italy=== Electric vehicles are exempt from the annual circulation tax or ownership tax for five years from the date of their first registration. Thereafter, EVs benefit from a 75% reduction of the tax rate applied to equivalent gasoline-powered vehicles.<ref name=ACEA2/> In the region of [[Lombardy]], electric vehicles are exempt from the annual ownership tax.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tributi.regione.lombardia.it/ds/Satellite?c=Page&childpagename=Tributi%2FSitiTematici%2FST_Layout&cid=1213376080623&p=1213369696045&packedargs=areaCorrelata%3DNA%26azioneTributaria%3DEsenzione%26introduttivo%3D1213369745423%26nomeTributo%3DTassa%2BAutomobilistica%26subtype%3DTRBT%252FContenutoTributario%26templateDaVisualizzare%3DContenutoTributarioDettaglio%26voceServizi%3DSi&pagename=TRBTWrapper |title=Portale dei Tributi :: Tassa Automobilistica |language=Italian |publisher=Regione Lombardia |accessdate=2015-09-15}}</ref>
=== Latvia === Electric vehicles, including cars, goods vehicles, buses, and motorcycles, are exempt from payment of the Vehicle Operation Tax. [http://www.vvc.gov.lv/export/sites/default/docs/LRTA/Citi/Law_On_the_Vehicle_Operation_Tax_and_Company_Car_Tax.doc]
===Luxembourg=== Buyers of electric vehicles and other vehicles emitting 60 [[g/km]] or less of carbon dioxide are eligible to receive a premium of {{euro|3,000}} (around {{USD|4,200}}), this premium ended 31 December 2011. In order to qualify for the rebate, the owner must have concluded an agreement to buy electricity from [[renewable energy]].<ref name=NYT072911/><ref name=ACEA2/>
===Monaco=== Buyers of electric vehicles and plug in hybrids are eligible to receive {{euro|9,000}} (around {{USD|12,600}}) from the [[Government of Monaco|Monegasque Government]]. In addition vehicles owners are allowed to park free at any public parking facility.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teslamotors.com/goelectric/incentives/MC/ |title=Electric Vehicle Incentives |publisher=Tesla Motors |date= |accessdate=2013-04-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aspectediplomatice.ro/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=351%3Athe-tesla-companys-electric-cars-establish-a-headquarters-in-monaco-&catid=42%3Arokstories&Itemid=120 |title=The Tesla Company's electric cars establish a headquarters in Monaco |publisher=Aspectediplomatice.ro |date= |accessdate=2013-04-22}}</ref>
===Netherlands=== {{See also|Plug-in electric vehicles in the Netherlands}} [[File:Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV (side) white.JPG|thumb|Launched in the Dutch market in 2013, the [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]] is the country's top selling ever plug-in electric vehicle.<ref name=Nether2012_082014/>]]
Considering the potential of plug-in electric vehicles in the country due to its relative small size and geography, the Dutch government set a target of 15,000 to 20,000 electric vehicles with three or more wheels on the roads in 2015; 200,000 vehicles in 2020; and 1 million vehicles in 2025.<ref name=Nether2011_13/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://arno.uvt.nl/show.cgi?fid=121053|title=The potential of electric vehicles amongst Dutch lease drivers |first=Sander |last=van der Kuip|publisher=[[Tilburg University]] |date=November 2011|accessdate=2013-10-11}}</ref> The first government target was achieved in 2013, two years earlier, thanks to the sales peak that occurred at the end of 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zerauto.nl/2013/12/24/de-ev-markt-van-2014-wat-wordt-het/|language=Dutch|trans-title=De EV-markt van 2014: wat wordt het?|title=The EV market in 2014: how it will be?|first=Marc |last=Bolier|publisher=Zerauto Netherlands|date=2013-12-24|accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref> According to official figures, 30,086 plug-in electric vehicles with three or more wheels have been registered in the country through 31 December 2013.<ref name=Nether2011_13>{{cite web|url=http://www.bovag.nl/data/sitemanagement/media/2013_cijfers%20elektrisch%20vervoer%20tm%20december%202013.pdf |title=Cijfers elektrisch vervoer - Aantal geregistreerde elektrische voertuigen in Nederland - Top 5 geregistreerde modellen elektrische auto (31-12-2013) |language=Dutch |trans-title=Figures electric transport - Number of registered electric vehicles in Netherlands and Top 5 registered electric vehicle models (12-31-2013) |publisher=Rijksdienst voor Ondernemend (RVO) |location=The Netherlands |date=January 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531142953/http://www.bovag.nl/data/sitemanagement/media/2013_cijfers%20elektrisch%20vervoer%20tm%20december%202013.pdf |archivedate=2014-05-31 |df= }} ''See under the heading "31-12-2013" for total registrations figures at the end of December 2013.''</ref>
Initially, the Dutch government set incentives such as the total exemption of the registration fee and road taxes, which resulted in savings of approximately {{euro|5,324}} for private car owners over four years,<ref name=ACEA2/><ref name=NissanNl>{{cite web|url=http://www.nissan.nl/NL/nl/inside-nissan/innovation-and-technology/leaf_prijzen.html|title=Leaf prijzen|language=Dutch|publisher=Nissan Netherlands|accessdate=2010-05-19}}</ref> and {{euro|19,000}} for corporate owners over five years.<ref name=ABGreen0510>{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2010/05/17/nissan-announces-european-prices-for-leaf-under-30-000-after-i/|title=Nissan announces European prices for Leaf, under €30,000 after incentives|first=Sam |last=Abuelsamid|date=2010-05-17 |publisher=AutoblogGreen |accessdate=2010-05-19}}</ref> Other vehicles including [[hybrid electric vehicle]]s were also exempt from these taxes if they emit less than 95 g/km for diesel-powered vehicles, or less than 110 g/km for gasoline-powered vehicles.<ref name="ACEA2"/> The exemption from the registration tax ended on January 1, 2014, and thereafter, all-electric vehicles pay a 4% registration fee and plug-in hybrids a 7% fee.<ref name=RegTax>{{cite news|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/590251-forse-toename-elektrische-autos.html|title=Forse toename elektrische auto's|language=Dutch|trans-title=Major increase in electric car sales|work=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]] (NOS)|date=2013-12-24|accessdate=2013-12-26}}</ref>
In addition, the national government offers through the [[Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment]] a {{euro|3,000}} subsidy on the purchase of all-electric taxis or delivery vans. This subsidy increases to {{euro|5,000}} per vehicle in [[Amsterdam]], [[Rotterdam]], [[The Hague]], [[Utrecht]], and [[Stadsregio Arnhem Nijmegen|Arnhem-Nijmegen metropolitan area]]. An additional subsidy is offered by several local government for the purchase of full electric taxis and vans, {{euro|5,000}} in Amsterdam and {{euro|3,000}} in [[Limburg (Netherlands)|Limburg]] and [[Tilburg]].<ref name=HighlightsNED2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.rvo.nl/sites/default/files/2014/04/Electromobility%20in%20the%20Netherlands%20Highlights%202013.pdf|title=Electromobility in the Netherlands - Highlights 2013|publisher=Rijksdienst voor Ondernemend (RVO)|location=The Netherlands |date=March 2014|accessdate=2014-09-25}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''See Financial stimulation, pp. 8.''</ref><ref name=Rotterdam/>
[[File:Tesla Model S PC Hooftstraat Amsterdam.jpg|thumb|left|[[Tesla Model S]] in [[Amsterdam]]. The Model S is the country's top selling all-electric car ever.<ref name=Nether2012_082014>{{cite web|url=http://www.rvo.nl/onderwerpen/duurzaam-ondernemen/energie-en-milieu-innovaties/elektrisch-rijden/stand-van-zaken/cijfers|title=Cijfers elektrisch vervoer - Aantal geregistreerde elektrische voertuigen in Nederland - Top 5 geregistreerde modellen plug-in hybride elektrische voertuigen (30-08-2014) - Top 5 geregistreerde modellen volledig elektrische voertuigen (30-08-2014)|language=Dutch|trans-title= Figures electric transport - Number of registered electric vehicles in Netherlands, Top 5 registered plug-in electric hybrid vehicle models (31-08-2014) and Top 5 registered all-electric vehicle models (31-08-2014) |publisher=Rijksdienst voor Ondernemend (RVO) |location=The Netherlands |date=September 2014|accessdate=2014-09-16}} ''See under the headings 31-12-2013, 30-06-2014 and 31-08-2014 for registrations figures for 2013 and through August 2014.''</ref>]]
In Amsterdam EV owners also have access to parking spaces reserved for [[battery electric vehicle]]s, so they avoid the current wait for a parking place in Amsterdam, which can reach up to 10 years in some parts of the city.<ref name=JustAuto0510>{{cite web|url=http://www.just-auto.com/news/nissan-leaf-costlier-in-europe-even-with-incentives_id104404.aspx?lk=dm|publisher=Just-Auto|title=UK: Nissan Leaf costlier in Europe even with incentives|first=Graeme |last=Roberts|date=2010-05-17|accessdate=2010-05-17}}</ref> Free charging is also offered in public parking spaces.<ref name=NYT02913/> EV owners in the city of Rotterdam are entitled to one year of free parking in downtown and enjoy subsidies of up to {{euro|1,450}} if they install a home charger using green electricity.<ref name=Rotterdam>{{cite news|url=http://www.automotiveworld.com/news-releases/rotterdam-introduces-worlds-best-ev-incentives-improve-air-quality/|title=Rotterdam introduces world's best EV incentives to improve air quality|work=Automotive World|date=2014-08-29|accessdate=2014-09-25}}</ref> The city also introduced in 2014 a [[scrappage program]] to remove old polluting vehicles to improve air quality in the city. Rotterdam offers a {{euro|2,500}} incentive for business buyers to replace the old vehicles with all-electric vehicles. The subsidy is only available to the first 5,000 applicants that buy an eligible vehicle before the end of December 2013.<ref name=Rotterdam/> Other factors contributing to the rapid adoption of plug-in electric vehicles are the relative small size of the country, which reduces [[range anxiety]] (the Netherlands stretches about {{convert|100|mi|abbr=on}} east to west); a long tradition of environmental activism; high gasoline prices ({{USD|8.50}} per gallon as of January 2013), which make the cost of running a car on electricity five times cheaper; and also some EV leasing programs provide free or discounted gasoline-powered vehicles for those who want to take a vacation driving long distances. With all of these incentives and tax breaks, plug-in electric cars have similar driving costs to conventional cars.<ref name=NYT02913/>
