Initially, sales of plug-in electric car were lower than expected, and during 2012 the segment captured a market share of less than 1% of new car sales in the country.<ref name=NYT02913>{{cite news|title=Plugging In, Dutch Put Electric Cars to the Test|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/10/world/europe/dutch-put-electric-cars-to-the-test.html|accessdate=2013-02-11|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2013-02-09|first=Elisabeth |last=Rosenthal}}</ref> As a result of the end of the total exemption of the registration fee, the segment sales peaked at the end of 2013,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.z24.nl/ondernemen/topjaar-verkoop-hybride-autos-maar-2014-wordt-minder-427872 |title=Topjaar verkoop hybride auto’s, maar 2014 wordt minder |language=Dutch|trans-title=Peak annual sales of hybrid cars, but 2014 will be lower|first=Jeroen |last=de Boer|work=Z24|date=2014-02-14|accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref> and plug-in electric car sales reached a market share of 5.34% of new car sales in 2013.<ref name=EVshare2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.rvo.nl/sites/default/files/2014/01/Special%20elektrisch%20vervoer%20analyse%20over%202013.pdf |title=Special: Analyse over 2013|language=Dutch|trans-title=Special: Analysis of 2013 (Closer look at the development of electric vehicles in 2013)|publisher=Rijksdienst voor Ondernemend (RVO) |location=The Netherlands |date=January 2014|accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref> The total cost of the tax exemptions for the Dutch treasury of the more than 22,000 plug-in electric vehicles sold in 2013 was estimated at {{euro|500 million}} ({{USD|691 million}}).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2014/03/seven_tax_breaks_on_electric_c.php|title=Seven tax breaks on electric cars cost Dutch treasury €500m|author=Volkskrant|author-link=Volkskrant|work=Dutch News|date=2014-03-29|accessdate=2014-04-21}}</ref>
===Norway=== {{See also|Plug-in electric vehicles in Norway}} [[File:Buddys and revas in norway.jpg|thumb|The [[Buddy (electric car)|Buddy]] and [[REVAi]] were among the top selling electric cars in Norway until 2010. Shown a free parking lot for EVs with charging stations.]]
The [[Parliament of Norway]] set the goal to reach 50,000 [[zero emission vehicle]]s by 2018. Among the existing incentives, [[all-electric car]]s are exempt in Norway from all non-recurring vehicle fees, including purchase taxes, which are extremely high for ordinary cars, and 25% [[VAT]] on purchase, together making electric car purchase price competitive with conventional cars.<ref name=NorIncentives/> As an example, by early 2013 the price of the top selling Nissan Leaf is 240,690 [[Norwegian krone|kroner]] (around {{USD|42,500}}) while the purchase price of the 1.3-lt [[Volkswagen Golf]] is 238,000 Krone (about {{USD|42,000}}).<ref name=Reuters032013>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/13/us-cars-norway-idUSBRE92C0K020130313|title=Norway shows the way with electric cars, but at what cost? |first1=Alister |last1=Doyle |first2=Nerijus |last2=Adomaitis |work=[[Reuters]]|date=2013-03-13|accessdate=2013-03-15}}</ref> Electric vehicles are also exempt from the annual [[road tax]], all public [[Free parking|parking fees]], and [[toll road|toll payments]], as well as being able to use [[bus lane]]s.<ref name=NorIncentives>{{cite web|url=http://www.emc-mec.ca/files/Electric_Mobility_Canada_2008_open.pdf |title=Electric Vehicle Policies in Norway |first=Lars Ole |last=Valøen |accessdate=2012-10-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302034445/http://www.emc-mec.ca/files/Electric_Mobility_Canada_2008_open.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-02 |df= }}</ref><ref name=NORincentives>{{cite web|url=http://www.elbil.no/om-elbilforeningen/english-please |title=The Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association |publisher=Norsk Elbilforening (Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association) |date=October 2012 |accessdate=2012-10-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011060518/http://elbil.no/om-elbilforeningen/english-please |archivedate=2012-10-11 |df= }}</ref>
Government officials reserved in 1999 the "EL" prefix for exclusive use of all-electric vehicles in order to be able to enforce on the road the benefits available to EVs. As the "EL" series is set to end at "EL 99999" ([[Vehicle registration plates of Norway#Prefixes and sequence numbers|most vehicles in the country have five-digit registration numbers between 10000 and 99999]]), the Norwegian Public Roads agency opted for the prefix "EK" in the second series of plates, to signify "''elektrisk kjøretøy''", Norwegian for electric vehicle. And because the sale of electric vehicles is expected to continue at a rapid pace, meaning that the second phase of license plates is likely to run out as well, the "EV" prefix has been set aside for future electric cars.<ref name=NorskEK>{{cite news| url=http://www.newsinenglish.no/2015/08/28/electric-car-craze-keeps-rolling-along/ |title=Electric car craze keeps rolling along |first=Nina |last=Berglund |work=News in English.no |date=2015-08-28 |accessdate=2016-03-05}}</ref> In July 2016, as the stock of "EL" prefix plates was almost depleted, the first electric vehicles registered with the new "EK" series were on the road.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dinside.no/937121/elbil-eller-ladbar-hybrid | title=Elbil eller ladbar hybrid? |language=Norwegian |trans-title=BEV or PHEV? |first=Fred Magne |last=Skillebæk |work=Dinside.no | date=2016-08-14 | accessdate=2016-08-15}}</ref><ref name=EKseries>{{cite news | url=http://norwaytoday.info/finance/first-ek-registered-e-cars-road/ | title=The first EK-registered e-cars on the road | first=Stefan | last=Jekic | work=Norway Today | date=2016-07-11 | accessdate=2016-08-15}}</ref>
Until June 2013, [[plug-in hybrid]]s have not been eligible for these benefits.<ref name="NorIncentives"/><ref name="NORincentives"/> Because the Norwegian tax system levies higher taxes to heavier vehicles, plug-in hybrids are more expensive than similar conventional cars due to the extra weight of the battery pack and its additional electric components. Beginning on 1 July 2013, the existing weight allowance for [[hybrid electric vehicle|conventional hybrid]]s and plug-in hybrids of 10% will be increased to 15% for PHEVs.<ref name=IncentivesPHEV2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.gronnbil.no/nyheter/billigere-plug-in-hybrider-fra-1-juli-article338-239.html |title=Billigere plug-in hybrider fra 1.juli |trans-title=Cheaper plug-in hybrids from 1 July |publisher=Grønn bil |date=2013-06-05 |accessdate=2013-06-06 |language=Norwegian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807123118/http://www.gronnbil.no/nyheter/billigere-plug-in-hybrider-fra-1-juli-article338-239.html |archivedate=2013-08-07 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Nissan Leaf in bus lanes Norway.jpg|thumb|left|Electric cars have access to [[bus lane]]s in Norway. Shown a Nissan Leaf, the top selling plug-in electric car in the country since 2012.]]
In September 2013 the Norwegian Parliament approved, as part of the revised 2014 budget, an exemption from the 25% VAT for leasing electric vehicles effective on 1 January 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elbil.no/nyheter/debatt/3128-positive-elbilnyheter-i-budsjettforliket |title=Positive elbilnyheter i budsjettforliket |language=Norwegian |trans-title=Positive EV news in the budget compromise |first=Ståle |last=Frydenlund |publisher=Norsk Elbilforening (Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association) |date=2013-11-15 |accessdate=2014-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140914045447/http://www.elbil.no/nyheter/debatt/3128-positive-elbilnyheter-i-budsjettforliket |archivedate=2014-09-14 |df= }}</ref> However, {{as of|2014|09|lc=y}}, the exemption has not gone into effect because the [[Minister of Finance (Norway)|Minister of Finance]] decided to defer the measure, pending a formal consultation with the [[EFTA Surveillance Authority]] (ESA) to ensure that the VAT exemption for leasing was not in violation of the [[European Economic Area]] Agreement. The government's loss of revenue due to the still not implemented leasing exemption is estimated at about 47 million [[Norwegian krone|krone]] (around {{USD|7.3 million}}) per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elbil.no/nyheter/debatt/3355-elbilforeningen-markerte-seg-pa-nrk |title=Elbilforeningen fikk fram MVA-misnøye på NRK |language=Norwegian |trans-title=The EV Society brought forth VAT dissatisfaction on NRK |first=Ståle |last=Frydenlund |publisher=Norsk Elbilforening (Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association) |date=2014-09-08 |accessdate=2014-09-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140914045700/http://www.elbil.no/nyheter/debatt/3355-elbilforeningen-markerte-seg-pa-nrk |archivedate=2014-09-14 |df= }}</ref><ref name=LeasingVAT>{{cite news|url=http://www.vg.no/forbruker/bil-baat-og-motor/venstre-raja-lei-av-sivs-elbil-sommel/a/23292011/|title=Venstre-Raja lei av Sivs elbil-sommel|language=Norwegian|trans-title=Left-Raja tired of Sivs EV-procrastination|first1=Alf Bjarne |last1=Johnsen |first2=Hanne |last2=Hattrem |work=[[Verdens Gang]]|date=2014-09-11|accessdate=2014-09-15}}</ref> One Member of Parliament has criticized the government for the delay. He had argued that the initial VAT exemption for all electric vehicles was never approved in ESA. In addition, an ESA spokesman confirmed that the Government has not sent any request {{as of|2014|09|lc=y}}, nor has ESA received any complaints about Norway's original EV tax exemption. The MP said he will demand that the decision be implemented when Parliament meets in October 2014.<ref name=LeasingVAT/>
[[File:Feiring av EL60000 i Norge 50K.jpg|thumb|The government's initial goal of 50,000 electric cars on Norwegian roads was reached on 20 April 2015. The plate "EL 60000" was granted to the 50,000th electric car registered.<ref name=Nor50K/>]]
The target of 50,000 electric cars on Norwegian roads was reached on 20 April 2015, more than two years earlier than expected.<ref name=Nor50K>{{cite news|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/norway-celebrates-50000th-plug-in-car-sold-will-ev-incentives-continue/|title=Norway Celebrates 50,000th Plug-in Car Sold; Will EV Incentives Continue?|first=Jeff |last=Cobb|work=HybridCars.com|date=2015-04-20|accessdate=2015-04-20}}</ref><ref name=EVs50K>{{cite web|url=http://www.elbil.no/nyheter/elbilpolitikk/3519-50-000-elbiler-pa-norske-veier |title=50.000 elbiler på norske veier! |language=Norwegian |trans-title=50,000 electric cars on Norwegian roads! |first=Petter |last=Haugneland |publisher=Norsk elbilforening (Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association |date=2015-04-20 |accessdate=2015-04-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425221106/http://www.elbil.no/nyheter/elbilpolitikk/3519-50-000-elbiler-pa-norske-veier |archivedate=2015-04-25 |df= }}</ref> In early March 2015 negotiations began among parties represented in the Parliament to define the future of all motor vehicles and fuel taxes. The Liberal Party wanted all the benefits to continue beyond the established quota. The Ministry of Finance also made a comprehensive review of all motor vehicle taxes. The two purchase tax exemptions cost the government about 3 billion [[Norwegian krone|krone]] (around {{USD|480 million}}) in lost revenue just in 2014, and up to 4 billion [[Norwegian krone|krone]] (around {{USD|640 million}}) if all the other benefits are accounted for.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tv2.no/2015/02/26/nyheter/el-bil/6621425|title=Fredningstiden for elbilene snart over|language=Norwegian|trans-title=Close season for electric cars will be over soon|first1==Kristoffer |last1=Thoner |first2=Robin |last2=Krüger |work=[[TV 2 (Norway)|TV2]]|date=2015-02-26|accessdate=2015-03-15}}</ref> Despite passing the established cap of 50,000 electric cars, the tax benefits were expected to continue at least until the end of 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aftenbladet.no/nyheter/okonomi/50000-elbiler-passeres-denne-maneden-3668323.html|title=50.000 elbiler passeres denne måneden|language=Norwegian|trans-title=50,000 EVs passed this month|author=[[Norsk Telegrambyrå]] (NBT)|work=Aften Bladet|date=2015-04-02|accessdate=2015-04-21}}</ref><ref name=Nor50K_3>{{cite news|url=http://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/article_xinhua.aspx?id=277541|title=Feature: Electric cars in Norway make headway mixed with growing public debate|work=[[Shanghai Daily]]|date=2015-04-21|accessdate=2015-04-21}}</ref>
==== Phase out of incentives ====
In May 2015 the Government decided to keep the existing incentives through 2017, and the political parties in Parliament agreed to reduced and phase out some of the incentives. Beginning in January 2018, electric car owners will be required to pay half of the yearly road license fee and the full rate as of 2020. The value-added tax (VAT) exemption for electric cars will end in 2018, but replaced by a new scheme, which may be subjected to a ceiling that could be reduced as technology develops. The agreement also gave local authorities the right to decide whether electric cars can park for free and use public transport lanes.<ref name=EV2018_1>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/transport/11589548/Norway-to-slash-electric-car-perks-because-its-costing-government-too-much-money.html | title=Norway to slash electric car perks because it's costing government too much money |work=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2015-05-07|accessdate=2016-03-06}}</ref><ref name=EV2018_2>{{cite news| url=http://www.dn.no/nyheter/politikkSamfunn/2015/05/06/2226/Bilavgifter/samarbeidspartiene-enige-om-bilavgifter | title= Samarbeidspartiene enige om bilavgifter |language=Norwegian| trans-title=Cooperative parties agreed vehicle taxes |work=[[Dagens Næringsliv]] |date=2015-05-06|accessdate=2016-03-06}}</ref>
In March 2016, the Ministry of Transport issued new regulations for parking in locations with access to the general public. The new parking regulations, that go into effect on January 1, 2017, terminated the free parking for zero-emission vehicles, but established that Municipalities can introduce payment exemption for electric and hydrogen powered motor vehicles on municipal parking locations.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://lovdata.no/dokument/SF/forskrift/2016-03-18-260#KAPITTEL_1 | title=Forskrift om vilkårsparkering for allmennheten og håndheving av private parkeringsreguleringer (parkeringsforskriften) | language=Norwegian | trans-title=Regulations on conditions parking for the general public and the enforcement of private parking regulations (parking regulations) |author=Ministry of Transport | publisher=LOVEDATA | accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> {{As of|2016|09}}, the city councils of [[Trondheim]] and [[Tønsberg]] decided to introduce full payment for EVs from 2017; the cities of [[Bodø]] and [[Tromsø]] will introduce payment for parking in downton but exempted parking outside the city's center; and the cities of [[Oslo]], [[Mandal, Norway|Mandal]] and [[Drammen]] decided to keep free parking for zero-emission vehicles.<ref name=Norsk092016>{{cite web | url= http://elbil.no/mandal-forst-ute-med-fortsatt-gratis-parkering-for-elbil/ | title=Mandal først ute med fortsatt gratis parkering for elbil |language=Norwegian |trans-title=Mandal pioneered to keep free parking for electric cars | first=Petter |last=Haugneland |publisher=Norsk Elbilforening (Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association) |date=2016-09-16 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://elbil.no/drammen-fortsetter-med-gratis-elbilparkering/ | title=Drammen fortsetter med gratis elbilparkering |language=Norwegian |trans-title=Drammen continues with free parking for electric cars | first=Ståle |last=Frydenlundd |publisher=Norsk Elbilforening (Norwegian Electric Vehicle Association) |date=2016-09-21 |accessdate=2016-09-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.tv2.no/nyheter/8620804/ | title=I denne byen blir det slutt på gratis elbil-parkering |language=Norwegian |trans-title=This city finally gets free electric vehicle parking | first=Robin |last=Krüger | work=[[TV 2 (Norway)|TV2]] |date=2016-09-27 |accessdate=2016-09-28}}</ref>
===Portugal=== The Portuguese Government launched in early 2008 a national Programme for Electric Mobility called [[Mobi.E]].<ref>[http://www.mobi-e.pt/ MOBI.E - Rede Nacional de Mobilidade Eléctrica. A energia que nos move]. Mobi-e.pt (2010-06-15). Retrieved on 2010-10-14.</ref>
Mobi.E is deploying a national electric mobility system. The system was designed to be scalable and used in multiple geographies, overcoming the current situation of lack of communication among the different electric mobility experiences that are being deployed in Europe. By the first semester of 2011, a wide public network of 1 300 normal and 50 fast charging points will be fully implemented in the main 25 cities of the country.
EVs are fully exempt from both the Vehicle Tax due upon purchase (Imposto Sobre Veículos) and the annual Circulation Tax (Imposto Único de Circulação). Personal income tax provides an allowance of EUR 803 upon the purchase of EVs. EVs are exempt from the 5%-10% company car tax rates which are part of the Corporation Income Tax. The Budget Law provides for an increase of the depreciation costs related to the purchase of EVs for the purpose of Corporation Income Tax.
[[Portugal]] established a government subsidy of €5,000 for the first 5,000 new electric cars sold in the country. In addition, there is in place a €1,500 incentive if the consumer turns in a used car as part of the down payment for the new electric car.<ref name=Portg0510>{{cite news|url=https://jn.sapo.pt/blogs/velocidade/archive/2010/05/17/nissan-j-225-divulgou-pre-231-o-do-carro-el-233-ctrico-leaf.aspx|title=Nissan já divulgou preço do carro eléctrico Leaf|publisher=Journal de Notícias|date=2010-05-17|accessdate=2010-05-17|language=Portuguese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20100517184611/http%3A//jn.sapo.pt/blogs/velocidade/archive/2010/05/17/nissan%2Dj%2D225%2Ddivulgou%2Dpre%2D231%2Do%2Ddo%2Dcarro%2Del%2D233%2Dctrico%2Dleaf.aspx|archivedate=2010-05-17|df=}}</ref> Electric cars are also exempt from the registration tax.<ref name=ACEA3>{{cite web|url=http://www.acea.be/images/uploads/files/20100420_EV_tax_overview.pdf|title=Overview of Tax Incentives for Electric Vehicles in the EU|publisher=[[European Automobile Manufacturers Association]]|date=2010-04-20|accessdate=2010-05-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611201348/http://www.acea.be/images/uploads/files/20100420_EV_tax_overview.pdf|archivedate=2011-06-11|df=}}</ref>
===Romania===
{{As of|2011|04}}, [[Romania]] offers a government grant of up to 25% of the price (up to a maximum of {{euro|5,000}}) for the purchase of a new electric car.<ref name=Romania>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/english/romanian-clunkers-program-available-for-electric-car-buyers-starting-next-week-8157168|title=Romanian Clunkers Program Available For Electric Car Buyers Starting Next Week|publisher=MediaFax|date=2011-04-14|accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref> Furthermore, through the cash-for-clunkers program ([[scrappage program]]), those who wish to purchase an electric car will receive vouchers of over €5,000 total in return for their used car.<ref name=Romania/> For hybrid vehicles, with or without plug-in capabilities, a €550 grant is offered, plus an additional €160 grant for hybrid vehicles emitting under 100g/km of {{CO2}}. Combined with the cash-for-clunkers program, the total grant is up to €2200.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.promotor.ro/masini-noi/dosar-analize/analiza-merita-sau-nu-sa-cumperi-un-hibrid-plug-in-sau-o-masina-electrica-14204615|title=ANALIZĂ: merită sau nu să cumperi un hibrid plug-in sau o maşină electrică?|author=Apropo Media|work=promotor.ro}}</ref> Electric and hybrid vehicles are exempt from the environmental tax, which also acts as a registration tax. From March 2015, electric vehicles are also exempt from the annual tax, while hybrid vehicles have a 95% reduction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digi24.ro/Stiri/Digi24/Gadget/Auto/Impozit+mic+pentru+masinile+electrice+si+hibrid|title=Impozit mic pentru mașinile electrice și hibrid|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2016, the "Rabla Plus" program offered a government grant of {{currency|5,000|EUR}} for the purchase of a new electric car.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mmediu.ro/app/webroot/uploads/files/2016-06-14_INFOGRAFIC_Rabla_2016.pdf |title=Infografic rabla 2016 |publisher=Ministry of Environment, Water and Forests |location=Romania |language=Romanian |date=2016-06-14 |access-date=2016-09-16}}</ref> In 2017, the "Rabla Plus" grant program increased to EUR 10,000 for the purchase of a pure electric vehicle (BEV). Furthermore, car owners will receive an additional {{currency|1,400|EUR}} if they end their registration of a car older than eight years.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.romania-insider.com/romanias-cash-bangers-rabla-program-kick-off-mid-may/ |title=Romania's Cash-for-Bangers "Rabla" program to kick off in mid-May |work=Romania Insider |date=2017-05-12 |access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref>
===Spain=== Spain's government aimed to have 1 million electric cars on the roads by 2014 as part of a plan to cut energy consumption and dependence on expensive imports, Industry Minister Miguel Sebastián said.<ref name="euobserver.com">{{cite web|url=http://euobserver.com/882/26594|title=EUobserver / EU states plug in to electric cars|first=Helena |last=Spongenberg|date=2008-08-27|publisher=Euobserver.com|accessdate=2009-09-19}}</ref><ref name="blogs.edmunds.com">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2008/07/spain-taking-steps-to-put-1-million-electric-vehicles-on-nations-roads-by-2014.html |title="Spain Taking Steps to Put 1 Million Electric Vehicles on Nation's Roads by 2014" Green Car Advisor |publisher=Blogs.edmunds.com |date=2008-07-30 |accessdate=2009-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091227043904/http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2008/07/spain-taking-steps-to-put-1-million-electric-vehicles-on-nations-roads-by-2014.html |archivedate=2009-12-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gas2.org/2008/07/30/1-million-electric-cars-on-spains-roads-by-2014/|title=1 Million Electric Cars on Spain’s Roads by 2014|work=Gas 2}}</ref><ref>[http://www.triplepundit.com/2008/07/spain-to-put-1-million-electric-cars-on-the-road/]</ref>
In May 2011 the Spanish government approved a {{€|72 million}} ({{USD|103 million}}) fund for year 2011 to promote electric vehicles. The incentives include direct subsidies for the acquisition of new electric cars for up to 25% of the purchase price, before tax, to a maximum of €6,000 per vehicle (US$8,600), and 25% of the gross purchase price of other electric vehicles such as buses and vans, with a maximum of €15,000 or €30,000, depending on the range and type of vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/05/spain-20110510.html#more|title=Government of Spain approves subsidies for purchase of electric vehicles|date=2011-05-10|publisher=Green Car Congress |accessdate=2011-05-10}}</ref> Several regional government grant incentives for the purchase of [[alternative fuel vehicle]]s including electric and hybrid vehicles. In [[Aragón]], [[Asturias]], [[Balearic Islands|Baleares]], [[Madrid]], [[Navarra]], [[Valencia, Spain|Valencia]], [[Castilla-La Mancha]], [[Murcia]], [[Castilla y León]] electric vehicles are eligible to a €6,000 tax incentive and hybrids to €2,000.<ref name=ACEA3/>
===Sweden=== In September 2011 the Swedish government approved a {{SEK|200 million}} program, effective starting in January 2012, to provide a subsidy of {{SEK|40,000}} per car for the purchase of electric cars and other "super green cars" with ultra-low carbon emissions (below 50 grams of carbon dioxide per km).<ref>{{cite news|last=Desk|first=Lifestyle|title=Sweden Follows Suit with Electric Car Subsidy|url=http://theglobalherald.com/sweden-follows-suit-with-electric-car-subsidy/24444/|accessdate=13 September 2011|newspaper=The Global Herald|date=2011-09-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111017103803/http://theglobalherald.com/sweden-follows-suit-with-electric-car-subsidy/24444/|archivedate=2011-10-17}}</ref> There is also an exemption from the annual circulation tax for the first five years from the date of their first registration that benefits owners of electric vehicles with an energy consumption of 37 [[kWh]] per 100 km or less, and hybrid vehicles with {{CO2}} emissions of 120 [[g/km]] or less. In addition, for both electric and hybrid vehicles, the taxable value of the car for the purposes of calculating the benefit in kind of a company car under personal income tax is reduced by 40% compared with the corresponding or comparable gasoline- or diesel-powered car. The reduction of the taxable value has a cap of {{SEK|16,000}} per year.<ref name=ACEA2/>
{{As of|2014|07}}, a total of 5,028 new "super clean cars" had been registered in the country since January 2012, and because the government allocated funds for a total of 5,000 super clean cars between 2012 and 2014, the fund has been exhausted.<ref name=Sweden072014>{{cite web|url=http://www.bilsweden.se/statistik/nyregistreringar_per_manad_1/nyregistreringar-2014/nyregistreringar-juli-2014|title=Fjärde högsta julisiffran någonsin för nya bilar|language=Swedish|trans-title=Fourth highest July sales figure ever for new cars|work=Bil Sweden |date=2014-08-01|accessdate=2014-09-01}} ''A total of 5,209 super clean cars have been registered in Sweden since 2011. Super clean cars are those with carbon dioxide emissions of up to 50 g/km. ''</ref><ref name=RebateEnds>{{cite news|url=http://www.dn.se/ekonomi/supermiljobilspremien-ar-slut/|title=Supermiljöbilspremien är slut|language=Swedish|trans-title=Super car rebate ends|author=Lasse Swärd|work=[[Dagens Nyheter]]|date=2014-08-01|accessdate=2014-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://avenytv.se.hemsida.eu/bilsweden/index.php/statistik/157-fjarde-hogsta-julisiffran-nagonsin-for-nya-bilar |title=Fjärde högsta julisiffran någonsin för nya bilar |language=Swedish |trans-title=Fourth highest July sales figure ever for new cars |publisher=[[Joomla]] |date=August 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903070211/http://avenytv.se.hemsida.eu/bilsweden/index.php/statistik/157-fjarde-hogsta-julisiffran-nagonsin-for-nya-bilar |archivedate=2014-09-03 |df= }}</ref> [[BIL Sweden]], the national association for the automobile industry, requested the government an additional {{SEK|100 million}} to cover the subsidy for another 2,500 registrations of new super clean cars between August and December 2014.<ref name="RebateEnds"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://avenytv.se.hemsida.eu/bilsweden/index.php/statistik/157-fjarde-hogsta-julisiffran-nagonsin-for-nya-bilar |title=Fjärde högsta julisiffran någonsin för nya bilar |language=Swedish |trans-title=Fourth highest July sales figure ever for new cars |publisher=[[Joomla]] |date=August 2014 |accessdate=2014-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903070211/http://avenytv.se.hemsida.eu/bilsweden/index.php/statistik/157-fjarde-hogsta-julisiffran-nagonsin-for-nya-bilar |archivedate=2014-09-03 |df= }}</ref> In December 2014 the [[Riksdagen]], the Swedish parliament, approved an appropriation of {{SEK|215 million}} to finance the super clean car subsidies in 2015. The appropriation for 2015, according to the parliamentary decision and subsequent government decision, was to also be used for the retroactive payment of the super green cars registered in 2014 that did not receive the subsidy.<ref name=Sweden2014>{{cite web|url=http://www.bilsweden.se/publikationer/pressmeddelanden/urstark-bilmarknad-under-2014|title=Urstark bilmarknad under 2014|language=Swedish|trans-title=Exceptionally strong car market in 2014|work=Bil Sweden|date=2015-10-02|accessdate=2015-02-22}} ''A total of 4,656 super clean cars and 282 all-electric vans were registered in Sweden in 2014. Super clean cars are those with carbon dioxide emissions of up to 50 g/km (two Porsche plug-in models, the Panamera S E-Hybrid and the 918 Spyder are not accounted as super clean cars, instead they are accounted with conventional hybrids). In 2011 there were 181 plug-in electric vehicles registered, 928 in 2012, 1,546 in 2013 and 4,656 super clean cars were registered during 2014. Since the introduction of the super clean car rebate in January 2012 until December 2014, a total of 7,130 super clean cars have been registered.''</ref>
The Government raised the appropriation for the super green car rebate by {{SEK|132 million}} for 2015 and by {{SEK|94 million}} for 2016. Beginning in 2016, only [[Zero-emissions vehicle|zero emissions cars]] are entitled to receive the full {{SEK|40,000}} premium, while other super green cars, plug-in hybrids, receive half premium. The exemption for the first five years of ownership from the annual circulation tax is still in place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bilsweden.se/fordon-i-samhallet/miljo/e10/stimulanser-for-miljobilar |title=Stimulanser för miljöbilar |language=Swedish |trans-title=Incentives for green cars |work=Bil Sweden |date=2016 |accessdate=2016-10-21}}</ref><ref name=Subisdies2015_2020/> In 2016, in order to promote the introduction of electricity-powered buses in the market, the Government planned to allocate {{SEK|50 million}} for 2016 and {{SEK|100 million}} per year between 2017 and 2019 to introduce an electric bus premium.<ref name=Subisdies2015_2020>{{cite web |url=http://www.government.se/government-policy/environment/fossil-free-transport-and-travel-the-governments-work-to-reduce-the-impact-of-transport-on-the-climate/ |title=Fossil-free transport and travel: The Government's work to reduce the impact of transport on the climate |publisher=Government Offices of Sweden |date=2016-05-25 |accessdate=2016-10-21}}</ref>
Two alternative proposals are being considered by the Swedish government regarding the introduction of a [[bonus-malus]] system. Both proposals entail changes to vehicle and car benefit taxation and the premium system for purchases of new cars. An official inquiry report was due by 29 April 2016. The goal is for the system to enter into force on 1 January 2017.<ref name=Subisdies2015_2020/> The new bonus-malus system, starting 1 july 2018, will offer electric car buyers a bonus of 60 000 SEK.<ref>https://www.transportstyrelsen.se/bonusmalus#166190</ref>
===Switzerland=== Switzerland has a car import tax which is 4% of the purchase price (before adding the VAT) which is waived for electric cars.<ref name=ezv>{{cite web|url=http://www.ezv.admin.ch/zollinfo_privat/04392/04393/04394/index.html?lang=de|title=Eidgenössische Zollverwaltung|date=2013-05-21}}</ref><ref name=xtares>{{cite web|url=http://xtares.admin.ch|title=swiss customs database}}</ref> Since [[Switzerland]] consists of [[cantons of Switzerland|26 cantons]] which have their own legislature, additional incentives for plug-in electric vehicles differ between the respective regions. The current list can be downloaded from the website of the Swiss Department of Energy.<ref name=bfe>{{cite web|url=http://www.bfe.admin.ch/energieetikette/00886/02038/index.html?lang=de&dossier_id=02083|title=Bundesamt für Energie|date=2014-02-04}}</ref>
There are no additional incentives on the actual purchase price, but some cantons offer road tax cuts. The Swiss road tax is a yearly recurring fixed amount calculated based on the specifications of the tax payers car. Currently, only the cantons [[Canton of Glarus|Glarus]] (GL), [[Canton of Solothurn|Solothurn]] (SO), [[Ticino]] (TI) and [[Canton of Zurich|Zurich]] (ZH) are completely waiving the tax for plug-in electric vehicles.
;Calculation example for [[Canton of Zurich|Zurich]]
Based on a usual car with the following specification:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stva.zh.ch/internet/sicherheitsdirektion/stva/de/StVAgeb/GEBva14/VArechner.html|title=Verkehrsabgabenrechner|work=zh.ch}}</ref> * Engine: 2 L * Total weight: 1800 kg * Energy efficiency: C * Year: 2013
The resulting tax to be paid per year will be {{CHF|278}}. Hence when calculating with a life expectancy of 10 years, the car owner in this example might save around {{CHF|2,780}} when buying a plug-in electric car.
However, since the [[Fuel tax|tax on fossil fuels]] are relatively high in all European countries, including Switzerland, there is still an indirect, but quite strong incentive for car buyers to decide for energy efficient vehicles.
Based on the following examples: * Fuel economy: {{Convert|7.8|L/100km|mpgUS|abbr=on}} unleaded * Driving habits: {{Convert|15000|km|abbr=on}} per year * Fuel tax: {{CHF| 0.7312}} per liter ({{CHF|2.7679}} per gallon) * Carbon tax (since January 1, 2014): {{CHF|0.1414}} per liter ({{CHF|0.5353}} per gallon)
The resulting taxes on the burned fuels will be around {{CHF|1,021}} per year, which results in {{CHF|10,210}} over the car's 10-year lifetime.
===United Kingdom=== {{See also|Plug-in electric vehicles in the UK}}
====Plug-in Car Grant====
The Plug-in Car Grant started on 1 January 2011 and is available across the UK. The program reduces the up-front cost of eligible cars by providing a 25% grant towards the cost of new plug-in cars capped at {{GBP|5,000}} ({{USD|7450}}).<ref name=GCC0210/><ref name=DfT>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/plug-in-car-grant/plug-in-car-grant-vehicles |title=Plug-in car grant eligibility guidance |publisher=[[Department for Transport]] |date=February 2015 |accessdate=2015-02-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216174641/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/plug-in-car-grant/plug-in-car-grant-vehicles |archivedate=2015-02-16 |df= }}</ref> From 1 April 2015, the purchase price cap was raised to cover up to 35% discount of the vehicle's recommended retail price, up to the already existing {{GBP|5,000}} limit. This change means electric cars priced under {{GBP|20,000}} will be able to take advantage of most or all of the £5,000 discount.<ref name=Grant2015>{{cite web|url=https://transportevolved.com/2015/02/13/uk-government-announces-changes-plug-car-incentives-introduces-banding-based-zev-capabilities/|title=UK Government Announces Changes to Plug-in Car Incentives, Introduces Banding Based on ZEV Capabilities|first=Nikki |last=Gordon-Bloomfield|publisher=Transport Evolved|date=2015-02-13|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> Both private and business fleet buyers are eligible for this grant, which is received at the point of purchase and the subsidy is claimed back by the manufacturer afterwards.<ref name=GCC0210>{{cite news|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/02/uk-ev-20100226.html|title=UK Government Announces £5,000 Grants Towards Purchase of Electric Drive Vehicles and First "Plugged-in Places"|publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2010-02-26|accessdate=2010-05-15}}</ref> The subsidy programme is managed in a similar way to the grant made as part of the 2009 [[Vehicle scrappage scheme (United Kingdom)|Car Scrappage Scheme]], allowing consumers to buy an eligible car discounted at the point of purchase with the subsidy claimed back by the manufacturer afterwards.<ref name=GCC0210/><ref name=DfT/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/motoring/green-motoring/7316351/5000-grant-to-buy-plug-in-electric-cars.html|title=£5,000 grant to buy plug-in electric cars|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|first=Paul |last=Hudson|date=2010-02-28|accessdate=2010-04-23 |location=London}}</ref>
[[File:Tesla Roadster.JPG|thumb|The [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Tesla Roadster]] was available in the UK but not included on the government's plug-in electric car grant list of eligible vehicles.<ref name=TeslaUK/>]]
The government announced in April 2014 that funding for the full grant of up to {{GBP|5000}} will remain in place until either 50,000 grants have been issued or 2017, whichever is first.<ref name=Grant2015/><ref name=UKGrant25K/> As forecasts estimated that the scheme will reach its 50,000 limit around November 2015, the government announced in August 2015 that the Plug-in Car Grant will continue until at least February 2016 for all plug-in cars with {{CO2}} emissions of 75 g/km of under.<ref name=GrantExtended>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextgreencar.com/news/7192/plugin-car-grant-scheme-extended/|title=Plug-in Car Grant scheme extended|first=Chris |last=Lilly|publisher=Next Green Car|location=UK |date=2015-08-26|accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref> The Government also announced that a minimum of {{GBP|200 million}} ({{USD|311 million}}) has been made available to continue the Plug-in Car Grant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2015/08/20150826-uk.html|title=UK extends current levels of the Plug-in Car Grant to at least February 2016 |publisher=Green Car Congress |first=Mike |last=Millikin|date=2015-08-26|accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref>
Vehicles eligible for the subsidy must meet the following criteria:<ref name=GCC0210/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://assets.dft.gov.uk/eligibility-criteria-summary.pdf |title=Summary of the Plug-in Car Grant Eligibility Criteria |publisher=[[Department for Transport]] |accessdate=2011-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328012159/http://assets.dft.gov.uk/eligibility-criteria-summary.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-28 |df= }}</ref> * Vehicle type: Only [[Ultra-low emission vehicle|ultra-low emission cars]] are eligible ([[Directive 2001/116/EC#Vehicle categories|vehicle category M1]]). Motorbikes, quadricycles and vans are not covered. * [[Carbon dioxide emission|Carbon dioxide exhaust emissions]]: Vehicles must emit equal or less than 75 [[g/km|grams of carbon dioxide ({{CO2}}) per kilometre]] driven. * Range: [[Electric vehicle]]s (EVs) must be able to travel a minimum of {{Convert|70|mi}} between charges. [[Plug-in hybrid electric vehicle]]s (PHEVs) must have a minimum [[all-electric range]] of {{Convert|10|mi}}. * Minimum top speed: Vehicles must be able to reach a speed of {{Convert|60|mph}} or more. * Warranty: Vehicles must have a 3-year or {{Convert|60,000|mi}} vehicle warranty (guarantee) and a 3-year battery and electric drive train warranty, with the option of extending the battery warranty for an extra 2 years('drive train' means the parts that send power from the engine to the wheels. These include the clutch, transmission (gear box), drive shafts, U-joints and differential). * Battery performance: Vehicles must have either a minimum 5-year warranty on the battery and electric drive train as standard, or extra evidence of battery performance to show reasonable performance after 3 years of use * Electrical safety: Vehicles must comply with certain regulations (UN-ECE Reg 100.01) that show that they are electrically safe. * Crash safety: To make sure cars will be safe in a crash, they must either have: EC whole vehicle type approval (EC WVTA, not small series) or evidence that the car has appropriate levels of safety as judged by international standards.
In February 2015 the government announced that to take account of rapidly developing technology, and the growing range of ULEVs on the British market, the criteria for the plug-in car grant was updated and from April 2015, eligible ultra-low emission vehicles (ULEVs) must meet criteria in one of the following categories depending on emission levels and zero-emission-capable mileage, with a technology neutral approach, which means that [[fuel cell vehicle|hydrogen fuel cell cars]] are also eligible for the grant:<ref name=DfT/><ref name=Grant2015/> * Category 1: {{CO2}} emissions of less than 50g/km and a zero emission range of at least {{Convert|70|mi|abbr=on}}. * Category 2: {{CO2}} emissions of less than 50g/km and a zero emission range between {{Convert|10|to|69|mi|abbr=on}}. * Category 3: {{CO2}} emissions of 50-75g/km and a zero emission range of at least {{Convert|20|mi|abbr=on}}.
In December 2015, the [[Department for Transport]] (DfT) announced that Plug-in car grant was extended until March 2018 to encourage more than 100,000 UK motorists to buy cleaner vehicles. A total funding of {{GBP|400 million}} (~{{USD|600 million}}) is available for the extension. To reflect the changes in the British market, the criteria for the Plug-in Car Grant was updated and the maximum grant drops from {{GBP|5,000}} (~{{USD|7,450}}) to {{GBP|4,500}} (~{{USD|6,700}}). For the extension, the amount of the grant is linked in directly with the Office for Low Emission Vehicles three vehicle categories issued in April 2015. The eligible ultra-low emission vehicles (ULEVs) must meet criteria in one of three categories depending on emission levels ({{CO2}} emissions bands between 50 and 75g/km) and zero-emission-capable mileage (minimum of {{Convert|10|mi|abbr=on}}), with a technology neutral approach, which means that [[fuel cell vehicle|hydrogen fuel cell cars]] are eligible for the grant.<ref name=Grant2015/><ref name=Extension2018>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/dec/17/plug-in-car-grant-extended-to-2018 |title=Plug-in car grant extended to 2018|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2015-12-17|accessdate=2015-12-20}}</ref><ref name=Extension2018_2>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextgreencar.com/news/7409/extension-announced-for-plugin-car-grant/ |title=Extension announced for Plug-in Car Grant|first=Chris |last=Lilly|publisher=Next Green Car|location=UK |date=2015-12-17|accessdate=2015-12-20}}</ref> The updated scheme went into force on 1 March 2016.<ref name=Extension2018_2/>
A price cap is in place, with all Category 1 plug-in vehicles eligible for the full grant no matter what their purchase price, while Category 2 and 3 models with a list price of more than {{GBP|60000}} (~{{USD|90000}}) are eligible for the grant. Vehicles with a zero-emission range of at least {{Convert|70|mi|abbr=on}} (category 1), including hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, get a full {{GBP|4,500}} (~{{USD|6,700}}), but plug-in hybrids (categories 2 and 3) costing under {{GBP|60000}} (~{{USD|90000}}) receive {{GBP|2500}} (~{{USD|3725}}).<ref name=Extension2018/><ref name=Extension2018_2/> Under the extended scheme, some plug-in hybrid sports car are no longer be eligible for the grant, such as the [[BMW i8]] because of its {{GBP|100000}} (~{{USD|150,000}}) purchase price tag.<ref name=Extension2018_3>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/cars/article-3364184/Plug-car-grant-extended-plug-hybrid-buyers-receive-half-saving.html |title=Plug-in car grant extended to 2018 but hybrid buyers will now receive half as much as before towards new vehicles|first=Robert |last=Hull |work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=2015-12-17|accessdate=2015-12-20}}</ref> The grant scheme will come under review when a cumulative total of 40,000 Category 1 claims, and 45,000 Category 2 and 3 combined sales have been made. Both these totals will include cars sold before March 2016.<ref name=Extension2018_2/>
{{As of|2016|10}}, the following 31 cars available in the British market are eligible for the grant according to their category:<ref name=UKGrantEligible>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/plug-in-car-van-grants/eligibility|title=Plug-in car and van grants - Eligible vehicles by category |publisher=UK Government|date=2016-10-25 | accessdate=2016-10-29}}</ref>
;Eligible category 1 vehicles [[BMW i3]], [[BYD e6]], [[Citroen C-Zero]], [[Ford Focus Electric]], [[Hyundai Ioniq Electric]], [[Kia Soul EV]], [[Mahindra e2o]], [[Mercedes-Benz B-Class Electric Drive]], [[Nissan e-NV200|Nissan e-NV200 5- and 7-seater Combi]], [[Nissan Leaf]], [[Peugeot iOn]], [[Renault Fluence Z.E.]], [[Renault Zoe]], [[Smart Fortwo electric drive]], [[Tesla Model S]], [[Toyota Mirai]], [[Volkswagen e-Golf]], and [[Volkswagen e-Up!]].
[[File:2016 BMW i8.jpg|thumb|[[Plug-in hybrid]] models with a list price of over {{GBP|60000}}, such as the [[BMW i8]], are no longer eligible for the Plug-in Car Grant from March 2016.<ref name=Extension2018_3/><ref name=UKGrantEligible/>]]
;Eligible category 2 vehicles [[Audi A3 e-tron]] (MY 2016 only), [[BMW 2 Series|BMW 225xe]], [[BMW 3 Series|BMW 330e]], [[Kia Optima PHEV]], [[Mercedes-Benz C-Class (W205)#C350 e Plug-in Hybrid (2015-)|Mercedes-Benz C350 e]], [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]] (except GX3h 4Work), [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]], [[Vauxhall Ampera]], [[Volkswagen Golf GTE]], [[Volkswagen Passat GTE]], [[Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid]] (D5 and D6 Twin Engine), and [[Volvo XC90 T8|Volvo XC90 T8 Twin Engine Momentum]].<ref name=UKGrantEligible/>
;Ineligible vehicles Category 2 or 3 vehicles with a recommended retail price over £60,000 aren't eligible for a grant. This includes: [[BMW i8]] (category 2), [[Mercedes-Benz S500 Plug-in Hybrid]] (category 3), and [[Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid]] (category 3).<ref name=UKGrantEligible/>
The [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Tesla Roadster]] was not included in the government's list of eligible vehicles for the plug-in electric car grant. Tesla Motors stated that the company applied for the scheme, but did not complete its application.<ref name=TeslaUK>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2010/dec/14/tesla-roadster-electric-car-list|title=Why is the Tesla Roadster not on the government's electric car grant list?|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2010-12-14|accessdate=2011-07-21}}</ref>
In addition to the extension of the Plug-in Grant, the government also announced it will continue the "Electric Vehicle Homecharge Scheme." Starting in March 2016 owners of ultra-low emission vehicles who install a dedicated charge point at their home, covering roughly half the average cost, will get {{GBP|500}} (~{{USD|750}}) towards the cost of installing the charging point, rather than the previous {{GBP|700}} (~{{USD|1050}}) maximum.<ref name=Extension2018/><ref name=Extension2018_2/>
====Plug-in Van Grant==== [[File:Vito E-Cell trimmed.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Mercedes-Benz Vito E-Cell]] is eligible for the Plug-In Van Grant.]]
The Plug-In Car Grant began in February 2012. Van buyers can receive 20% - up to {{GBP|8000}} - off the cost of a plug-in van. To be eligible for the scheme, vans have to meet performance criteria to ensure safety, range, and ultra-low tailpipe emissions. Consumers, both business and private will receive the discount at the point of purchase.<ref name=UKPIVan/> The Plug-In Van Grant scheme was extended in October 2016 to make electric trucks above 3.5 tonnes eligible for grants of up to {{GBP|20,000}}, when businesses switch their large trucks to an electric vehicle. The government also announced their commitment for an additional {{GBP|4 million}} to the scheme so that all vans and trucks meeting the eligibility requirements can benefit from the grant scheme.<ref name=UKtruck>{{cite web| url=http://www.investinuk.net/news/%C2%A34-million-boost-help-businesses-switch-vans-and-trucks-electric | title=£4 million boost to help businesses switch vans and trucks to electric | publisher=InvestInUK | date=October 2016 | accessdate=2016-10-29}}</ref> The extension of the Plug-In Van grant means that [[Large goods vehicle|N2 vans]] (3.5 – 12 tonnes gross weight) and [[Vehicle category#EU classification|N3 vans]] (over 12 tonnes gross weight) are now eligible.<ref name=UKtruck/>
The eligibility criteria for vans with a gross weight of 3.5 tonnes or less ([[Light commercial vehicle|N1 van]]) are:<ref name=UKPIVan>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/plug-in-van-grant|title=Plug-in Van Grant|publisher=[[Department for Transport]] (DfT) |location=UK |date=2014-02-03|accessdate=2014-08-17}} ''{{As of|2013|06|30}}, 637 claims have been made through the plug-in van grant program.''</ref>
* Vehicle type: only new [[Light commercial vehicle|N1 van]]s are eligible. This includes pre-registration conversions (normal, internal combustion engine vans that were converted to battery or hybrid versions by specialist converters before the car's first registration). * Carbon dioxide exhaust emissions: vehicles must emit less than 75 grams of carbon dioxide ({{CO2}}) per kilometre driven. * Range: eligible fully electric vans must be able to travel a minimum of {{convert|60|mi|abbr=on}} between charges. Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs) must have a minimum electric range of {{convert|10|mi}}. * Minimum top speed: vehicles must be able to reach a speed of {{convert|50|mi/h|abbr=on}} or more. * Warranty: Vehicles must have a 3-year or {{convert|60000|mi|abbr=on}} vehicle warranty (guarantee) and a 3-year battery and electric drive train warranty, with the option of extending the battery warranty for an extra 2 years * Battery performance: vehicles must have either a minimum 5-year warranty on the battery and electric drive train as standard or extra evidence of battery performance to show reasonable performance after 3 years of use * Electrical safety: vehicles must comply with certain regulations (UN-ECE Reg 100.00) that show that they are electrically safe. * Crash safety To make sure cars will be safe in a crash, they must either have EC whole vehicle type approval (EC WVTA, not small series) or evidence that the car has appropriate levels of safety as judged by international standards.
{{As of|2016|12}}, the number of claims made through the Plug-in Van Grant scheme totaled 2,938 units since the launch of the programme in 2012, up from 1,906 made by the end of December 2015.<ref name=UK4Q2016Van>{{cite web |url=http://www.racfoundation.org/data/plug-in-van-grant-claims-data-page |title=Claims made through the Plug-in Van Grant scheme |publisher=[[RAC Foundation]] |location=UK |date=February 2017 |accessdate=2017-02-24}} ''See graph with PIVG cumulative claims and claims by quarter''.</ref> {{As of|2016|10}} the following nine vans are eligible for the grant: [[BD Otomotive eTraffic]], [[BD Otomotiv eDucato]], [[Peugeot ePartner|Citroën Berlingo]], [[Mercedes-Benz Vito E-Cell]], [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV|Mitsubishi Outlander GX3h 4Work]], [[Nissan e-NV200]], [[Peugeot ePartner]], [[Renault Kangoo Z.E.]], and [[Smith Electric Edison]].<ref name=UKGrantEligible/>
====Number of beneficiaries====
The number of eligible registered plug-in electric vehicles passed the 25,000 unit milestone in January 2015.<ref name=UKGrant25K>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/take-up-of-plug-in-car-grant-continues-to-rise|title=Take-up of plug-in car grant continues to rise - Number of ultra-low emission vehicles breaks 25,000 barrier.|publisher=[[Department for Transport]], Office for Low Emission Vehicles and Baroness Krame|location=UK |date=2015-02-13|accessdate=2015-02-14}}</ref> {{As of|2017|03}}, the number of eligible registered plug-in electric cars that have benefited with the subsidy totaled 94,541 units since the launch of the programme in 2011.<ref name=UK032017>{{cite web | url=https://www.smmt.co.uk/2017/04/march-2017-ev-registrations/ |title=March 2017 – EV registrations |publisher=[[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]] (SMMT) |date=2017-04-05 |accessdate=2017-04-16}}</ref> {{As of|2016|12}}, the number of claims made through the Plug-in Van Grant scheme totaled 2,938 units since the launch of the programme in 2012.<ref name="UK4Q2016Van"/> About 90,000 [[plug-in electric vehicle]]s have been registered in the UK up until December 2016, including over 85,000 plug-in hybrids and all-electric cars, and about 4,000 plug-in commercial vans. Not all vehicles were eligible for the grant schemes.<ref name=UKStats>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextgreencar.com/electric-cars/statistics/|title=Electric car market statistics|first=Ben |last=Lane|publisher=Next Green Car|location=UK |date=February 2017|accessdate=2017-02-24}}</ref>
====Plugged-in Places==== On 19 November 2009, [[Andrew Adonis]], the [[Secretary of State for Transport]], announced a scheme called "Plugged-in-Places", making available £30 million to be shared between three and six cities to investigate further the viability of providing power supply for electric vehicles, and encouraging local government and business to participate and bid for funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.which.co.uk/news/2009/11/thousands-of-electric-car-charging-points-due-189176 |publisher=[[Which?]]|date=2009-11-20|accessdate=2009-11-22|title=Thousands of electric car charging points due}}</ref>
The UK government is supporting the "Plugged-In Places" program to install vehicle recharging points across the UK. The scheme offers match-funding to consortia of businesses and public sector partners to support the installation of EV recharging infrastructure in lead places across the UK.<ref name=DfT2>{{cite web|url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/topics/sustainable/olev/recharging-electric-vehicles/|title=Recharging infrastructure|publisher=[[Department for Transport]] |accessdate=2011-12-06}}</ref> There are eight Plugged-In Places:East of England;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sourceeast.net/ |title=Source East |publisher=Source East |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> Greater Manchester; London;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sourcelondon.net/ |title=Source London |publisher=Source London |date=2011-11-05 |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> Midlands;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cenex.co.uk/programmes/plugged-in-places|title=Plugged-in-Places|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110825170205/http://www.cenex.co.uk/programmes/plugged-in-places|archivedate=2011-08-25|df=}}</ref> Milton Keynes;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chargemasterplc.com/charging-schemes/milton-keynes/ |title=Milton Keynes « ChargeMaster |publisher=Chargemasterplc.com |accessdate=2012-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316101205/http://chargemasterplc.com/charging-schemes/milton-keynes/ |archivedate=2012-03-16 |df= }}</ref> North East;
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chargeyourcar.org.uk/ |title=Charge Your Car |publisher=Charge Your Car |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> Northern Ireland;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/ecar |title=Northern Ireland e-car project |publisher=nidirect |date=2009-10-04 |accessdate=2012-03-30}}</ref> and Scotland. The Government also published an Infrastructure Strategy in June 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/publications/plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy|title=Making the connection: the plug-in vehicle infrastructure strategy|work=dft.gov.uk}}</ref>
====London congestion charge==== [[Battery electric vehicles|All-electric vehicle]]s (BEVs) and eligible [[plug-in hybrid electric vehicle]]s (PHEVs) qualify for a 100% discount from the [[London congestion charge]]. A plug-in electric drive vehicle qualifies if the vehicle is registered with the [[Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency]] (DVLA) and has a fuel type of 'electric', or alternatively, if the vehicle is a 'plug-in hybrid' and is on the Government's list of PHEVs eligible for the OLEV grant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tfl.gov.uk/modes/driving/congestion-charge/discounts-and-exemptions?intcmp=4368|title=Discounts and exemptions - Ultra Low Emission Discount (ULED)|publisher=[[Transport for London]] |date=February 2015|accessdate=2015-02-15}} ''Click on "Ultra Low Emission Discount (ULED)" for details.''</ref> {{As of|2015|02}}, approved PHEVs include all extended-range cars such as the [[BMW i3 REx|BMW i3 with range extender]] and [[Vauxhall Ampera]], and plug-in hybrids that emit 75g/km or less of {{CO2}} and that meet the [[Euro 5]] standard for air quality, such as the [[Audi A3 Sportback e-tron]], [[BMW i8]], [[Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV]], and [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.goultralow.com/what-are-go-ultra-low-cars/types-of-vehicles/plug-in-hybrid/|title=Vehicle technologies - Plug-in hybrids|publisher=Go Ultra Low|date=February 2015|accessdate=2015-02-15}}</ref>
The original Greener Vehicle Discount was substituted by the Ultra Low Emission Discount (ULED) scheme that went into effect on 1 July 2013. The ULED introduced more stringent emission standards that limited the free access to the congestion charge zone to any car or van that emits 75g/km or less of CO<sub>2</sub> and meets the [[Euro 5]] emission standards for air quality. {{As of|2013|07}} there are no [[internal combustion]]-only vehicles that meet this criteria. The measure is designed to limit the growing number of diesel vehicles on London's roads. [[Mayor Boris Johnson]] approved the new scheme in April 2013, after taking into account a number of comments received during the 12-week public consultation that took place. About 20,000 owners of vehicles registered for the Greener Vehicle Discount by June 2013 were granted a three-year [[Sunset provision|sunset period]] (until 24 June 2016) before they have to pay the full congestion charge.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/04/uled-20130424.html |title=London to introduce new Ulta Low Emission Discount for Congestion Charge scheme; countering dieselization |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2013-04-24 |accessdate=2013-04-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/apr/24/pollution|title=London tightens up congestion charge in attempt to drive out diesel |work=[[The Guardian]]|date=2013-04-24|accessdate=2013-04-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thegreencarwebsite.co.uk/blog/index.php/2013/07/01/london-tightens-congestion-charge-exemptions/ |title=London tightens Congestion Charge exemptions |first=Faye |last=Sunderland |publisher=The Green Car Website |location=UK |date=2013-07-01 |accessdate=2013-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216062939/http://www.thegreencarwebsite.co.uk/blog/index.php/2013/07/01/london-tightens-congestion-charge-exemptions/ |archivedate=2015-02-16 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-23125082|title=New green discount for the congestion charge comes in |work=[[BBC News]]|date=2013-07-01|accessdate=2013-07-02}}</ref>
==North America== ===Canada=== ====Ontario==== [[File:Ride and Drive EVs Plug'n Drive Ontario.jpg|thumb|[[Nissan Leaf]], [[Smart electric drive]], and [[Mitsubishi i MiEV]] (from farthest to closest) electric cars in downtown [[Toronto]].]]
;Former rebate program The Ontario Ministry of Transportation (MTO) established the Electric Vehicle Incentive Program (EVIP) – later renamed the Electric and Hydrogen Vehicle Incentive Program (EHVIP) {{endash}} in 2010. To qualify, Battery Electric Vehicles (BEVs) and Plug-In Hybrid Electric Vehicles (PHEVs) had to be purchased or leased from a seller in Ontario and owned or leased for at least 12 months. Leased vehicles with 12 month terms received 33% of the incentive, 24-month lease terms received 66%, and lease terms 36 months or longer received the full incentive. Vehicles were required to be on a government-developed list of approved vehicles to qualify, and vehicles with a Manufacturer's Suggested Retail Price (MSRP) of {{CAD|75,000}} or greater were not eligible for the incentive. Electric vehicles with a battery size of 5 -16 kWh were eligible for incentives from {{CAD|6000}} to {{CAD|10,000}}. Vehicles with a battery size exceeding 16 kWh qualified for {{CAD|9000}} to {{CAD|13,000}}. Vehicles with five or more seats were eligible for an additional {{CAD|1000}}. Demonstration vehicles under a specified mileage and used exclusively for test drives at dealerships or leasing companies were also eligible. Applications for incentives were required to be submitted within 3 months of the vehicle's provincial registration. Prior to the cancellation of the program, the Government of Ontario included rebates of up to {{CAD|14000}} for electric and hybrid vehicles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mto.gov.on.ca/english/vehicles/electric/electric-vehicle-rebate.shtml |title=Eligible Electric Vehicles |publisher=Ministry of Transportation |location=[[Ontario]] |date=2017-12-14 |access-date=2018-01-02}}</ref> The EHVIP was financed by proceeds from Ontario's participation with Quebec and California in the [[Western Climate Initiative]] (WCI) cap-and-trade program.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mto.gov.on.ca/english/vehicles/electric/electric-vehicle-incentive-program.shtml |title=Electric vehicles incentive program |publisher=Ministry of Transportation |location=[[Ontario]] |date=2017-02-01 |access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref>
The program (and the companion incentive program to encourage private businesses to install charging stations) was cancelled on July 11, 2018 after the government of Premier [[Doug Ford]] began the withdrawal of Ontario from the WCI.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ontario government ends electric and hydrogen vehicle incentive programs |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ontario-electric-hydrogen-vehicle-charging-incentive-program-ends-1.4743579 |work=CBC News |date=2018-07-11 |access-date=2018-07-23}}</ref> Rebates will still be issued for vehicles if either of the following conditions are met: the vehicle was delivered to the consumer, registered, and plated on or before July 11; or the vehicle is currently in the inventory of a dealership or was ordered from the manufacturer on or before July 11, provided that the vehicle is delivered to the consumer, registered, and plated by September 10.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Maronese |first1=Nicholas |title=Ontario’s EV rebate goes away by September 10 |url=https://driving.ca/auto-news/news/ontarios-ev-rebate-goes-away-by-september-10 |work=Driving |publisher=Postmedia Network |date=2018-07-12 |access-date=2018-07-23}}</ref>
;Green vehicle plates [[File:2010 Ontario license plate GVAH 823 electric vehicle.png|thumb|Design of the Ontario Green Vehicle License Plate]]
Electric vehicles in Ontario are eligible for special license plates, officially called Green Vehicle License Plates, from the Ministry of Transportation. In addition to a green colour scheme distinct from the province's typical blue and white license plates, these green plates permit BEV and PHEV owners to travel in the province's [[High-occupancy vehicle lane|high-occupancy vehicle]] (HOV) and travel at no cost in the [[High-occupancy toll lane|high-occupancy toll]] (HOT) lanes, regardless of the number of passengers in the vehicle.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Goddard |first1=John |title=Going green has perks for drivers |url=https://www.thestar.com/business/personal_finance/spending_saving/2011/09/02/going_green_has_perks_for_drivers.html |work=Toronto Star |date=2011-09-02 |access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Ontario's Green Vehicle Licence Plate Program |url=http://www.mto.gov.on.ca/english/vehicles/electric/green-licence-plate.shtml |website=Ministry of Transportation |publisher=Government of Ontario |accessdate=2018-07-23}}</ref>
====Quebec====
[[Quebec]] began offering rebates of up to {{CAD|8000}} (~ {{USD|8358}}) beginning on January 1, 2012, for the purchase of new plug-in electric vehicles equipped with a minimum of 4 [[kWh]] battery, and new [[hybrid electric vehicle]]s were eligible for a {{CAD|1,000}} rebate. All-electric vehicles with high-capacity battery packs were eligible for the full {{CAD|8,000}} rebate, and lower incentives were set for low-range electric cars and plug-in hybrids. Quebec's government earmarked {{CAD|50 million}} (~ {{USD|49.9 million}}) for the program, and the maximum rebate amount was set to be slowly reduced every year until a maximum of {{CAD|3,000}} in 2015, but the rebates would continue until the fund runs out. There was also a ceiling for the maximum number of eligible vehicles: 10,000 for all-electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids, and 5,000 for conventional hybrids.<ref name=QuebecRebate>{{cite web|url=http://green.autoblog.com/2011/04/11/quebec-offer-plug-in-vehicle-rebates-8000-dollars/|title= Quebec to offer plug-in vehicle rebates of up to C$8,000 |first=Eric |last=Loveday |publisher=AutoblogGreen |date=2011-04-11|accessdate=2011-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vehiculeselectriques.gouv.qc.ca/english/pdf/action-plan.pdf|title=Running on Green Power! Electric Vehicles: 2011-2020 Québec Action Plan |publisher=Gouvernement du Québec|year=2011|accessdate=2011-06-08}} ''See Table Box 7 for the rebate details and how it changes by year.''</ref>
[[File:Mitsubishi i-MiEV Hydro-Québec.JPG|thumb|left|[[Mitsubishi i MiEV]] from [[Hydro-Québec]] showcased at the 2012 [[Montreal International Auto Show]].]]
In November 2013, the provincial government announced its decision to earmark in 2014 an additional {{CAD|65 million}} (~ {{USD|45.5 million}}) to fund a three-year extension to the electric-vehicle rebate program. The maximum rebate was kept at {{CAD|8000}}, but a graded scale was introduced in order to spread the incentive over 10,000 or more vehicles.<ref name=Quebec2014>{{cite news | url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1088156_will-quebec-join-california-oregon-as-electric-car-pioneers | title=Will Quebec Join California, Oregon As Electric-Car Pioneers? | first=Matthew |last=Klippenstein | work=Green Car Reports | date=2013-11-07 | accessdate=2016-10-28}}</ref> Quebec's government also set the goal to deploy 12,500 more electric vehicles in the province by 2017, consisting of 10,200 consumer cars, 325 taxis, and 2,000 government-fleet vehicles. Also, incentives were issued for "greening" 525 taxis, aimed to introduce 325 plug-in vehicles (275 plug-in hybrids and 50 all-electrics) and 200 conventional hybrids. The purchase incentives start at {{CAD|20,000}} for battery-electric taxis, {{CAD|12,000}} for plug-in hybrids, and {{CAD|3,000}} for conventional hybrids, with the rebate declining over time. The province planned to also subsidize 125 Level 2 stations for the taxi industry, paying 75% of the cost up to {{CAD|5,000}}, and pay for the majority of costs to fund 10 Level 3 chargers for taxis.<ref name=Quebec2014/>
Also in 2013, the provincial government announced it support to deploy 5,000 new charging stations. A total of 500 stations were to be located around various cities and along the province's so-called Electric Circuit route, another 1,000 near government buildings, and 3,500 at various workplaces for employee use. Businesses are eligible for a 75% rebate on installation costs up to {{CAD|5,000}} for Level 1 or Level 2 charging stations. In addition, a 50% rebate will continue to be offered to individuals for installation of home charging stations, with a maximum of {{CAD|1,000}}.<ref name=Quebec2014/> Also the government announced an initiative for the gradual electrification of the provincial government's own vehicle fleet. The goal is to replace vehicles of the provincial government's 34 ministers (cabinet-level officials) with plug-in hybrid or pure electric vehicles by March 2017. The government expects to bring 2,000 plug-in vehicles into the provincial fleet over the same time.<ref name=Quebec2014/>
In October 2016, the [[National Assembly of Quebec]] passed a new zero emission vehicle legislation that obliges any carmaker who sells in the Canadian province more than 4,500 new vehicles per year over a three-year average, to offer their customers a minimum number of plug-in hybrid and all-electric models. Under the new law, 3.5% of the total number of autos sold by carmakers in Quebec have to be [[zero emissions vehicle]]s (ZEV) starting in 2018, rising to 15.5% in 2020. A [[Carbon credit|tradable credit system]] was created for those carmakers not fulfilling their quotas to avoid financial penalties. The quotas will be determined by Quebec's [[Ministry of Sustainable Development, Environment and Parks (Quebec)|Ministry of Sustainable Development]]. Quebec became the first Canadian province to pass such legislation, joining ten U.S. states, including California, that have similar ZEV laws. Quebec aims to have 100,000 zero emission vehicles on the road by 2020.<ref name=QuebecPEVs>{{cite web |url=http://www.avere-france.org/Site/Article/?article_id=6747&from_espace_adherent=0 |title=L'Assemblée nationale du Québec adopte la loi véhicules zéro émission | language=French | trans-title=Quebec's National Assembly enacted a zero emissions vehicle law |publisher=France Mobilité Électrique - AVERE France |date=2016-10-28 |accessdate=2016-10-28}}</ref><ref name=QuebecZEV>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/canada-autos-quebec-idUSL1N1CW1TZ | title=Quebec approves new law to boost sales of zero emission vehicles | first=Allison |last=Lampert | work=[[Reuters]] | date=2016-10-26 | accessdate=2016-10-28}}</ref> Initially, the provincial government set the goal in 2011 to have 300,000 plug-in vehicles on the roads by 2020.<ref name=QuebecRebate/>
====British Columbia==== [[File:Model S Charging at Parksville beach BC Canada.jpg|thumb|[[Tesla Model S]] charging in [[Parksville, British Columbia]].]]
As of April 1, 2015, [[British Columbia]]'s Clean Energy Vehicle (CEV) Program, funded by the Government of British Columbia and administered by the New Car Dealers of British Columbia industry group, was renewed with funding for approximately 1250 to 1500 vehicles. This program will expire on March 31, 2020 or when the {{CAD|6,355,000}} in new funding is depleted.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cevforbc.ca/clean-energy-vehicle-program |title=Clean Energy Vehicle Program {{!}} Clean Energy Vehicles for British Columbia |publisher=New Car Dealers Association of BC |location=Canada |date=2018 |access-date=2018-09-23}}</ref> The current levels of incentives are: {{CAD|5000}} for an EV (min.15 kWh capacity), {{CAD|2500}} for a plug-in hybrid or an extended range vehicle with a smaller battery capacity (min. 4 kWh capacity) and up to {{CAD|6000}} for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, these amounts may be reduced annually. All vehicles must be new and purchased in BC, each claim is processed by the dealer at the Point of Sale and deducted from the vehicle price. The previous program that provided funding to cover part of the cost of installing home EV charging equipment has been discontinued. There is also a separate provincially funded "SCRAP-IT" program with incentives for scrapping model year 2000 or earlier, conventional gas powered vehicles. Basic incentives range from bus passes to coop car-share membership credits, or {{CAD|200}} in cash. However, there is also the option of applying for a {{CAD|3000}} rebate cheque (plus {{CAD|250}} off the Point of Sale purchase price) when buying a new or used EV (min.15 kWh capacity). The "SCRAP-IT" rebate program currently brings the combined provincial incentives available to buyers of a qualifying new EV in BC to {{CAD|8250}}.
The Government of British Columbia had announced the ''LiveSmart BC'' program, which started offering rebates of up to {{CAD|5,000}} per eligible clean energy vehicle commencing on December 1, 2011. The incentives were available until March 31, 2013 or until available funding were depleted, whichever came first. Available funds were enough to provide incentives for approximately 1,370 vehicles. Battery electric vehicles, fuel cell vehicles and plug-in hybrids with battery capacity of 15.0 kWh and above are eligible for a {{CAD|5,000}} incentive. Also effective December 1, 2011, rebates of up to {{CAD|500}} per qualifying electric vehicle charging equipment were available to B.C. residents who had purchased a clean energy vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livesmartbc.ca/incentives/transportation/|title=The Clean Energy Vehicle (CEV) Program|publisher=LiveSmart BC|date=2011-11-05|accessdate=2011-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111114150054/http://www.livesmartbc.ca/incentives/transportation/#|archive-date=2011-11-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livesmartbc.ca/incentives/transportation/vehicle_incentives_list.pdf|title=Table 1 –Examples of Clean Energy Vehicles and Incentive Levels|publisher=LiveSmart BC|accessdate=2011-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403123015/http://www.livesmartbc.ca/incentives/transportation/vehicle_incentives_list.pdf#|archive-date=2012-04-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> As of February 14, 2014, the Point of Sale Incentive Program and Residential Electric Charging Station Program had depleted their budgets and were no longer accepting applications for rebates prior to the Point of Sale incentive program being re-funded in April 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livesmartbc.ca/incentives/transportation/index.html|title=NEW February 14, 2014|publisher=LiveSmart BC|accessdate=2014-02-14}}</ref>
Since 2016, PHEV and BEV owners can apply for a special decal which permits access to high-occupancy vehicle lanes regardless of the number of passengers in the vehicle.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Meissner |first1=Dirk |title=Electric vehicles get HOV lane access in B.C. |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/electric-vehicles-hov-bc-1.3472255 |accessdate=September 28, 2018 |work=CBC News |agency=The Canadian Press |date=March 2, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Electric Vehicles & HOV Lanes |url=https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/transportation/driving-and-cycling/traveller-information/routes-and-driving-conditions/hov-lanes/electric |website=Government of British Columbia |accessdate=September 28, 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
=== Mexico === [[File:Parque_España_-_Ciudad_de_México_-_Auto_eléctrico_en_estación_de_carga.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Parque_Espa%C3%B1a_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Auto_el%C3%A9ctrico_en_estaci%C3%B3n_de_carga.jpg|thumb|'''EVstation (Parque España, Mexico City)'''. Evstations are free charging stations for PHEVs and electric devices (bicycles, motorcycles and mobiles). The service is provided by Imágenes y Muebles Urbanos (IMU), owners of the stations, and was approved by the Ministry of Urban Development and Housing and the Ministry of Mobility. 28 spots exist throughout Mexico City.]] Mexico has set a minimum goal of clean energies as part of the electric power generation mix in for the next years (25% in 2018, 30% in 2021 and 35% in 2024)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dof.gob.mx/nota_detalle.php?codigo=5421295&fecha=24/12/2015|title=Energy Transition Law|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Official Journal of the Federation|access-date=}}</ref> as a strategy to reach Greenhouse Gases (GHG) emission cuts. [[Efficient energy use|Energy efficiency]] is also regarded as one of the greater cost-benefit potential alternatives to achieve GHG reduction.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gob.mx/cms/uploads/attachment/file/214/ENE.pdf|title=National Energy Strategy 2014-2028|last=|first=|date=|website=Ministry of Energy|access-date=}}</ref> Moreover, the transport sector in Mexico represents 44.7% of the total final consumption of energy,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sie.energia.gob.mx/bdiController.do?action=cuadro&cvecua=IE7C02|title=Energy Information System|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Ministry of Energy - Energy Information System|access-date=}}</ref> almost 17% more than the world average (28%).<ref name=":22"/> Thus, replacing low fuel efficient transport with alternative fuels<ref name=":3" /> is regarded as a considerable contribution to reduce 50% of its GHG emissions by the year 2050, as established by the General Law on Climate Change commitments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www4.unfccc.int/submissions/INDC/Published%20Documents/Mexico/1/MEXICO%20INDC%2003.30.2015.pdf|title=Intended Nationally Determined Contribution - Mexico|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|access-date=}}</ref> Therefore, incentives for PHEVs have been created both at regional and federal levels to decrease cost of ownership for the end-consumers.
'''Minimum fuel efficiency by vehicle class'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diariooficial.gob.mx/nota_detalle.php?codigo=5379566&fecha=27/01/2015|title=Energy Efficiency Guidelines for the Federal Public Adminsitration|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Official Journal of the Federation|access-date=}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |'''Vehicle Class''' |'''Minimum Fuel Efficiency''' '''(km/l)''' |- |Subcompact |16.43 |- |Compact |14.39 |- |Multiple use |9.7 |- |Light truck class 1 |8.61 |- |Light truck class 2 |8.51 |}
==== Federal ==== In Mexico, there are several existing incentives regarding Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicles (PHEV) at a federal level. Fiscal incentives for end-consumers include higher daily lease tax deductions per car ($285 versus $200 MXN), higher tax deduction caps per car ($250,000 versus $175,000 MXN), and fiscal credits for up to 30% of investments for charging stations located in public places.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/LISR_301116.pdf|title=Income Tax Law|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Mexico's Chamber of Deputies|access-date=}}</ref> Furthermore, PHEVs are exempt of the tax on new vehicles (paid by the manufacturer, assembler or dealer).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diputados.gob.mx/LeyesBiblio/pdf/123_120117.pdf|title=Federal Tax Law on New Vehicles|last=|first=|date=|website=Mexico's Chamber of Deputies|access-date=}}</ref>
Also, the electrical power service contract for residential charging stations can be independent of household consumption under a commercial rate, which can save up to 40% on electricity compared to consolidating billing in the same meter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://saladeprensa.cfe.gob.mx/boletines/show/8381/|title=CFE promotes the use of electric vehicles with installation of independent meters on consumer's households.|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Federal Electricity Commission|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cfe.gob.mx/casa/4_Informacionalcliente/SiteAssets/Paginas/Para-contratar/Guiacontratacionservicios.pdf|title=Power service contract guide for charging stations for electric vehicles|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Federal Electricity Commission|access-date=}}</ref>
==== Regional ==== In [[Mexico City]], [[State of Mexico|Mexico State]] and [[Jalisco]], PHEVs are exempt from vehicular emission verification.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.senado.gob.mx/sgsp/gaceta/63/1/2016-04-28-1/assets/documentos/Dic_MA_PA_Vehiculos_Electricos.pdf|title=Opinion of the Committee on the Environment and Natural Resources to the Agreement point that urges federal government and governors or the 32 federation entities to implement actions that encourage the use of electric vehicles.|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Mexico's Senate of the Republic|access-date=}}</ref> They can instead obtain an exempt hologram which unbounds them from the restrictions imposed by the vehicular emission verification programs, which limits car usage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sedema.cdmx.gob.mx/programas/programa/verificacion-vehicular|title=Programs: Vehicle Verification|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Mexico's Ministry of the Environment|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sma.edomex.gob.mx/vehiculos_nuevos|title=Services and Procedures|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Mexico State's Ministry of the Environment|access-date=}}</ref> PHEVs are also exempt of the annual ownership vehicle tax in [[Baja California]], [[Durango]], [[Mexico City]], [[State of Mexico|Mexico State]], [[Nayarit]], [[Tlaxcala]] and [[Querétaro|Queretaro]].<ref name=":4" /> In Mexico City, they also have right to a 50% discount on other contributions (permits, concessions, registry, etc.), and models from 2002 to 2017 pay only an endorsement right for vehicle control services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.finanzas.cdmx.gob.mx/servicios/servicio/servicios-de-control-vehicular|title=Services: Vehicular Control Services 2017|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Mexico City's Ministry of
