Finance|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://data.finanzas.cdmx.gob.mx/tesoreria/controlvehicular/hibridosElectricos_2017.html|title=Ownership or use tax 2017: Electric and hybrid vehicles|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Mexico City's Ministry of Finance|access-date=}}</ref> Finally, in Mexico City, PHEVs also have preferential parking in private and public parking lots.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.paot.org.mx/centro/leyes/df/pdf/2016/LEY_MOVILIDAD_DISTRITO_FEDERAL_07_10_2016.pdf|title=Mobility Law|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Mexico City's Environmental and Territorial Ordering Office|access-date=}}</ref>
==== Charging station network ==== As of January 2017, in Mexico there were 700 public access charging stations for PHEVs that are privately owned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.energiaadebate.com/blog/1281/|title=CFE's CEO inaugurates substation and charging station for PHEVs number 700|last=|first=|date=2017-10-07|website=Energia a Debate|access-date=}}</ref> The [[Secretariat of Energy (Mexico)|Ministry of Energy]] and the state owned electric power utility, [[Comisión Federal de Electricidad|Comision Federal de Electricidad]], will destine $25 million MXN to install 100 more charging stations through 2017-2018 in the metropolitan areas of [[Guadalajara]], [[Monterrey]] and [[Mexico City]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/cartera/economia/sener-anuncia-instalacion-de-100-electrolineras-en-el-pais|title=The Energy Ministry announces the installation of 100 charging stations for PHEVs|last=|first=|date=20 September 2017|website=El Universal|access-date=}}</ref> As of now, users of the existing network can charge their PHEVs for free, as the cost of electricity is absorbed by the owners of the establishments where the charging stations are located.
===United States=== {{See also|Plug-in electric vehicles in the United States}}
==== Federal government ==== {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=Chevrolet Volt WAS 2010 8852.JPG|image2=Nissan Leaf 001.JPG|width=225|caption2=The [[Chevrolet Volt]] (top) and the [[Nissan Leaf]] (bottom) are PEVs eligible for a U.S. federal [[tax credit]] up to {{USD|7,500}}, and additional incentives in several states.}}
In his 2011 [[State of the Union address]], President [[Barack Obama]] set the goal for the U.S. to become the first country to have one million electric vehicles on the road by 2015.<ref name=USA0710/><ref name=SC0211/> For this purpose, his administration pledged {{USD|2.4}} billion in federal grants to support the development of next-generation electric vehicles and batteries.<ref name=USA0710>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/driveon/post/2010/07/obama-pushes-electric-cars-battery-power-this-week-/1|title=Obama pushes electric cars, battery power this week | work=USA Today | date=2010-07-14 |first=Chris|last=Woodyard}}</ref><ref name=SC0211>{{cite web |url=http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/news/progress_alerts.cfm/pa_id=152 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090323053421/http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/news/progress_alerts.cfm/pa_id%3D152 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-03-23 |title=EERE News: Recovery Act Announcement: President Obama Announces $2.4 Billion for Electric Vehicles |publisher=Apps1.eere.energy.gov |date=2009-03-19 |accessdate=2009-09-19 |df= }}</ref> The funds were allocated as follows: $1.5 billion in grants to U.S. based manufacturers to produce highly efficient batteries and their components; up to $500 million in grants to U.S. based manufacturers to produce other components needed for electric vehicles, such as electric motors and other components; and up to $400 million to demonstrate and evaluate plug-in hybrids and other electric infrastructure concepts—like [[truck stop]] charging station, [[electric rail]], and training for technicians to build and repair electric vehicles ([[greencollar job]]s).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calcars.org/calcars-news/1051.html |title=Obama's Pitches for Plug-In Hybrids: Videos, Transcripts, Clips |publisher=Calcars.org |date= |accessdate=2009-09-19}}</ref>
Considering that actual plug-in car sales were lower than initially expected, as of early 2013, several industry observers have concluded that Obama's one million goal was unattainable.<ref name=NYT062012>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/12/business/energy-environment/a123-us-backed-battery-maker-claims-breakthrough.html?_r=1&ref=automobiles|title=Shaky Battery Maker Claims an Advance|author1=Bill Vlasic |author2=Matthew L. Wald |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2012-06-11|accessdate=2012-06-12}}</ref><ref name=CBS062012>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18563_162-57445738/electric-vehicles-fall-drastically-short-of-obamas-1-million-goal/|title=Electric vehicles fall drastically short of Obama's 1 million goal |first=Sharyl |last=Attkisson |work=[[CBS News]]|date=2012-06-02|accessdate=2012-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20120417/AUTO01/204170368|title=Battery-powered autos proving a tough sell|first=David |last=Shepardson|work=[[The Detroit News]]|date=2012-04-17|accessdate=2012-06-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120611232950/http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20120417/AUTO01/204170368|archivedate=2012-06-11|df=}}</ref> As of December 2016, approximately 542,000 EVs have been sold to date in the U.S.<ref name=Recode>{{cite news|url=https://www.recode.net/2016/12/21/14041112/electric-vehicles-report-2016|title=There have now been over 540,000 electric vehicles sold in the U.S.|author1=Johana Bhuiyan|accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> According to a July 2012 study by Pike Research, cumulative sales will reach the one million goal set by the Obama Administration only in 2018,<ref name=Pike072012>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/07/pikepev-20120702.html|title=Pike Research projects plug-in sales to fall short of US 2015 target; strong growth through 2020|author=Pike Research|publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2012-07-02|accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref> while other analysts agree that the goal could be achieved in 2018.<ref name=US500k/> With only about 400,000 plug-in electric cars sold in the United States by the end of December 2015, [[United States Secretary of Energy|Secretary of Energy]], [[Ernest Moniz]], said in January 2016 that the one million goal may not be reached until 2020. According to the Secretary purchases have fallen well below President Barack Obama's goal due to low gasoline prices, which had a negative impact on sales. Also improvements in battery technology are required as lowering battery costs is "absolutely critical" to boost electric vehicle sales.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-electric-moniz-idUSKCN0UZ2MK |title= U.S. may not hit one million electric vehicles until 2020: official |first=David |last=Shepardson |work= [[Reuters]] |date=2016-01-21|accessdate=2016-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://fortune.com/2016/01/25/elon-musk-oil-prices-electric-cars/ |title= Tesla CEO Elon Musk Says Cheap Oil Will Hurt Electric Cars |first=Kirsten |last=Korosec |work= [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=2016-01-25|accessdate=2016-02-01}}</ref> U.S. cumulative plug-in sales since 2008 achieved the 500,000 unit milestone in August 2016.<ref name=US500k>{{cite news|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/americans-buy-their-half-millionth-plug-in-car/ | title=Americans Buy Their Half-Millionth Plug-in Car | first=Jeff | last=Cobb| work=HybridCars.com| date=2016-09-01| accessdate=2016-09-10}} ''See other figures in graphs.''</ref>
In March 2018, a group of America's [[Edison Electric Institute|largest electric utilities]] sided with U.S. automakers and asked Congress to preserve the tax credit in order to support the continued growth of sales of electric vehicles. Currently, there are hundreds of thousands of electric vehicles on the road. However, the auto industry is approaching a point at which the tax incentives will begin to expire. According to ''Daily Energy Insider'', "The utilities' efforts occur at a time when growth in electric sales is sluggish and electric companies see a possible opportunity to apply the latest battery technology to help serve their customers."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dailyenergyinsider.com/news/11363-utilities-ask-congress-keep-electric-vehicle-tax-incentive/|title=Utilities ask Congress to keep electric vehicle tax incentive|last=Yingling|first=Bill|date=2018-03-20|work=Daily Energy Insider|access-date=2018-03-22|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
===== New plug-in electric vehicles =====<!--move image?-->
The [[Energy Improvement and Extension Act of 2008]] granted tax credits for new qualified plug-in electric drive motor vehicles.<ref name="IRS2009" /> The [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009]] (ARRA) also authorized federal [[tax credits]] for converted plug-ins, though the credit is lower than for new PEVs.<ref name="IRS0409" /> [[American Clean Energy and Security Act of 2009]] (ACES) also has extensive provisions for electric cars. The bill calls for all electric utilities to, "develop a plan to support the use of plug-in electric drive vehicles, including heavy-duty hybrid electric vehicles". The bill also provides for "smart grid integration," allowing for more efficient, effective delivery of electricity to accommodate the additional demands of plug-in electric vehicles. Finally, the bill allows for the Department of Energy to fund projects that support the development of PEVs and smart grid technology and infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://energycommerce.house.gov/Press_111/20090331/acesa_discussiondraft.pdf |title=Discussion Draft of Waxman Markey ACES Bill |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813103414/http://energycommerce.house.gov/Press_111/20090331/acesa_discussiondraft.pdf |archivedate=2009-08-13 |df= }}</ref>
As defined by the 2009 ACES Act, a PEV is a vehicle which draws propulsion energy from a traction battery with at least 4 [[kwh]] of capacity and uses an offboard source of energy to recharge such battery.<ref name="IRS2009">{{cite web|url= https://www.irs.gov/irb/2009-48_IRB/ar09.html |title=Notice 2009-89: New Qualified Plug-in Electric Drive Motor Vehicle Credit|publisher=[[Internal Revenue Service]]|date=2009-11-30 |accessdate=2010-04-01}}</ref><ref name="IRS2009s">{{cite web|url= https://www.irs.gov/businesses/plug-in-electric-vehicle-credit-irc-30-and-irc-30d |title=Plug In Electric Vehicle Credit IRC 30 and IRC 30D (Summary) |publisher= Internal Revenue Service|work=www.irs.gov |accessdate= 2017-10-06}}</ref> The tax credit for new plug-in electric vehicles is worth $2,500 plus $417 for each kilowatt-hour of battery capacity over 4 kwh, and the portion of the credit determined by battery capacity cannot exceed $5,000. Therefore, the maximum amount of the credit allowed for a new PEV is $7,500.<ref name="IRS2009" /> Both the [[Nissan Leaf]] electric vehicle and the [[Chevrolet Volt]] plug-in hybrid, launched in December 2010, are eligible for the maximum $7,500 tax credit.<ref name="Yahoo0330">{{cite web |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/Nissans-electric-car-to-cost-apf-3270595876.html?x=0&sec=topStories&pos=6&asset=&ccode= |title=Nissan will sell electric car for just over $25K |publisher=Yahoo Finance |date=2010-03-30 |accessdate=2010-03-30 }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]], released in January 2012, is eligible for a $2,500 tax credit due to its smaller battery capacity of 5.2 kWh.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.greencarreports.com/blog/1040132_toyota-prius-plug-in-hybrid-on-sale-in-2011-less-than-10k-more |title=Toyota Prius Plug-In Hybrid On Sale in 2011, Less Than $10K More|publisher=GreenCarReports.com |first=John |last=Voelcker|date=2009-12-14 |accessdate=2010-04-18}}</ref> All [[Tesla, Inc.|Tesla]] cars and [[Chevrolet Bolt]]s are eligible for the 7,500 tax credit.
As granted by the 2009 ACES Act, electric vehicles produced after 2010 are eligible for an IRS tax credit from $2,500 to $7,500.<ref>{{cite web |title=Electric Vehicles: Tax Credits and Other Incentives |url=https://energy.gov/eere/electricvehicles/electric-vehicles-tax-credits-and-other-incentives |publisher=US Department of Energy (Office of Energy Efficiency & Renewable Energy) |access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref> There are some limitations and rules however that go along with the applied tax credit from electric vehicles. When an electric vehicle is leased, the tax credit is held by the manufacturer offering the lease, not by the lessee.<ref>{{cite news |title=Electric Vehicle Tax Credits: What You Need to Know |url=https://www.edmunds.com/fuel-economy/the-ins-and-outs-of-electric-vehicle-tax-credits.html |work=Edmunds |date=2017-03-29 |access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref> Other restrictions that affect PEV tax credit include limitation of credit for electric vehicles used in reselling purposes, terms requiring the vehicle to remain in the United States, and production by qualified sellers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Edmunds|title=Electric Vehicle Tax Credits: What You Need to Know|url=https://www.edmunds.com/fuel-economy/the-ins-and-outs-of-electric-vehicle-tax-credits.html|website=Edmunds|publisher=Edmunds|date=2018-01-12|accessdate=2017-11-28}}</ref>
;Phaseout [[File:US EV Federal Tax Credit phaseout example.gif|size=300|right|Example of phaseout]] These granted tax credits on PEV vehicles will phase out once 200,000 plug-in vehicles are sold in the U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cars.usnews.com/cars-trucks/how-does-the-electric-car-tax-credit-work|title=How Does the Electric Car Tax Credit Work?|last1=Vincent|first1=John|website=U.S News & World Report|publisher=U.S News & World Report|date=2017-02-15|accessdate=2017-11-28}}</ref> During this phase out period after 200,000 plug-in car sales, qualified producers will experience a drop in a tax credit of $7,500 to $3,750 for the next 6 months followed by a drop to $1,875 for another 6 months until the credit is ran out completely.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://insideevs.com/us-federal-7500-ev-credit-expiry-date-by-automaker-estimates/|title=US Federal $7,500 Electric Vehicle Credit Expiry Date By Automaker|last1=Cole|first1=Jay|website=InsideEVs|date=2017-01-12|accessdate=2017-11-28}}</ref>
{{external media | topic = |align=right | image1 =[http://blog.ucsusa.org/wp-content/uploads/Federal-incentive-tracking.png PEV tax credit development since 2011] <!-- from http://blog.ucsusa.org/dave-reichmuth/ev-incentives --> | image2 =[https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/iabb9G366Ek4/v1/800x-1.png PEV tax credit development since 2016] <!-- from https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-25/tesla-buyers-antsy-for-model-3-keys-months-after-1-000-deposit --> }}
The qualified plug-in electric vehicle credit phases out for a PEV manufacturer over the one-year period beginning with the second calendar quarter after the calendar quarter in which at least 200,000 qualifying vehicles from that manufacturer have been sold for use in the U.S. Cumulative sales started counting sales after December 31, 2009. After reaching the cap, qualifying PEVs for one quarter still earn the full credit, the second quarter after that quarter PEVS are eligible for 50% of the credit for six months, then 25% of the credit for another six months and finally the credit is phased out.<ref name="IRS2009" /><ref name="IRS2009s" />
In July 2018, [[Tesla Inc.]] was the first plug-in manufacturer to pass 200,000 sales and the full tax credit will be available until the end 2018, with the phase out beginning in January 2019.<ref name=TeslaPhaseout>{{cite web|url=https://insideevs.com/tesla-likely-passed-200k-deliveries/ |title=UPDATE: Tesla Has Officially Confirmed Passing 200k, Credit Safe until December | first=Wade | last=Malone | publisher=InsideEVs.com | date=2018-07-12 | accessdate=2018-12-02}}</ref> {{Asof|2018|10|31}}, [[General Motors]] combined sales of plug-in electric vehicles in the U.S. totaled 196,986 units and are expected to pass 200,000 early in 2019. Thereafter, the applicable tax credit reduces gradually until it is completely phase out beginning on January 1, 2020.<ref name=UStaxcredits2018>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/arielcohen/2018/11/30/gm-must-adapt-or-die-a-lesson-for-u-s-automakers/ |title=GM Must Adapt Or Die: A Lesson For U.S. Automakers |first=Ariel |last=Cohen |work=Forbes |date=2018-11-30| accessdate=2018-12-02}}</ref><ref name=UStaxcredit>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimgorzelany/2018/11/13/will-the-next-congress-extend-or-kill-the-electric-car-tax-credit/ |title=Will The Next Congress Extend, Or Kill, The Electric Car Tax Credit? |first=Jim |last=Gorzelany |work=Forbes |date=2018-11-13| accessdate=2018-12-02}}</ref>

;Studies A 2013 study published in the journal ''Energy Policy'' determined that current federal subsidies are "not aligned with the goal of decreased gasoline consumption in a consistent and efficient manner." In particular, hybrid-vehicle credit is given according to battery capacity rather than on the vehicle's [[all-electric range]]. Across the battery-capacity and charging-infrastructure scenarios examined, the lowest-cost solution is for more drivers to switch to traditional hybrid electrics or low-capacity plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs). Installing charging infrastructure would provide lower gasoline savings per dollar spent than paying for increased PHEV battery capacity.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://journalistsresource.org/studies/environment/sustainability/cost-effectiveness-plug-in-hybrids-charging-infrastructure | title=Cost-effectiveness of Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicle Battery Capacity and Charging Infrastructure Investment for Reducing U.S. Gasoline Consumption}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Peterson | first1 = Scott B. | last2 = Michalek | first2 = Jeremy J. | year = 2013 | title =Cost-effectiveness of Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicle Battery Capacity and Charging Infrastructure Investment for Reducing U.S. Gasoline Consumption | journal = Energy Policy | url = https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421512008415 | doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2012.09.059}}</ref>
A 2016 study conducted by researchers from the [[University of California, Davis]] found that the federal tax credit was the reason behind more than 30% of the plug-in electric sales. The impact of the federal tax incentive is higher among owners of the [[Nissan Leaf]], with up to 49% of sales attributable to the federal incentive. The study, based on a stated preference survey of more than 2,882 plug-in vehicle owners in 11 states, also found that the federal tax credit shifts buyers from [[internal combustion engine]] vehicles to plug-in vehicles and advances the purchase timing of new vehicles by a year or more.<ref>{{cite journal| title=Exploring the Impact of the Federal Tax Credit on the Plug-In Vehicle Market |first1=Gil |last1=Tal |first2=Michael A. |last2=Nicholas |journal=Transportation Research Record: Journal of the Transportation Research Board | volume=2572 |issue=|pages= |date=2016 |doi=10.3141/2572-11}} Published online 2008-02-11.</ref>
===== Plug-in conversion kits ===== [[File:Charging stations in SF City Hall 02 2009 01.jpg|thumb|[[Plug-in hybrid conversion#Conversions of gas-only hybrids|Plug-in electric drive conversion]] were also eligible for a maximum $4,000 federal tax credit. Shown here are normal [[Toyota Prius]]es that were converted to Plug-in hybrids recharging in [[San Francisco]].]]The 2009 ARRA provided a tax credit for [[Plug-in hybrid conversion#Conversions of gas-only hybrids|plug-in electric drive conversion]] kits. The credit is equal to 10% of the cost of converting a vehicle to a qualified plug-in electric vehicle and in service after February 17, 2009. The maximum amount of the credit is $4,000. The credit does not apply to conversions made after December 31, 2011.<ref name=IRS0409>{{cite web|url=https://www.energy.gov/taxbreaks.htm|title=Consumer Energy Tax Incentives: Plug-In Hybrid Conversion Kits|publisher=[[U.S. Department of Energy]]|accessdate=2010-04-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/article/0,,id=206871,00.html/|title=Energy Provisions of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009: Conversion Kits|publisher=[[Internal Revenue Service]]|date=2009-04-10 |accessdate=2010-04-01}}</ref>
===== Charging equipment ===== Through 2010, there was a federal tax credit equal to 50% of the cost to buy and install a home-based [[charging station]] with a maximum credit of {{USD|2,000}} for each station. Businesses qualified for tax credits up to $50,000 for larger installations.<ref name=Yahoo0330/><ref name=HC0310>{{cite web|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/incentives-laws/us-tax-incentives-plug-hybrids-and-electric-cars.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311193109/http://www.hybridcars.com/incentives-laws/us-tax-incentives-plug-hybrids-and-electric-cars.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-03-11|title=US Tax Incentives for Plug-in Hybrids and Electric Cars|publisher=HybridCars.com|date=2010-03-08|accessdate=2010-01-04}}</ref> These credits expired on December 31, 2010, but were extended through 2013 with a reduced tax credit equal to 30% with a maximum credit of up to {{USD|1,000}} for each station for individuals and up to {{USD|30,000}} for commercial buyers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plugincars.com/breaking-electric-car-charging-station-tax-credit-extended-lower-30-pre-stimulus-levels-106580.html|title=Electric Car Charging Station Tax Credit Extended, But at Lower 30% Pre-Stimulus Levels|publisher=PluginCars.com|date=2010-12-17|accessdate=2010-12-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plugincars.com/federal-and-local-incentives-plug-hybrids-and-electric-cars.html|title=Federal and Local Incentives for Plug-in Hybrids and Electric Cars|publisher=plugincars.com|date=2013-05-08|accessdate=2013-08-11}}</ref>
===== New proposals ===== [[File:Cadillac ELR 2013 NY Auto Show.jpg|thumb|left|An initiative by the [[Obama Administration]] to increase the maximum tax credit for plug-in electric vehicles to {{USD|10,000}}, would not apply to luxury vehicles with a sales price of over {{USD|45,000}}, such as the [[Cadillac ELR]] (shown) and the [[Tesla Model S]].]]
Two separate initiatives were pursued in 2011 to transform the tax credit into an instant cash rebate; these did not pass. The objective of both initiatives was to make new qualifying [[plug-in electric car]]s more accessible to buyers by making the incentive more effective. The rebate would have been available at the point of sale allowing consumers to avoid a wait of up to a year to apply the tax credit against income tax returns.<ref name=Rebate1>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/blog/1055032_senator-stabenow-7500-electric-car-credit-should-be-rebate|title= Senator Stabenow: $7,500 Electric-Car Credit Should Be Rebate|first=John |last=Voelcker|publisher=GreenCarReports.com|date=2011-02-08|accessdate=2011-02-16}}</ref><ref name=Rebate2>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/02/budget-20110214.html#tp|title=Obama FY 2012 budget proposes big boost for EVs and EV technology, cuts for hydrogen |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2011-02-14|accessdate=2011-02-16}}</ref> The first initiative was from Senator [[Debbie Stabenow]] who reintroduced the "Charging America Forward Act." This bill was introduced in August 2010 but was not voted by the full [[United States Senate|Senate]].<ref name=Rebate1/> The bill would have turned the tax credit into a rebate worth up to {{USD|7500}} for plug-in electric vehicles and also would have provided businesses with a tax credit for purchasing medium or heavy duty [[plug-in hybrid]] trucks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stabenow.senate.gov/?p=press_release&id=238|title=Charging America Forward Act to support Michigan-made vehicles|publisher=Stabenow.senate.gov|date=2011-02-08}}</ref> The other initiative was from the [[Obama Administration]] and was submitted in the FY2012 Budget as a provision to transform the existing credit into a rebate that would have been claimable by dealers and passed along to the consumers, this was not included in the Budget.<ref name=Rebate2/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plugincars.com/white-house-pushes-instant-7500-cash-rebate-towards-electric-car-purchases-106794.html|title=White House Pushes For a $7,500 Instant Cash Rebate Towards Electric Car Purchases|publisher=PluginCars.com|first=Nick |last=Chambers|date=2011-02-09|accessdate=2011-02-16}}</ref>
Another change plug-in tax credit was proposed by Senator [[Carl Levin]] and Representative [[Sander Levin]] who proposed to raise the existing cap on the number of plug-in vehicles eligible for the tax credit. The proposal would have raised that limit from the existing 200,000 PEVs per manufacturer to 500,000 units, this was not passed.<ref name=Rebate1/>
In March 2014 the [[Obama Administration]] included a provision in the FY2015 Budget to increase the maximum tax credit for plug-in electric vehicles and other advanced vehicles to {{USD|10,000}}. However, the new maximum tax credit would not apply to luxury vehicles with a sales price of over {{USD|45,000}}, which would be capped at {{USD|7,500}}. The proposal sought to remove the 200,000 vehicle cap per manufacturer after which the credit phases out over a year. Instead, the incentives would begin to phase out—falling to 75% of the current credit—starting in 2019 for all manufacturers, and would be completely phased out by 2022; this did not get included in the Budget.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20140304/AUTO01/303040118 |title=White House: Boost EV, alternative vehicle tax credits to $10,000 |first=David |last=Sheparson |work=[[The Detroit News]] |date=2014-03-04 |accessdate=2014-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310071656/http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20140304/AUTO01/303040118 |archivedate=2014-03-10 |df= }}</ref>
In November 2017, House Republicans proposed scrapping the $7,500 tax credit as part of a sweeping tax overhaul,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tax-vehicles/house-republicans-propose-to-scrap-7500-electric-vehicle-credit-idUSKBN1D2282|title=House Republicans propose to scrap $7,500 electric vehicle credit|date= 2017-11-02|work=Reuters|accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref> but the final bill passed left the credit intact.
==== {{Anchor|California}} In California ==== {{See also|Plug-in hybrids in California#Government incentives|l1=Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles in California}} [[File:Model S 04 2015 Berkeley 1849.JPG|thumb|The [[Tesla Model S]] is eligible for a {{USD|7,500}} federal tax credit and a rebate in [[California]], depending on income.]]
The Clean Vehicle Rebate Project (CVRP), initially funded with a total of {{USD|4.1}} million by the [[California Environmental Protection Agency]]'s [[Air Resources Board]] (ARB), was established in order to promote the production and use of [[zero-emission vehicle]]s (ZEVs), including plug-in electric and [[fuel cell vehicle]]s. The program was created from Assembly Bill 118 that was signed by [[Arnold Schwarzenegger|Governor Schwarzenegger]] in October 2007. The funding is provided on a first-come, first-served basis, and the project is expected to go through 2015.<ref name=CalCVRP>{{cite web|url= http://energycenter.org/index.php/incentive-programs/clean-vehicle-rebate-project |title=Clean Vehicle Rebate Project|publisher=Center for Sustainable Energy|accessdate=2010-04-01}}</ref>
[[File:11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg|thumb|left|Besides a {{USD|2,500}} federal tax credit, the [[Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid]] is eligible for a rebate in [[California]], depending on income.]] Eligible vehicles include only new ARB-certified or approved zero-emission or plug-in hybrid electric vehicles. A list of eligible vehicles can be found on the California Center for Sustainable Energy web site.<ref name=CalifEligible/> Among the eligible vehicles are [[neighborhood electric vehicle]]s, [[battery electric vehicle|battery electric]], [[plug-in hybrid|plug-in hybrid electric]], and [[fuel cell]] vehicles including cars, trucks, medium- and heavy-duty commercial vehicles, and zero-emission motorcycles. Vehicles must be purchased or leased on or after March 15, 2010. Rebates of up to $5,000 per light-duty vehicle are available for individuals and business owners who purchase or lease new eligible vehicles. Certain zero-emission commercial vehicles are also eligible for rebates up to $20,000.<ref name=CalCVRP/><ref name=CalifEligible>{{cite web|url= http://energycenter.org/index.php/incentive-programs/clean-vehicle-rebate-project/cvrp-eligible-vehicles |title=CVRP Eligible Vehicles|publisher=Center for Sustainable Energy California|accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref>
[[File:2011 Chevrolet Volt NRMA cropped.jpg|thumb|The 2012 [[Chevrolet Volt]] fitted with a low emissions package qualifies in California for the {{USD|1,500}} CVRP rebate and since February 2012 have free access to [[high-occupancy vehicle lane]]s.]]
As of early September 2012, private individuals accounted for 88% of rebate funds reimbursed.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://wheels.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/28/california-issues-10000th-rebate-for-zero-emissions-incentive-program/?ref=automobiles |title=California Issues 10,000th Rebate for Zero-Emissions Incentive Program |first=Tori |last=Tellem |publisher=The New York Times |date=2012-09-28 |accessdate=2012-09-29}}</ref> As of early March 2013, CARB has issued about 18,000 rebates totaling {{USD|41}} million.<ref name=CEC2013>{{cite web|url= http://www.greencarcongress.com/2013/03/cec-20130301.html |title=California Energy Commission awards $4.5M to ARB for more clean vehicle rebates|author=California Energy Commission|publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2013-03-01 |accessdate=2013-03-03}}</ref> However, CARB notices that approximately 2,300 Chevrolet Volts were sold in California before the Volt became eligible for the rebate in February 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://energycenter.org/index.php/incentive-programs/clean-vehicle-rebate-project/cvrp-project-statistics |title=Clean Vehicle Rebate Project Statistics |publisher=[[California Center for Sustainable Energy]] |date=March 2013 |accessdate=2013-03-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130119223428/http://energycenter.org/index.php/incentive-programs/clean-vehicle-rebate-project/cvrp-project-statistics |archivedate=2013-01-19 |df= }}</ref> As a result of the rebate and other existing incentives, such as allowing solo drivers in HOV lanes, California is the leading PEV market in the United States with about 40% of all new plug-in electric vehicles sold nationwide during 2011 and 2012, while the state represents about 10% of all new car sales in the country.<ref name=CEC2013/>
{{As of|2014|03|10}}, a total of 52,264 clean vehicle rebates have been issued by the CVRP, for a total of {{USD|110,222,866}} disbursed, with only {{USD|3.8 million}} remaining for fiscal year 2013-2014. {{As of|2014|04}}, the CVRP was facing an estimated {{USD|30 million}} funding shortfall for the 2013-14 fiscal year, and uncertainty about additional funding for the 2014-15 fiscal year. CARB staff presented a proposal to the board to overcome the funding shortage and also to facilitate the rebates to benefit buyers in disadvantaged communities who live in areas with bad air quality or who can't afford high-end electric cars.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://capitolweekly.net/tesla-rebates-california-cap-msrp/ |title=ARB, Tesla at odds over rebate cuts for electric vehicles|first=John |last=Howard|work=Capitol Weekly|date=2014-04-10 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref>
A bill signed into law in September 2014, mandated the CARB to draft a financial plan to meet California's goal of putting one million vehicles on the road while making sure that disadvantaged communities can participate. CARB had to change the Clean Vehicle Rebate program to provide an extra credit for low-income drivers who wish to purchase or lease an electric car. CARB also provides assistance to [[carsharing]] programs in low-income neighborhoods and install charging stations in apartment buildings in those communities. Under bill SB 1275, low-income residents who agree to scrap older, polluting cars will also get a clean vehicle rebate on top of existing payments for junking smog-producing vehicles.<ref name=SFG092014>{{cite news|url= http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Brown-signs-several-clean-air-vehicle-bills-5771184.php |title=Brown signs several clean-air vehicle bills|first=Marisa |last=Lagos|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=2014-09-22 |accessdate=2014-09-22}}</ref><ref name=Green77K>{{cite news|url= http://www.latimes.com/local/political/la-me-pc-brown-electric-vehicles-20140921-story.html |title=Gov. Jerry Brown signs bills to boost purchases of electric cars|first1= Melanie |last1=Mason |first2=Patrick |last2=McGreevy |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2014-09-21|accessdate=2014-09-21}}</ref>
Another bill signed into law in September 2014, AB 1721, grants clean air vehicles free or reduced rates in [[high-occupancy toll lane]]s (HOT) lanes.<ref name=SFG092014/><ref name=GCC092014>{{cite web|url= http://www.greencarcongress.com/2014/09/20140922-california.html |title=California governor signs 6 bills to advance state's electric vehicle market; HOT and HOV benefits|first=Mike |last=Millikin|publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2014-09-22|accessdate=2014-09-23}}</ref> AB 2565 facilitates access to charging stations by requiring commercial and residential property owners to approve installation if the charging station meets requirements and complies with the owner's process for approving a modification to the property.<ref name=SFG092014/><ref name=GCC092014/>
{{As of|2016|03|29}}, California added income-based caps to its rebate system. Buyers with incomes less than 300% of the [[Federal poverty level]] will get up to {{USD|3,000}} for a plug-in hybrid, {{USD|4,000}} for an all-electric car, and {{USD|6,500}} for a hydrogen fuel-cell car and the rebate scales down until Californian buyers with incomes over {{USD|250,000}} are no longer are eligible for incentives on hybrids or electric cars, however can get {{USD|5,000 for a hydrogen fuel-cell car}}.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1098988_california-ends-electric-car-rebates-for-wealthiest-buyers-boosts-them-for-poorest |title=California Ends Electric-Car Rebates For Wealthiest Buyers, Boosts Them For Poorest |first=Stephen |last=Edelstein |work=Green Car Reports |date=2015-07-15 |accessdate=2015-07-28}}</ref><ref name=cvrIncome>{{cite web|url=https://cleanvehiclerebate.org/eng/income-eligibility|title=Income Eligibility|date= 2016-05-31 |publisher= |accessdate= 2017-07-26}}</ref> As of March 2016, the Center for Sustainable Energy has issued more than $291 million in the CVRP for over 137,200 vehicles since 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2016/03/15/psa-california-clean-vehicle-rebate/ |title=PSA: California Clean Vehicle Rebate is increasing for low- and moderate-income drivers, and going away for high-income drivers on March 29 |first=Fred |last=Lambert |work= [[Electrek]] |location=US |date=2016-03-15 |access-date=2016-08-24}}</ref>
The income-base caps went into effect on 1 November 2016. Residents will not be eligible for rebates if their gross annual income exceeds {{USD|150,000}} for single tax filers, {{USD|204,000}} for head of household filers and {{USD|300,000}} for joint filers.<ref name=cvrIncome/> These limits do not apply to the purchase of [[fuel cell electric vehicle]]s, which represent less than 1% of rebate applications.<ref name=CVRP112016>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2016/11/20161108-berk.html |title=Berkeley study finds clean vehicle rebates have predominantly benefited wealthy, white Californians |first=Mike |last=Millikin |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2016-11-08 |accessdate=2016-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-electric-car-rebates-20161031-story.html | title=California's electric-car rebates jump for lower-income buyers and vanish for more high earners | first=Rob |last=Nikolewski | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=2016-10-31 | accessdate=2016-11-09}}</ref>
The standard tax credits (on eligible cars) are $1,500 for plug-in hybrids, $2,500 for all-electrics, and $5,000 for fuel cell cars.<ref name=CVReligiblecars>{{cite web|url= https://cleanvehiclerebate.org/eng/eligible-vehicles |title=CVRP Eligible Vehicles|publisher= |accessdate=2017-07-26}}</ref>
=====Access to HOV lanes===== {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=Cal green sticker CMax Energi 04 2015 SFO 2530.JPG|caption1=California's green Clean Air Vehicle sticker for plug-in hybrids|image2=Cal white sticker Model S 04 2015 Berkeley 1845.JPG|caption2=California's white Clean Air Vehicle sticker for all-electric cars}}
In California a vehicle that meets specified emissions standards may be issued Clean Air Vehicle (CAV) decals that allow the vehicle to be operated by a single occupant in California's [[high-occupancy vehicle lane]]s (HOV), or [[carpool]] or diamond lanes. All-electric vehicles are classified as Federal Inherently Low Emission Vehicles (ILEVs), and as zero emissions vehicles are entitled to an unlimited number of white CAV stickers. Green CAV stickers were initially available to a limited number of applicants that purchased or leased cars meeting California's Enhanced Advanced Technology Partial Zero Emission Vehicle (Enhanced AT PZEV) or Transitional Zero-Emission Vehicle (TZEV) requirements, for which plug-in hybrids classify. The green car sticker cap was increased several times, and since September 2016 the cap was removed.<ref name=CAVdecal>{{cite web|url= http://www.dmv.ca.gov/vr/decal.htm |title=Clean Air Vehicle (CAV) Decals - High Occupancy Vehicle HOV Lane Usage |publisher=Department of Motor Vehicles |location=California|date=March 2014|accessdate=2014-07-12}}</ref>
Research performed in 2015 by the [[UCLA Luskin School of Public Affairs|UCLA Luskin Center for Innovation]] found that access to HOV lanes has a significant impact on plug-in car sales. Researchers linked automobile sales to a sample of more than 7,000 of the 8,057 [[census tracts]] in California for the study, including Los Angeles, Sacramento, San Diego and San Francisco. The study concluded that the ability to use potentially time-saving HOV lanes prompted the purchase of more than 24,000 plug-in electric cars and hybrids in the four urban areas from 2010 to 2013, or about 40% of the total of such vehicles. The UCLA researcher concluded that without the policy giving plug-in vehicles access to HOV lanes, total plug-in sales in the same study areas would have been only 36,692 for the three-year period.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.latimes.com/science/la-me-1111-california-commute-20151111-story.html |title=Law expanding HOV access to plug-in cars drives higher sales, UCLA study says|first=Dan |last=Weikel|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2015-11-10 |accessdate=2015-11-22}}</ref>
==== All states ==== {{main|Plug-in electric vehicles in the United States#State incentives}} {{As of|2014|11}}, 37 states and [[Washington, D.C.]] have established incentives and [[tax exemption]]s for [[battery electric vehicle|BEV]]s and [[Plug-in hybrid|PHEV]]s, or utility-rate breaks, and other non-monetary incentives such as free parking and [[high-occupancy vehicle lane]] access.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2025117609_electriccarsxml.html |title=Inslee pushes incentives for electric cars |first=Phuong |last=Le |publisher=[[The Seattle Times]] |work=[[The Associated Press]] |date=2014-11-27 |accessdate=2014-11-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128050135/http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2025117609_electriccarsxml.html |archivedate=2014-11-28 |df= }}</ref> All states are eligible for the $7,500 income tax credit.
=={{Anchor|Oceania}} Australia==
===Federal incentives===
In Australia, the [[Government of Australia|Federal Government]] offers no direct incentives for electric vehicle ownership and imposes a substantial financial ''disincentive'' by way of a Federal [[Luxury Car Tax]] that is applied on new vehicles valued over a certain threshold (in 2014–15, this was [[Australian dollar|A$]]61,884). The application threshold for this tax is increased to A$75,375 for fuel efficient vehicles - defined as those with a fuel consumption rating under 7 litres per 100 kilometres.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ato.gov.au/rates/luxury-car-tax-rate-and-thresholds/?fb_locale=en_GB&page=1|title=Australian Taxation Office - Luxury Car Tax rate and thresholds|publisher=[[Australian Taxation Office]]|accessdate=2015-01-15}}</ref> By definition, electric vehicles which do not use conventional fuel sources are covered by this classification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenvehicleguide.gov.au/GVGPublicUI/Information.aspx?type=ElectricVehicleInformation |title=Green Vehicle Guide - Electric Vehicle Information |publisher=[[Australian Government]] |accessdate=2015-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115080951/http://www.greenvehicleguide.gov.au/GVGPublicUI/Information.aspx?type=ElectricVehicleInformation |archivedate=2015-01-15 |df= }}</ref>
===State and Territory incentives=== Motor vehicle registrations in Australia are the responsibility of the [[states and territories of Australia|state and territory]] governments. Two of these jurisdictions offer incentives or rebates for electric vehicles:
====Victoria==== * In [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], hybrid and electric vehicles received a $100 annual discount on vehicle registration.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vicroads.vic.gov.au/registration/registration-fees/vehicle-registration-fees|title=VicRoads - Registration fees|publisher=[[VicRoads]]|accessdate=2015-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.themotorreport.com.au/50581/victorian-hybrid-and-ev-drivers-to-get-100-registration-rebate|title=Victorian Hybrids And EVs To Get $100 Rego Rebate; Opposition Calls Hybrid Camry A "Flop"|publisher=themotorreport.com.au|date=15 July 2010|accessdate=2015-01-15}}</ref>
====Australian Capital Territory==== * In the [[Australian Capital Territory]], [[stamp duty#Australia|stamp duty]] on motor vehicle purchases is reduced for lower emission vehicles - for electric vehicles with [[zero emission|zero tailpipe emissions]], the stamp duty is $0.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.accesscanberra.act.gov.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/2928 |title=Stamp Duty Payable upon registration or transfer of a motor vehicle |publisher=ACT Road Transport Authority |location=Australia |date=2016-01-25 |accessdate=2016-06-09}}</ref>
Electric powered vehicles are entitled to 20% discount on registration. The owner pays 20% less on the cost of the annual registration component, however must pay the full fee for compulsory third party insurance, road rescue fee, road safety contribution.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.accesscanberra.act.gov.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/694#!tabs-8|publisher=Access Canberra |title = Motor vehicle registration and renewal |location=Australia |date=2016-09-21 |accessdate=2017-08-21}}</ref>
There are no electric vehicle incentives in [[New South Wales]], [[Queensland]], [[South Australia]], [[Western Australia]], [[Tasmania]] or the [[Northern Territory]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aevasa.kestar.com.au/#Incentives|title=Australian Electric Vehicle Association - Incentives|publisher=[[Aeva]]|accessdate=2015-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://my.teslamotors.com/en_AU/incentives/AU|title=Nationwide Incentives - Australia|publisher=[[Tesla Motors]]|accessdate=2015-01-15}}</ref>
==Africa== ===Morocco=== Electric and hybrid vehicles are exempt from customs duties since 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2016/10/200202/morocco-introduces-tax-package-reward-eco-friendly-car-owners/ |title=Morocco Introduces Tax Package to Reward Eco-Friendly Car Owners |first=Ezzoubeir |last=Jabrane |work=Morocco World News |date=2016-10-31 |access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref>

[[File:SolarHouse5253.JPG|thumb|House with solar panels in [[Moshav]] [[Tkuma, Israel|Tkuma]]]] '''Green building in Israel''' refers to the practice and regulation of [[green building]] in [[Israel]].
==History== Israel has had its own voluntary Green Building Standard,for buildings with reduced environmental impact, IS-5281 since 2005. The standard is based on a point rating system, awarding up to 5 stars based on the number of points achieved (55 – 100) in 8 categories.
While the 2005 version covered only new residential and office buildings,a significantly revised and updated new version was approved in 2011, following pressure from professionals and market players. The new standard written with the help of BRE, the British office that wrote BREEAM, the UK Green Building tool,covers new buildings and buildings under significant renovation. This version was revised in August 2014.
A number of Israeli municipalities are currently using the standard as a mandatory part of their building licensing process. Together with complementary standards 5282 [classification of buildings according to energy use] and 1738 for [[sustainable products]] provides a system for evaluating the [[sustainability|environmental sustainability]] of buildings.<ref>[http://www.sviva.gov.il/English/env_topics/GreenBuilding/Pages/GreenBuildingStandards.aspx Green Building Standards]</ref>
United States Green Building Council [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] rating system has been implemented on some building in Israel including the [[Intel]] Development Center in [[Haifa]].
==Standard 5281== The Israeli Green Building Standard ('Buildings of Lesser Environmental Harm'), Standard 5281, was upgraded and expanded in 2011 in cooperation with the Ministry of Environmental Protection, the Standards Institute of Israel, the Ministry of Interior, Ministry of Building and Housing and the Israeli Green Building Council. While the old standard only applied to residential and office buildings, the revised version defined seven standards for seven types of buildings: residential, offices, healthcare institutions, public, commercial, education and tourism buildings.
The 5281 standard encompasses issues pertinent to every green building: energy, land, water, building materials, health and welfare of building users, waste, transportation, building site management and innovation. Each issue is divided into sub-categories that include rating and assessment criteria, and the score is determined in accordance with the project's compliance with the requirements.
A building is deemed a 'green building' if it meets the minimal requirements for each of the categories, as well as additional preconditions to minimize the building's "environmental footprint." The standard has five levels, ranging from one star to five stars.
The Israeli Green Building Council (ILGBC) publishes general and technical manuals that provide information on these standards and their implementation.<ref>[https://en-environment.tau.ac.il/PSESbuilding/Israeli_Green_Building_Standard Israeli Green Building Standard]</ref> ==See also== * [[Architecture of Israel]] * [[Ministry of Environmental Protection (Israel)]] * [[Environmental issues in Israel]] * [[Energy in Israel]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox court case | name = Hopkinson v Police | court = [[High Court of New Zealand|Wellington High Court]] | date_filed = | image = Coat of arms of New Zealand.svg | date decided = 23 July 2004 | full name = | citations = [2004] 3 NZLR 704 | judges = [[Ellen France|Ellen France J]] | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = | transcripts = | Keywords = [[Criminal law]], [[Flag desecration]], [[New Zealand Bill of Rights Act 1990]] }} '''''Hopkinson v Police''''' was a successful appeal by a protester convicted for the offence of [[flag desecration|burning]] the [[Flag of New Zealand|New Zealand flag]] with the intention of dishonouring it.''Hopkinson v Police'' [2004] 3 NZLR 704 The case is notable because of the High Court's interpretation of the Flags, Emblems, and Names Protection Act 1981 in a manner consistent with the [[New Zealand Bill of Rights Act 1990|Bill of Rights Act 1990]]. Justice Ellen France held that "the prohibition of flag burning under the Act was a breach of the right to freedom of expression, and such a limit was not justified under s 5 of the Bill of Rights."''R v Morse'' [2009] NZCA 623 at [87]. ==Background== On 10 March 2003 between 500 and 1000 people marched through central [[Wellington]] in protest at a visit of Australian Prime Minister [[John Howard]] to the New Zealand Parliament. The protest was against the Australian Government's support for the United States-led [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]]. During the protest Hopkinson held the New Zealand flag on a pole upside down and a Mr Phillips lit the flag with a cigarette lighter resulting in a fireball and a column of flame 2 metres high. As a result of the protest, Wellington schoolteacher Paul Hopkinson became the first person ever to be prosecuted under the Flags, Emblems, and Names Protection Act 1981 after burning a New Zealand flag at an anti-war protest in March 2003.{{Cite news|url = http://tvnz.co.nz/content/229906/423466/article.html|title = Flag burning trial under way|last = |first = |date = 20 October 2003|work = One News|access-date = 14 May 2015|via = }} Hopkinson was convicted in November in the [[District Courts of New Zealand|Wellington District Court]] of an offence under s 11(1)(b) of the Flags, Emblems, and Names Protection Act 1981; destroying the New Zealand flag with the intention of dishonouring it. Judge Noble ruled that Hopkinson had deliberately disrespected the flag to gain attention as he "sought to add weight to the effects of the protest".{{Cite news|url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/11/08/1068013410082.html?from=storyrhs|title = Teacher convicted of flag burning|last = |first = |date = 8 November 2003|work = AP|access-date = 14 May 2015|via = theage.com.au}} Hopkinson appealed the conviction on the basis that the District Court had failed to correctly interpret the Flags, Emblems and Names Protection Act 1981 in a manner consistent with the right to freedom of expression and of peaceful assembly under ss 14 and 16 of the Bill of Rights Act 1990. ==Judgment== Section 6 of the Bill of Rights required the Court to adopt a meaning of the word "dishonour" that could be read consistently with the Bill of Rights. Justice Ellen France held,
[81] Looking at the statutory scheme as a whole, there is some support for the respondent's view that there is just the one tenable meaning, namely, that adopted by the District Court Judge. However, the better view is that the statute does allow of the narrower meaning of “vilify”. If that meaning is adopted, as s 6 of the Bill of Rights demands that it must, I consider s 11(1)(b) can be read consistently with the Bill of Rights. However, I do not accept the respondent's submission that the appellant's conduct would fall foul of this narrower definition of “dishonour”, that is, one limited to dishonour in the sense of vilifying. That would have required some additional action on the appellant's part beyond a symbolic burning of the flag. My decision is of course confined to this particular appellant's conduct. What other conduct may come within this narrower interpretation of “dishonour” is a matter for a different case.
[82] On this basis, that is, that the prohibition on the appellant's conduct is not a justified limit on the right to freedom of expression and does not come within the proper Bill of Rights consistent interpretation of s 11(1)(b), the appellant's conviction cannot stand.
== See also == * [[New Zealand Bill of Rights Act 1990]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hopkinson v Police}} [[Category:High Court of New Zealand cases]] [[Category:2004 in New Zealand law]] [[Category:2004 in case law]] [[Category:Criminal law]] [[Category:Human rights in New Zealand]]

[[File:EricTheRedsLand.gif|right|thumb|Area of Greenland that was occupied by [[Norway]]]] The '''Ihlen Declaration''' was a statement made on 22 July 1919 by the [[Foreign minister of Norway]], [[Nils Claus Ihlen]], on the topic of [[Denmark]]'s [[sovereignty]] over [[Greenland]], in which Ihlen declared verbally to the Danish Minister that "...the plans of the Royal [Danish] Government respecting Danish sovereignty over the whole of Greenland...would be met with no difficulties on the part of Norway." The declaration became an issue when the question was raised whether the statement was binding on [[Norway]]. The question eventually went all the way to the [[Permanent Court of International Justice]] in the form of the [[Eastern Greenland Case]] in 1933.<ref name="General-Principles">{{cite book|last=Cheng|first=Bin|author2=Georg Schwarzenberger|title=General Principles of Law as Applied by International Courts and Tribunals|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2006|location=Oxford|pages=198–9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qE52nT_aD20C&pg=PA198&lpg=PA198&dq=Ihlen+Declaration&source=web&ots=Mk2xqkPkSe&sig=m3gIGI4SA1Aspj2Em1a3PwMREAs&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPA198,M1|isbn=0-521-03000-5 |id={{ISBN|9780521030007}}}}</ref><ref name="contemporary-issues">{{cite book|last=Fitzmaurice|first=Malgosia|author2=Olufemi Elias|title=Contemporary issues in the law of treaties|publisher=Eleven International Publishing|year=2005|pages=13–4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rD_DDw2Rr_EC&pg=PA14&lpg=PA14&dq=Ihlen+Declaration&source=bl&ots=TQ9IHf3w9k&sig=Q2vJDcLMy8HUy-1YTVMe_goia8M&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=10&ct=result#PPA13,M1|isbn=90-77596-06-2 |id={{ISBN|9789077596067}}}}</ref>
==The declaration== [[File:Nils Claus Ihlen.jpg|thumb|left|[[Foreign minister of Norway]] [[Nils Claus Ihlen]]]] In a meeting, Denmark agreed not to object to any claim to [[Spitsbergen]] which Norway might submit at an upcoming peace conference, if Norway would not oppose the Danish claim at the same conference to the whole of [[Greenland]]. This was on 4 July 1919. At the time, Norway occupied certain parts of East Greenland.
In response, Ihlen made the declaration on 22 July 1919 that "...the plans of the Royal [Danish] Government respecting Danish sovereignty over the whole of Greenland...would be met with no difficulties on the part of Norway."<ref name="contemporary-issues"/>
==Eastern Greenland Case== {{main|Eastern Greenland Case}} However, Norway continued to occupy East Greenland into the 1930s. This led Denmark and Norway to agree to take the case to the [[Permanent Court of International Justice]] in 1933. This led to several questions: Are affirmations made by one government to another binding? Was the declaration valid if it was made in violation of Norwegian municipal law article 46 - invalidity (article 27 - observance) of the [[Norwegian Constitution]] requiring consent by the [[Norwegian Parliament]] to enter into a treaty? Should Denmark have known that assent by the Norwegian Parliament was needed to make a treaty?<ref name="questions">{{cite web|last=Halvorssen|first=Anita M.|title=TREATIES|date=12 September|url=http://google.com/search?q=cache:KP0bNfZlr5UJ:sobek.colorado.edu/~halvorss/Intl-law%25204-8.ppt+Ihlen+Declaration&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=2&gl=us&client=firefox-a|format=PPT|accessdate=1 November 2008}}</ref>
The International Court at the Hague awarded the disputed territory to Denmark. The Court declared that the Ihlen declaration constituted an unconditional and definitive promise. The decision was accepted by both countries.<ref name="verdict">{{cite book|last=Lauterpacht|first=Elihu|authorlink=C. J Greenwood|author2=Olufemi Elias|title=International Law Reports|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2005|pages=379|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sM35IwUWriEC&pg=PA379&dq=Ihlen+Declaration&as_brr=3&ei=t-oMSdazE5bQzATm1c29CA|isbn=0-521-46395-5 |id={{ISBN|9780521463959}}}}</ref>

[[Image:TannerMapKingdomSardinia1839.jpg|thumb|370px|Savoy was part of the Kingdom of Sardinia (map of 1839, with Savoy at the top left in pink)]] '''Italian irredentism in Savoy''' was the political movement among Savoyards promoting annexation to the [[House of Savoy|Savoy dynasty's]] [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]]. It was active from 1860 to [[World War II]].
==History==
Italian irredentists were citizens of Savoy who considered themselves to have ties with the [[House of Savoy]] dynasty. Savoy was the original territory of the duke of Savoy that later became King of Italy's [[House of Savoy]]. Since the [[Renaissance]] the area rules over [[Piedmont]] and had for regional capital the town of ([[Chambéry]]). The official language of Savoy was French since the 15th century,<ref>Honoré Coquet, Les Alpes, enjeu des puissances européennes : L'union européenne à l'école des Alpes ?, L'Harmattan, 2003, 372 p. ({{ISBN|978-2-29633-505-9}}), p. 190.</ref> and was divided administratively in Savoie Propre (Chambéry), Chablais ([[Thonon]]), Faucigny ([[Bonneville, Haute-Savoie|Bonneville]]), Genevois ([[Annecy]]), [[Maurienne]] (Saint Jean de Maurienne) and Tarentaise ([[Moûtiers]]). [[Vaugelas]], a native of the duchy became one of the most renowned French linguist.
In spring 1860 the area was annexed to France after a referendum and the administrative boundaries changed, but most of the Savoyard population demonstrated against the annexation. Indeed, the final vote count on the referendum announced by the Court of Appeals was 130,839 in favour of annexation to France, 235 opposed and 71 void, showing an unbelievable complete support for French nationalism (that motivated strong criticism about rigged results).<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=pKQBAAAAYAAJ Wambaugh, Sarah & Scott, James Brown (1920), ''A Monograph on Plebiscites, with a Collection of Official Documents'', New York: Oxford University Press, p. 599]</ref> {{Quote|Presently, the situation seems the following : generally, it does not exist any will to separate Savoy and Piedmont. In the highest part of the country, Maurienne, Tarentaise and Upper-Savoy (Albertville and Beaufortain), the population is resolutely for the statu quo. In Genevois, Faucigny and Chablais, if ever should produce a change, the annexation by Switzerland is preferred to any other solution.<ref>F. ENGELS, ''Savoyen, Nizza und die Rhein'', Berlin, 1860</ref>}} At the beginning of the year 1860, more than 3,000 persons demonstrated in Chambéry against the annexation to France rumours. On 16 March 1860, the provinces of Northern Savoy (Chablais, Faucigny and Genevois) sent to [[Victor Emmanuel II]], to [[Napoleon III]], and to the Swiss Federal Council a declaration - sent under the presentation of a manifesto together with petitions - where they were saying that they did not wish to become French and shown their preference to remain united to the [[Kingdom of Sardinia]] (or be annexed to Switzerland in the case a separation with Sardinia was unavoidable).<ref>[http://notre.savoie.free.fr/default_a.htm Section: our country, Savoy / History]</ref> [[Image:Italy unification 1815 1870.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The [[Italian unification]] process was done even with the loss in 1860 of the Savoy province of the Kingdom of Sardinia. Savoy is located northwest in the map, on the upper left corner]]
[[Giuseppe Garibaldi]] complained about the referendum that allowed France to annex Savoy and [[Nice]], and a group of his followers (between the Italian Savoyards) took refuge in Italy in the following years. With a 99.8% vote in favour of joining France, there were allegations of [[vote-rigging]]<ref>[http://www.freesavoy.com/post/2009/09/21/Universal-suffrage-in-Savoy The Times (April 28 1860): Universal suffrage in Savoy]</ref>
Some opposition to French rule was manifest when, in 1919, France officially (but contrary to the annexation treaty) ended the military neutrality of the parts of the country of Savoy that had originally been agreed to at the [[Congress of Vienna]], and also eliminated the [[free trade zone]] - both treaty articles having been broken unofficially in World War I. France was condemned in 1932 by the international court for noncompliance with the measures of the treaty of Turin, regarding the countries of Savoy and Nice. Indeed, in 1871 a strong break away movement appeared in north and central Savoy against the annexation. The Republican Committee of the town of [[Bonneville, Haute-Savoie|Bonneville]] considered that "the 1860 vote, was the result of imperial pressure, and not the free demonstration of the will of our country" and called for a new Referendum: France sent 10,000 troops to Savoy to restore order.
In the [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]] was founded after 1861 the ''Associazione Oriundi Savoiardi e Nizzardi Italiani'' ,<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/bollettino01sociuoft/bollettino01sociuoft_djvu.txt Text (in Italian) of "Bollettino" from the Savoiardi association]</ref> an association of the Italian Savoyards that lasted one century until 1966.
During the [[Italian fascism|fascist]] period in the early 1940s, organizations were created that promoted the unification of Savoy to the Kingdom of Italy. The fascist members were nearly one hundred in 1942, concentrated mainly in [[Grenoble]] and [[Chambéry]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZcUNELPsQQsC&printsec=index&dq=davide+rodogno+fascism's+european+empire&psp=1&source=gbs_toc_s&cad=1#PRA7-PA148,M1 Fascism's European Empire -By Davide Rodogno]</ref>
When Italy occupied Savoy in November 1942 these fascist groups claimed that nearly 10,000 Savoyards demanded the unification to Italy, but nothing was done mainly because the [[Victor Emmanuel III|King of Italy]] opposed it.<ref>Vignoli, Giulio. ''Gli Italiani Dimenticati'' p. 130</ref>
After World War II all the organizations of the Irredentist Savoyards were outlawed by the French authorities of [[Charles de Gaulle]].
Most of the remaining Irredentist Savoyards supported in the 1950s and 1960s the development of autonomistic political organizations of Savoy, like the [[Mouvement Région Savoie]] (Savoy Regional Movement).
===Italian-occupied Savoy===
[[image:France map Lambert-93 with regions and departments-occupation.svg|thumb|left|200 px|The parts of Savoy under Italian control are highlighted in green]]Only in 1940 did the Italian Savoyards fulfilled their [[Italia irredenta|irredentism]], and some small areas bordering the [[Alps]] were annexed by Italy. The initial zone was 832 km² and contained 28,500 inhabitants.<ref name="GSWW311">Militärgeschichtliches Forschungsamt. ''Germany and the Second World War - Volume 2: Germany's Initial Conquests in Europe'', pg. 311</ref>
In November 1942, in conjunction with "[[Case Anton]]", the German occupation of most of [[Vichy France]], the [[Royal Italian Army (1940–1946)|Royal Italian Army]] (''Regio Esercito'') expanded its occupation zone. Italian forces took control of [[Grenoble]], [[Nice]], the [[Rhône River]] delta, and nearly all of Savoy.
A process of [[Italianization]] of the schools in Savoy was started, but was never fully implemented. Only a few Italian Savoyards were voluntarily enrolled in the Italian Army through fascist organizations like the [[Blackshirts|Camicie Nere]], most of them rejoined the resistance and fought against the invaders.
Most of the Irredentist Savoyards helped actively the Jews in the occupied zone in Savoy, a region that acted as a refuge for [[Vichy Regime#Vichy.27s racial policies and collaboration|Jews fleeing persecution in Vichy France]] during World War II.<ref>Robert O. Paxton. ''Vichy France, Old Guard, New Order''. 1972</ref>
The projects to unify Savoy to the Kingdom of Italy were supported by the fascist Savoyards of Grenoble{{citation needed|date=August 2014}}, but nothing was done even because in September 1943 [[Nazi Germany]] substituted Italy in the occupation of Savoy.
==The Savoyard dialect==
Savoyards historically have spoken a dialect related to the [[Arpitan language]]: the [[Savoyard dialect]]. Arpitan is spoken in France, in Switzerland and in Italy. However, [[French language|French]] is the predominant language today.
During the fascist occupation in 1940-1943, Italian authorities promoted a process of Italianization of all the people of Savoy, mainly related to the use of [[Italian language|Italian]] in substitution of the Savoyard dialect{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}.

Editions Cabédita. Lyon, 1996. * Rodogno, Davide. ''Fascism European Empire''. Cambrigge University Press. Cambridge, 2004. * Vignoli, Giulio. ''Gli Italiani Dimenticati''. Ed. Giuffè. Roma, 2000

{{Infobox Officeholder |name=Jefferson Rowe Thompson |image= |office=[[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana State Representative for District 8 (Bossier Parish)]] |term_start=2012 |term_end=2014 |preceded=[[Jane H. Smith]] |succeeded=[[Mike Johnson (Louisiana politician)|Mike Johnson]] |office2=Division B [[Judge]] of the Louisiana 26th Judicial District Court |term_start2=January 2015 |term_end2= |preceded2=[[Ford E. Stinson Jr.]] |succeeded2= |birth_name=Jefferson Rowe Thompson |birth_date={{birth date and age|1965|3|10}} |birth_place=[[Alexandria, Louisiana|Alexandria]], [[Louisiana]], U.S. |death_date= |death_place= |death_cause= |resting_place= |residence=[[Benton, Louisiana]] |spouse=Toni Estelle Hurst Thompson |children=2 |party= [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |occupation=[[Lawyer]] and [[Judge]] |religion=[[Southern Baptist]] |alma_mater=[[University of Louisiana at Monroe]]
[[Tulane University School of Law]] |footnotes= }} '''Jefferson Rowe Thompson,''' known as '''Jeff R. Thompson''' (born March 10, 1965), is a [[judge]] of the Louisiana 26th Judicial District Court for [[Bossier Parish, Louisiana|Bossier]] and [[Webster Parish, Louisiana|Webster]] parishes, who is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] former member of the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] for District 8, a position which he held from January 2012 to January 2015. A resident of [[Bossier City, Louisiana|Bossier City]], Thompson ran without opposition in the [[nonpartisan blanket primary]] held on November 4, 2014, to succeed the retiring Division B Judge [[Ford E. Stinson Jr.]], a [[Democratic party (United States)|Democrat]], on the 26th District Court.{{cite web|url=http://press-herald.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9892:thompson-announces-bid-for-district-judge&catid=34:local-news&Itemid=69|title=Thompson announces bid for district judge|publisher=''[[Minden Press-Herald]]''|accessdate=July 22, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/local/2014/08/20/desoto-da-minden-mayor-candidates-qualify/14331543/|title=Final day of qualifying in DeSoto, Webster|author=Vickie Welborn|publisher=''[[The Times (Shreveport)|The Shreveport Times]]''|accessdate=August 22, 2014}} ==Background== A graduate of [[Jena High School]] in Jena in [[Central Louisiana]], Thompson obtained degrees in [[real estate]] and [[insurance]] from the [[University of Louisiana at Monroe]] (1988) and the [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Tulane University Law School]] in [[New Orleans]] (1995). He was affiliated with [[Pi Kappa Alpha]] [[fraternity]]. While living in [[Monroe, Louisiana|Monroe]], he was from 1989 to 1992 the ULM (then Northeast Louisiana University) Associate Director of Development. He was also a reserve officer with the Monroe Police Department and an [[insurance agent]] for [[Ralph T. Troy|Troy]] & Nichols Mortgage Company. After obtaining his law degree with honors from Tulane University in New Orleans, Louisiana, he relocated to Bossier City to engage in the practice of law and is active in the bar association. He is a member of the large Cypress [[Southern Baptist|Baptist]] Baptist Church of Benton. He is affiliated with the [[National Rifle Association]] and was a district director of the Norwela Council of the [[Boy Scouts of America]]. In 2004, he was the president of the Bossier [[Chamber of Commerce]].{{cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/108814/jeff-thompson#.U_fpEctAQ5s|title=Jeff R. Thompson|publisher=[[Project Vote Smart]]|accessdate=August 22, 2014}} Thompson and his wife, the former Toni Estelle Hurst, reside in [[Benton, Louisiana|Benton]], the Bossier Parish [[County seat|parish seat]], where the 26th Judicial District Court convenes. The couple has two children, Lillie and Rowe Thompson. ==Political life== Thompson was elected to the House in 2011, when the term-limited incumbent, fellow Republican [[Jane H. Smith]] of Bossier City, ran instead, unsuccessfully, for the [[Louisiana State Senate]]. Thompson defeated fellow Republican, Michael Durrell "Duke" Lowrie (born April 1970), 4,991 (56.8 percent) to 3,803 (43.3 percent).{{cite web|url=http://staticresults.sos.la.gov/10222011/10222011_Legislative.html|title=Election returns, October 22, 2011|publisher=staticresults.sos.la.gov|accessdate=May 15, 2012}} Smith, meanwhile, was defeated by the Republican businessman [[Barrow Peacock]] of [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]] for the Senate seat vacated by [[B. L. Shaw|B. L. "Buddy" Shaw]]. In 2008, Thompson was an unsuccessful candidate for the [[United States House of Representatives]] for [[Louisiana's 4th congressional district]]. The seat opened when the incumbent [[Jim McCrery]] stepped down to become a [[lobbyist]]. Thompson finished in third place in the primary. The position went to the Republican physician and businessman [[John C. Fleming]] of [[Minden, Louisiana|Minden]], who held it until 2017. In the spring of 2012, Representative Thompson amended an anti-[[bullying]] bill sponsored by Patricia Smith, a Democrat from [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]]. [[Conservative (politics)|Conservative]] opponents of the bill claimed the measure is at odds with [[freedom of speech]] rulings by the [[United States Supreme Court]]. Thompson offered an amendment, which removed those sections of the bill that specify prohibitions against bullying in regard to only [[sexual orientation]], disabilities, and race. Smith said that the Thompson amendment effectively killed the focus of the legislation, and she withdrew it from further consideration. Thompson opposed bullying in schools for any reason and worked to protect the educational opportunities of all children.{{cite web|url=http://theadvocate.com/home/2606631-125/changes-doom-bullying-proposal |title=Changes doom bullying proposal |author=Will Sentell |date=May 1, 2012 |publisher=''[[The Advocate (Baton Rouge)|Baton Rouge Morning Advocate]]'' |accessdate=May 15, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120514130100/http://theadvocate.com/home/2606631-125/changes-doom-bullying-proposal |archivedate=May 14, 2012 |df= }} Representative Thompson served on the House Education, Homeland Security, Ways and Means, and Military and Veterans Affairs committees. He also sits on the Joint House and Senate Committee on Homeland Security. Thompson was a leader in the Louisiana legislature to address the over 17 millions pounds of propellant improperly and illegally stored at Camp Minden near Doyline, Louisiana. [[Mike Johnson (Louisiana politician)|Mike Johnson]], a Republican lawyer from Benton, was unopposed in the special election held in February 2015 to choose Thompson's successor in the House. Johnson is not the U.S. representative for the 4th congressional district. ==Court activities== In 2017, [[plaintiff]]s James Wheat and Danny Brinson, after their arrests in Bossier City for violating a state statute forbidding [[Begging|panhandling]], filled a [[class action]] lawsuit in the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana]] against Bossier Parish Sheriff Julian Curtis Whittington and all judges of the 26th Judicial District Court, including Chief Judge Parker Self and Judge Thompson. Wheat and Brinson allege that Bossier Parish unjustly jails defendants who cannot pay for [[bail]] or the required $40 fee to the office of the [[public defender]]. Nor does Bossier Parish permit defendants to seek a lowering of the bail amount, which is instead automatically set by the court. The suit claims that the parish has for years violated a "bedrock principle of our legal system that a person cannot be detained or imprisoned solely for their inability to pay a fee. Such an [[incarceration]] violates the [[substantive due process]] and [[Equal Protection Clause|equal protection]] clauses of the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]]."{{cite web|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/2017/03/21/lawsuit-claims-violation-constitutional-rights-impoverished/99467604/|title=Lawsuit: Bossier Parish routinely violates rights of poor|publisher=''[[The Times (Shreveport)|The Shreveport Times]]''|author=Sarah Crawford|date=March 21, 2017|accessdate=June 16, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://ksla.images.worldnow.com/library/4fcc84a0-2727-4274-9bd8-a676452413e8.pdf|title=''James M. Wheat and Danny Brinson v. Judges Mike Craig, Jeff R. Thomposn, Jeff Cox, E. Charles Jacobs, Mike Nerren, and Parker Self and Sheriff Julian Whittington''|publisher=[[KSLA]] Images|date=March 20, 2017|accessdate=June 17, 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-la-hs}} {{succession box |before=[[Jane H.
